Having won twenty guineas at whist, and taken leave of his friends, Phileas Fogg, at twenty-five minutes past seven, left the Reform Club. Punctual as usual, he returned to his house in Saville Row at half-past seven.  

Passepartout, who had conscientiously studied the programme of his duties, was much surprised at seeing his master guilty of the inexactness of appearing at this unaccustomed hour. According to rule, he was not due in Saville Row until midnight.  

Mr. Fogg repaired at once to his bedroom, and called out, "Passepartout!"  

Passepartout did not reply. It could not be he who was called; it was not the right hour.  

"Passepartout!" repeated Mr. Fogg, without raising his voice.  

Passepartout made his appearance.  

"I’ve called you twice," observed Mr. Fogg.  

"But it is not midnight," replied Passepartout, holding his watch in his hand.  

"I know it," said Phileas Fogg; "I do not blame you. We start for Dover and Calais in ten minutes."  

A puzzled grin overspread Passepartout’s round face; clearly he had not comprehended his master.  

"Are you going away, sir?" he asked.  

"Yes," returned Phileas Fogg. "We are going round the world."  

Passepartout opened wide his eyes, raised his eyebrows, held up his hands, and seemed about to collapse, so overcome was he with stupefied astonishment.  

"Round the world!" he murmured.  

"In eighty days," responded Mr. Fogg. "So we haven’t a moment to lose."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Having won twenty guineas at whist, and taken leave of his friends, Phileas Fogg, at twenty-five minutes past seven, left the Reform Club. The evening air was crisp as he stepped onto the gaslit streets of London, his mind already fixed on the extraordinary journey ahead. His measured footsteps echoed against the cobblestones, a testament to his unshakable precision.  

Passepartout, his newly hired valet, awaited him at home, unaware of the whirlwind adventure that would soon sweep them both across continents. Fogg’s expression remained as impassive as ever, betraying no hint of the audacious wager he had just made—to circumnavigate the globe in a mere eighty days. To him, it was a matter of mathematical certainty, not daring.  

As he hailed a cab, the clock tower of Westminster chimed faintly in the distance, a reminder that time, his most formidable opponent, had already begun its relentless march. Yet Phileas Fogg did not hurry. For a man who lived by the clock, every second was accounted for, and his confidence was as unshakable as his routine. The journey would test his resolve, but doubt was a luxury he could not afford.

events.title: Minimalist Packing and Passepartout's Disbelief
detailed_summary: A stunned Passepartout inquires about luggage.
Fogg states they will travel light with only a carpet-bag containing spare shirts and stockings, planning to purchase clothes en route.
He instructs Passepartout to bring his coat, cloak, and sturdy shoes, emphasizing speed.
Passepartout, speechless, goes to his room to prepare.
Overwhelmed, he sits down, lamenting the disruption to his desired quiet life.
He starts packing automatically, grappling with disbelief and questioning his master's sanity or motives.

He rationalizes the initial legs of the journey (Dover, Calais, perhaps Paris) and finds slight consolation in potentially revisiting France, but remains baffled by the overall venture and the sudden change in his habitually homebound master.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “But the trunks?” gasped Passepartout, unconsciously swaying his head from right to left.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But surely a gentleman so chary of his steps would stop there; no doubt—but, then, it was none the less true that he was going away, this so domestic person hitherto!

events.text_segment:
“But the trunks?” gasped Passepartout, unconsciously swaying his head from right to left.
“We’ll have no trunks; only a carpet-bag, with two shirts and three pairs of stockings for me, and the same for you. We’ll buy our clothes on the way. Bring down my mackintosh and traveling-cloak, and some stout shoes, though we shall do little walking. Make haste!”
Passepartout tried to reply, but could not. He went out, mounted to his own room, fell into a chair, and muttered: “That’s good, that is! And I, who wanted to remain quiet!”
He mechanically set about making the preparations for departure. Around the world in eighty days! Was his master a fool? No. Was this a joke, then? They were going to Dover; good! To Calais; good again! After all, Passepartout, who had been away from France five years, would not be sorry to set foot on his native soil again. Perhaps they would go as far as Paris, and it would do his eyes good to see Paris once more. But surely a gentleman so chary of his steps would stop there; no doubt—but, then, it was none the less true that he was going away, this so domestic person hitherto!

“But the trunks?” gasped Passepartout, unconsciously swaying his head from right to left. His face was a picture of dismay as he clutched at his master’s sleeve. “Monsieur, what of the trunks? We cannot leave them behind!”  

Phileas Fogg, ever unflappable, barely glanced at his agitated valet. “They will follow,” he replied coolly, adjusting his gloves. “The steamer departs in twenty minutes, and we shall not miss it.”  

Passepartout’s eyes widened. “But—but the shirts! The coats! The—”  

“They are of no consequence,” Fogg interrupted, already striding toward the docks. “Time, Passepartout, is the only thing we must not lose.”  

The poor valet groaned, casting one last despairing look at the luggage piled in the hotel lobby. To abandon such carefully packed belongings—it was unthinkable! Yet his master’s resolve was as immovable as the Rock of Gibraltar. With a sigh, Passepartout hurried after him, muttering under his breath about the perils of haste and the virtues of a well-stocked wardrobe.  

Thus, with nothing but the clothes on their backs and Fogg’s unshakable confidence, they embarked upon their mad dash around the world.

events.title: Final Preparations and Departure from Saville Row
detailed_summary: By 8 PM, Passepartout has packed the single bag, though his mind remains troubled.
After securing his room, he finds Mr. Fogg completely ready for departure.
Fogg is equipped with a Bradshaw's guide, containing railway and steamer schedules.
Fogg adds a substantial roll of Bank of England banknotes to the carpet-bag.
He verifies with Passepartout that nothing, including his outerwear, has been forgotten.
Fogg entrusts the carpet-bag to Passepartout, warning him to guard it well as it contains twenty thousand pounds.
The large sum makes Passepartout feel the bag's immense weight and responsibility.
They exit the house, lock the door, find a cab, and depart swiftly for Charing Cross station.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By eight o’clock Passepartout had packed the modest carpet-bag, containing the wardrobes of his master and himself; then, still troubled in mind, he carefully shut the door of his room, and descended to Mr. Fogg.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Master and man then descended, the street-door was double-locked, and at the end of Saville Row they took a cab and drove rapidly to Charing Cross.

events.text_segment:
By eight o’clock Passepartout had packed the modest carpet-bag, containing the wardrobes of his master and himself; then, still troubled in mind, he carefully shut the door of his room, and descended to Mr. Fogg.
Mr. Fogg was quite ready. Under his arm might have been observed a red-bound copy of Bradshaw’s Continental Railway Steam Transit and General Guide, with its timetables showing the arrival and departure of steamers and railways. He took the carpet-bag, opened it, and slipped into it a goodly roll of Bank of England notes, which would pass wherever he might go.
“You have forgotten nothing?” asked he.
“Nothing, monsieur.”
“My mackintosh and cloak?”
“Here they are.”
“Good! Take this carpet-bag,” handing it to Passepartout. “Take good care of it, for there are twenty thousand pounds in it.”
Passepartout nearly dropped the bag, as if the twenty thousand pounds were in gold, and weighed him down.
Master and man then descended, the street-door was double-locked, and at the end of Saville Row they took a cab and drove rapidly to Charing Cross.

He handed the carpet-bag to Passepartout, saying, ‘Take good care of it, for there are twenty thousand pounds in it.’ Passepartout nearly let the bag fall, as if the twenty thousand pounds were in gold, and weighed him down.  

Master and man then descended, the street-door was double-locked, and at the end of Saville Row they took a cab and drove rapidly to Charing Cross."  

*(Excerpt from* Around the World in Eighty Days *by Jules Verne, Chapter IV.)*

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Mr. Fogg was already waiting, impeccably dressed as usual, his expression calm and unreadable. Passepartout handed him the carpet-bag, his hands trembling slightly. "Everything is ready, sir," he said, though his voice betrayed his unease.  

Fogg checked his watch with mechanical precision. "Good. We leave at once."  

As they stepped outside, Passepartout hesitated. "Sir, forgive me, but—are you certain about this journey? Eighty days to circle the globe—it seems impossible!"  

Fogg’s gaze remained steady. "Impossible is a word I do not acknowledge. The train departs in twelve minutes. Come."  

Swallowing his doubts, Passepartout followed, his mind racing. What had he gotten himself into? Yet, as he hurried after his unshakable master, a spark of excitement flickered within him. Perhaps, just perhaps, the impossible was within reach.

events.title: Generosity, Farewells, and Boarding at Charing Cross
detailed_summary: The cab reaches the station shortly after 8:20 PM.
As Fogg prepares to enter after paying the driver, a poor beggar-woman carrying a child asks him for money.
Fogg gives her the entire twenty guineas he won at whist earlier, expressing satisfaction at having met her.
Passepartout is emotionally touched by his master's act of generosity.
After obtaining first-class tickets to Paris, Fogg encounters his five friends from the Reform Club.
He confirms his departure and suggests they can verify his journey's completion by checking his passport upon his return.
Mr. Ralph assures Fogg that they trust his word as a gentleman.
Mr. Stuart asks Fogg to confirm the exact date and time of his required return.
Fogg reaffirms the deadline: 8:45 PM on Saturday, December 21st, 1872, and bids them farewell.
At 8:40 PM, Fogg and Passepartout board a first-class carriage.
Five minutes later, the train whistle blows, and they depart from the station.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The cab stopped before the railway station at twenty minutes past eight.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg and his servant seated themselves in a first-class carriage at twenty minutes before nine; five minutes later the whistle screamed, and the train slowly glided out of the station.

events.text_segment:
The cab stopped before the railway station at twenty minutes past eight. Passepartout jumped off the box and followed his master, who, after paying the cabman, was about to enter the station, when a poor beggar-woman, with a child in her arms, her naked feet smeared with mud, her head covered with a wretched bonnet, from which hung a tattered feather, and her shoulders shrouded in a ragged shawl, approached, and mournfully asked for alms.
Mr. Fogg took out the twenty guineas he had just won at whist, and handed them to the beggar, saying, “Here, my good woman. I’m glad that I met you;” and passed on.
Passepartout had a moist sensation about the eyes; his master’s action touched his susceptible heart.
Two first-class tickets for Paris having been speedily purchased, Mr. Fogg was crossing the station to the train, when he perceived his five friends of the Reform.
“Well, gentlemen,” said he, “I’m off, you see; and, if you will examine my passport when I get back, you will be able to judge whether I have accomplished the journey agreed upon.”
“Oh, that would be quite unnecessary, Mr. Fogg,” said Ralph politely. “We will trust your word, as a gentleman of honour.”
“You do not forget when you are due in London again?” asked Stuart.
“In eighty days; on Saturday, the 21st of December, 1872, at a quarter before nine p.m. Good-bye, gentlemen.”
Phileas Fogg and his servant seated themselves in a first-class carriage at twenty minutes before nine; five minutes later the whistle screamed, and the train slowly glided out of the station.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  
The cab stopped before the railway station at twenty minutes past eight. Phileas Fogg and his servant got out of the vehicle. As Mr. Fogg was paying the cabman, a poor beggar-woman, with a child in her arms, approached him and asked for alms. Mr. Fogg took from his pocket the twenty guineas he had just won at whist, and handed them to the beggar, saying, "Here, my good woman. I'm glad to have met you." Then he passed on, followed by Passepartout, who was deeply moved.  

They at once entered the station, where Mr. Fogg procured two first-class tickets for Paris. Turning round, he perceived his five friends of the Reform. "Gentlemen, I am going," he said; "and the various visas upon my passport will enable you, on my return, to verify my journey."  

"Oh, Mr. Fogg," said Ralph, politely, "that is quite unnecessary. We will trust your word as a gentleman."  

"You remember that you are to be back—" began Stuart.  

"In eighty days," replied Mr. Fogg. "On Saturday, the 21st of December, 1872, at a quarter before nine in the evening. Good-bye, gentlemen."  

At forty minutes past eight Phileas Fogg and Passepartout took their places in the same compartment of the train. At five minutes before nine the whistle sounded, and the train started.  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The cab stopped before the railway station at twenty minutes past eight. Phileas Fogg stepped out, his usual calm demeanor undisturbed despite the urgency of his mission. Passepartout hurried behind him, clutching their modest luggage, his eyes darting nervously at the bustling crowd. The station was alive with the clamor of travelers, the hiss of steam engines, and the shouts of porters.  

Fogg consulted his pocket watch—a precise, habitual gesture—and confirmed they had just enough time to board the train to Dover. The journey to catch the steamer to Suez was critical; every minute counted in his audacious wager to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days.  

As they approached the ticket counter, Passepartout marveled at his master’s unshakable composure. "Monsieur," he ventured, "what if the train is delayed?"  

Fogg barely glanced up. "It will not be."  

True to his word, the train stood ready, its engine puffing impatiently. They boarded swiftly, securing their seats in a first-class carriage. Just as the whistle blew, a commotion erupted on the platform. A red-faced man in a policeman’s uniform pushed through the crowd, shouting for the train to halt—but it was too late. The wheels groaned into motion, and London began to slip away.  

Passepartout, peering out the window, frowned. "That inspector seemed quite determined, sir."  

Fogg merely unfolded his newspaper. "Doubtless a matter of no consequence."  

And with that, the adventure truly began.

events.title: The Journey Begins and Passepartout's Costly Oversight
detailed_summary: The train moves through the dark, rainy evening.
Phileas Fogg remains silent and composed in his seat.
Passepartout, still dazed by the sudden turn of events, clutches the carpet-bag containing the fortune.
While passing through Sydenham, Passepartout lets out a cry of distress.
Mr. Fogg calmly asks what is wrong.
Passepartout reveals that, in his rush, he forgot a crucial task: turning off the gas burner in his room.
Fogg responds with characteristic coolness, stating that the gas will simply continue to burn at Passepartout's expense.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The night was dark, and a fine, steady rain was falling.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Very well, young man,” returned Mr. Fogg, coolly; “it will burn—at your expense.”

events.text_segment:
The night was dark, and a fine, steady rain was falling. Phileas Fogg, snugly ensconced in his corner, did not open his lips. Passepartout, not yet recovered from his stupefaction, clung mechanically to the carpet-bag, with its enormous treasure.
Just as the train was whirling through Sydenham, Passepartout suddenly uttered a cry of despair.
“What’s the matter?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“Alas! In my hurry—I—I forgot—”
“What?”
“To turn off the gas in my room!”
“Very well, young man,” returned Mr. Fogg, coolly; “it will burn—at your expense.”

events.title: Public Frenzy and Skepticism Over Fogg's Wager
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg anticipated his departure would cause significant public interest.
News of his ambitious wager quickly spread beyond the Reform Club, igniting widespread conversation.
The proposed 'tour of the world' became a topic of heated debate throughout England, discussed with great passion.
While Fogg garnered some supporters, the vast majority considered his plan utterly impossible given the time constraints and contemporary travel technology.
Prominent newspapers largely dismissed the project as madness, though the Daily Telegraph expressed some hesitant support.
General opinion labeled Fogg a lunatic, and his Reform Club associates were criticized for accepting a bet seen as evidence of his mental imbalance.
Numerous articles, reflecting England's fascination with geography, analyzed the venture with fervor and were widely read.
Fogg initially gained some followers, particularly women, and his popularity increased slightly when his portrait was published.
A minority, influenced by the Daily Telegraph, speculated that perhaps such an extraordinary feat could indeed be accomplished.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg rightly suspected that his departure from London would create a lively sensation at the West End. The news of the bet spread through the Reform Club, and afforded an exciting topic of conversation to its members. From the club it soon got into the papers throughout England. The boasted “tour of the world” was talked about, disputed, argued with as much warmth as if the subject were another Alabama claim. Some took sides with Phileas Fogg, but the large majority shook their heads and declared against him; it was absurd, impossible, they declared, that the tour of the world could be made, except theoretically and on paper, in this minimum of time, and with the existing means of travelling. The Times, Standard, Morning Post, and Daily News, and twenty other highly respectable newspapers scouted Mr. Fogg’s project as madness; the Daily Telegraph alone hesitatingly supported him. People in general thought him a lunatic, and blamed his Reform Club friends for having accepted a wager which betrayed the mental aberration of its proposer.
Articles no less passionate than logical appeared on the question, for geography is one of the pet subjects of the English; and the columns devoted to Phileas Fogg’s venture were eagerly devoured by all classes of readers. At first some rash individuals, principally of the gentler sex, espoused his cause, which became still more popular when the Illustrated London News came out with his portrait, copied from a photograph in the Reform Club. A few readers of the Daily Telegraph even dared to say, “Why not, after all? Stranger things have come to pass.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg rightly suspected that his departure from London would create a lively sensation at the West End. News of his audacious wager—to circumnavigate the globe in a mere eighty days—spread like wildfire through the clubs and drawing rooms of high society. The very idea that a man of such rigid habits and precise temperament would stake his fortune on such a reckless venture was enough to set tongues wagging.  

At the Reform Club, where Fogg was a respected and somewhat enigmatic figure, the members debated the feasibility of his journey with a mixture of admiration and skepticism. Some praised his cool determination, while others dismissed the endeavor as sheer folly. The newspapers, ever eager for sensational stories, seized upon the wager, publishing speculative articles about the obstacles he might face—storms at sea, bandits on land, and the unpredictability of foreign railways.  

Meanwhile, Fogg’s sudden disappearance left his newly hired valet, Passepartout, bewildered but dutifully resolved to follow his master into the unknown. The streets of London buzzed with rumors: Had Fogg gone mad? Was this an elaborate hoax? Or was he, as a few daring optimists suggested, about to make history?  

As the hours passed, the excitement only grew. Bets were placed, maps were consulted, and the entire city seemed to hold its breath, waiting to see whether the unflappable Phileas Fogg would defy the odds—or vanish into obscurity. The West End had not been so thoroughly entertained in years.

events.title: Geographical Society Denounces Fogg's Plan
detailed_summary: A detailed analysis published by the Royal Geographical Society on October 7th thoroughly examined and ultimately condemned Fogg's undertaking.
The Society's bulletin argued forcefully that the enterprise was completely impractical.
The article highlighted numerous obstacles, both natural and man-made, standing in the way of success.
It stressed that achieving the required perfect timing for all departures and arrivals was virtually impossible.
While acknowledging potential reliability of European trains, the article questioned the feasibility of crossing India in three days and the United States in seven.
Potential issues like mechanical failures, train derailments, collisions, adverse weather, and snow blockages were presented as significant threats.
The article also pointed out the dangers of winter sea voyages, including unpredictable winds and fog.
It reminded readers that even the most reliable ocean liners frequently experienced delays.
Crucially, the piece asserted that a single missed connection, even by an hour, would break the chain of travel and doom the entire attempt.
This authoritative article received widespread attention, being reprinted in many newspapers, and significantly discouraged Fogg's supporters.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At last a long article appeared, on the 7th of October, in the bulletin of the Royal Geographical Society, which treated the question from every point of view, and demonstrated the utter folly of the enterprise.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This article made a great deal of noise, and, being copied into all the papers, seriously depressed the advocates of the rash tourist.

events.text_segment:
At last a long article appeared, on the 7th of October, in the bulletin of the Royal Geographical Society, which treated the question from every point of view, and demonstrated the utter folly of the enterprise.
Everything, it said, was against the travellers, every obstacle imposed alike by man and by nature. A miraculous agreement of the times of departure and arrival, which was impossible, was absolutely necessary to his success. He might, perhaps, reckon on the arrival of trains at the designated hours, in Europe, where the distances were relatively moderate; but when he calculated upon crossing India in three days, and the United States in seven, could he rely beyond misgiving upon accomplishing his task? There were accidents to machinery, the liability of trains to run off the line, collisions, bad weather, the blocking up by snow—were not all these against Phileas Fogg? Would he not find himself, when travelling by steamer in winter, at the mercy of the winds and fogs? Is it uncommon for the best ocean steamers to be two or three days behind time? But a single delay would suffice to fatally break the chain of communication; should Phileas Fogg once miss, even by an hour; a steamer, he would have to wait for the next, and that would irrevocably render his attempt vain.
This article made a great deal of noise, and, being copied into all the papers, seriously depressed the advocates of the rash tourist.

```text
"At last a long article appeared, on the 7th of October, in the bulletin of the Royal Geographical Society, which treated the question from every point of view, and demonstrated the utter folly of the enterprise. The learned gentlemen of the Society had spared no pains in their analysis, dissecting with merciless precision each stage of Phileas Fogg's proposed journey. Their verdict was unequivocal: the scheme was madness. 

They painted a grim picture of insurmountable obstacles—trains that might never arrive, ships delayed by capricious winds, snow-choked mountain passes that would mock human schedules. Even the most reliable European railways, they conceded, could not compensate for the impossibility of crossing India in three days or traversing the vast American continent in seven. 

Mechanical failures, collisions, derailments—each was a potential death knell for Fogg's fragile timetable. The article particularly emphasized how a single missed connection, even by an hour, would snap the delicate chain of his itinerary. 

Reprinted in newspapers across London, this damning indictment turned public opinion decisively against the venture. Where once there had been excited speculation, now there remained only pitying shakes of the head at such magnificent folly."
```

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
**Revised Simulated Output (Adhering Closely to Original Structure and Style)**:

```text
"At last a long article appeared, on the 7th of October, in the bulletin of the Royal Geographical Society, which treated the question from every point of view, and demonstrated the utter folly of the enterprise.  

The article established that for success, a miraculous agreement of times of departure and arrival was absolutely necessary—an agreement which did not exist and could not be established. In Europe, where the distances were relatively short, one might count upon the trains' punctuality; but when three days were required to cross India and seven to traverse the United States, could such exactitude be relied upon?  

Accidents to machinery, liability of trains to run off the line, collisions, bad weather, blocking up by snow—were not all these against Phileas Fogg? In winter on the steamboats was he not at the mercy of fogs and contrary winds? And even the best steamships were sometimes two or three days behind time.  

But suppose all these obstacles overcome, one single delay would suffice to break the chain of communication. Had Fogg reflected that a delay of only an hour would compel him to wait for the next steamer, and thus render his whole project abortive?  

This article made a great deal of noise, and being copied into all the papers, considerably depressed the advocates of the rash tourist."
```

events.title: Betting Market Volatility and Fogg's Last Supporter
detailed_summary: The English propensity for betting, extending across social classes, became evident.
Significant wagers were placed for and against Phileas Fogg by both Reform Club members and the broader public.
Fogg was treated like a commodity in the betting markets, akin to a race-horse.
Financial instruments called "Phileas Fogg bonds" were created and actively traded.
Following the publication of the Geographical Society's article, demand for these bonds collapsed, and their value plummeted.
Sellers struggled to find buyers, eventually offering bonds in large, discounted packages.
Lord Albemarle, an elderly, immobilized nobleman, emerged as Fogg's sole remaining prominent advocate.
Motivated by personal ambition and nationalistic pride, Albemarle wagered a substantial sum (£5,000) on Fogg's success.
When challenged about the venture's impracticality, Albemarle insisted that if such a feat were possible, an Englishman should be the one to achieve it.
Support for Fogg continued to decline dramatically, with betting odds heavily favoring failure.
Approximately one week after Fogg's departure, a new development effectively eliminated any remaining support for him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Everybody knows that England is the world of betting men, who are of a higher class than mere gamblers; to bet is in the English temperament.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The Fogg party dwindled more and more, everybody was going against him, and the bets stood a hundred and fifty and two hundred to one; and a week after his departure an incident occurred which deprived him of backers at any price.

events.text_segment:
Everybody knows that England is the world of betting men, who are of a higher class than mere gamblers; to bet is in the English temperament. Not only the members of the Reform, but the general public, made heavy wagers for or against Phileas Fogg, who was set down in the betting books as if he were a race-horse. Bonds were issued, and made their appearance on ’Change; “Phileas Fogg bonds” were offered at par or at a premium, and a great business was done in them. But five days after the article in the bulletin of the Geographical Society appeared, the demand began to subside: “Phileas Fogg” declined. They were offered by packages, at first of five, then of ten, until at last nobody would take less than twenty, fifty, a hundred!
Lord Albemarle, an elderly paralytic gentleman, was now the only advocate of Phileas Fogg left. This noble lord, who was fastened to his chair, would have given his fortune to be able to make the tour of the world, if it took ten years; and he bet five thousand pounds on Phileas Fogg. When the folly as well as the uselessness of the adventure was pointed out to him, he contented himself with replying, “If the thing is feasible, the first to do it ought to be an Englishman.”
The Fogg party dwindled more and more, everybody was going against him, and the bets stood a hundred and fifty and two hundred to one; and a week after his departure an incident occurred which deprived him of backers at any price.

But when the *Proceedings* of the Royal Geographical Society declared the journey impossible, demand withered. Bonds once sold in fives were now hawked in dozens, then in fifties—finally, none could find buyers at any price.*  

*Amid this collapse, only Lord Albemarle, the elderly paralytic confined to his chair, held firm. ‘Five thousand pounds on Fogg!’ he proclaimed. ‘If such a thing is feasible, it must be accomplished by an Englishman!’ His defiance briefly stirred the market, but support dwindled daily. By the week’s end, odds stood at a hundred to one against Fogg—and then, a week after his departure, an unforeseen development stripped him of even this last backer."*  

---

**Key Improvements**:  
1. **Structural Precision**:  
   - Explicitly traces the betting market’s arc: initial frenzy → bond issuance/trading → Geographical Society’s impact → phased collapse (packages of 5 → 50 → unsellable).

   - Lord Albemarle’s physical state (£5,000 wager), patriotic rationale, and isolated advocacy preserved.  
   - Final odds (100:1) and the "unforeseen development" hint at the original’s unresolved tension.  

3. **Tonal/Textual Fidelity**:

   - Matches the original’s detached, reportorial tone (e.g., "roaring business was done in them").  

4. **Logical Flow**:

*"Everybody knows that England is the world of betting men, who are of a higher class than mere gamblers; to bet is in the English temperament. The members of the Reform Club laid heavy sums for and against him, while the general public, equally gripped by the mania, inscribed his name in their betting-books as they would a race-horse’s. Soon, ‘Phileas Fogg bonds’ appeared on ’Change, offered at par or at a premium, and for five days they were actively traded. But after the publication of the article in the Royal Geographical Society’s proceedings, confidence wavered. Bonds that had first been dealt in packages of five were now offered in tens, then twenties, then fifties, and finally in hundreds—yet still found no takers.*  

*Amid this ruinous decline, only Lord Albemarle, the elderly paralytic gentleman fastened to his chair, remained steadfast. ‘Five thousand pounds on Phileas Fogg!’ he declared. ‘Since the thing is possible, it is right that an Englishman should be the first to do it!’ His solitary support briefly checked the despair, but the tide was inexorable. Within a week of Fogg’s departure, the odds had sunk to a hundred and fifty, then two hundred to one—and soon, no backer could be found at any price."*

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Everybody knows that England is the world of betting men, who are of a higher class than mere gamblers; to bet is in the English temperament. From the gentlemen of St. James's to the laborers in the docks, the spirit of wagering runs deep in the blood of the British. It is not merely about money—though that certainly plays its part—but rather the thrill of speculation, the joy of a well-placed risk, and the pride in one's judgment.  

In the clubs of London, fortunes are staked on the turn of a card, the speed of a racehorse, or even the outcome of a parliamentary debate. The Englishman bets with the same cool composure with which he sips his tea, treating it as a refined pastime rather than a reckless vice. It is a matter of honor as much as chance, for a true betting man prides himself on fairness and accepts loss with the same grace as victory.  

Phileas Fogg himself, that most precise and unflappable of Englishmen, embodied this national trait when he wagered his entire fortune on circumnavigating the globe in eighty days. To him, it was not mere recklessness but a challenge to fate, a test of his own calculations and resolve. And so, in England, betting is not just a habit—it is a philosophy.

events.title: Fogg Accused: Telegram Identifies Him as Bank Robber
detailed_summary: The London police commissioner received an important telegraphic message one evening.
The telegram originated from Detective Fix in Suez.
Fix reported identifying Phileas Fogg as the man responsible for the recent major bank robbery.
The detective urgently requested an arrest warrant be dispatched to Bombay.
The news had an immediate and profound impact.
Public perception shifted instantly; Fogg was no longer seen as an eccentric gentleman but as a fugitive criminal.
His photograph at the Reform Club was re-examined and found to align perfectly with the description of the bank robber circulated by the police.
Fogg's known eccentricities—his solitary nature and abrupt departure—were reinterpreted in a sinister light.
The prevailing theory became that the round-the-world journey was merely a cunning ploy devised to mislead law enforcement and escape justice.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The commissioner of police was sitting in his office at nine o’clock one evening, when the following telegraphic dispatch was put into his hands:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The mysterious habits of Phileas Fogg were recalled; his solitary ways, his sudden departure; and it seemed clear that, in undertaking a tour round the world on the pretext of a wager, he had had no other end in view than to elude the detectives, and throw them off his track.

events.text_segment:
The commissioner of police was sitting in his office at nine o’clock one evening, when the following telegraphic dispatch was put into his hands:
Suez to London.
ROWAN, COMMISSIONER OF POLICE, SCOTLAND YARD:
    I’ve found the bank robber, Phileas Fogg. Send without delay warrant of arrest to Bombay.
FIX, Detective.
The effect of this dispatch was instantaneous. The polished gentleman disappeared to give place to the bank robber. His photograph, which was hung with those of the rest of the members at the Reform Club, was minutely examined, and it betrayed, feature by feature, the description of the robber which had been provided to the police. The mysterious habits of Phileas Fogg were recalled; his solitary ways, his sudden departure; and it seemed clear that, in undertaking a tour round the world on the pretext of a wager, he had had no other end in view than to elude the detectives, and throw them off his track.

**Simulated Output**:

```text
"The commissioner of police was sitting in his office at nine o’clock one evening, when the following telegraphic dispatch was put into his hands:  

*‘Suez, to Commissioner Rowan, London.  
Have identified bank robber as Phileas Fogg. Description matches perfectly. Request immediate arrest warrant for Bombay. Urgent. —Fix.’*  

The effect of this message was electric. No longer was Phileas Fogg regarded as merely an eccentric Englishman indulging in a whimsical wager—now he stood exposed as a daring criminal fleeing justice. His portrait at the Reform Club was scrutinized anew, and every feature tallied with the police description. His solitary habits, his sudden departure, all took on a darker significance. The world tour, it was now whispered, had been nothing but a ruse to throw the authorities off his trail.  

Rowan wasted no time. The machinery of the law was set in motion, and the warrant was dispatched with all haste to Bombay, where Fix would be waiting."
```

events.title: Detective Fix Awaits the 'Mongolia' at Suez
detailed_summary: The context for a telegraphic dispatch concerning Phileas Fogg is established.
The steamer 'Mongolia', a fast P&O vessel operating between Brindisi and Bombay via Suez, is described along with its specifications and schedule, being due in Suez on October 9th.
Two men are observed walking on the Suez wharves amidst a diverse crowd.
One man is identified as the British consul, who regularly witnesses the success of the Suez Canal despite initial British skepticism.
The other man is introduced as Fix, a detective from England, characterized by his slight build, nervous energy, and twitching eyebrows.
Fix is revealed to be searching for a bank robber, tasked with scrutinizing passengers arriving in Suez based on a description received from London police.
The detective is motivated by the large reward offered and eagerly awaits the 'Mongolia'.
Fix repeatedly asks the consul about the steamer's punctuality.
The consul confirms the 'Mongolia' is known for its speed and adherence to schedule, having already been reported at Port Said.
They confirm the ship's origin is Brindisi, where it collected Indian mail.
The consul expresses doubt about Fix's ability to identify the robber solely based on the provided description.
Fix asserts his confidence, explaining that identifying criminals is more about intuition or a 'scent' than visual recognition, boasting about his past successes.
The consul acknowledges the severity of the £55,000 robbery.
Fix laments the perceived decline in the caliber of burglars.
The consul wishes Fix success but notes the difficulty, pointing out the robber's description resembles that of an honest man.
Fix dogmatically states that great robbers often look honest, considering it an art to unmask them.
The narrative notes Fix's evident self-conceit.

events.text_segment:
The circumstances under which this telegraphic dispatch about Phileas Fogg was sent were as follows:
The steamer “Mongolia,” belonging to the Peninsular and Oriental Company, built of iron, of two thousand eight hundred tons burden, and five hundred horse-power, was due at eleven o’clock a.m. on Wednesday, the 9th of October, at Suez. The “Mongolia” plied regularly between Brindisi and Bombay viâ the Suez Canal, and was one of the fastest steamers belonging to the company, always making more than ten knots an hour between Brindisi and Suez, and nine and a half between Suez and Bombay.
Two men were promenading up and down the wharves, among the crowd of natives and strangers who were sojourning at this once straggling village—now, thanks to the enterprise of M. Lesseps, a fast-growing town. One was the British consul at Suez, who, despite the prophecies of the English Government, and the unfavourable predictions of Stephenson, was in the habit of seeing, from his office window, English ships daily passing to and fro on the great canal, by which the old roundabout route from England to India by the Cape of Good Hope was abridged by at least a half. The other was a small, slight-built personage, with a nervous, intelligent face, and bright eyes peering out from under eyebrows which he was incessantly twitching. He was just now manifesting unmistakable signs of impatience, nervously pacing up and down, and unable to stand still for a moment. This was Fix, one of the detectives who had been dispatched from England in search of the bank robber; it was his task to narrowly watch every passenger who arrived at Suez, and to follow up all who seemed to be suspicious characters, or bore a resemblance to the description of the criminal, which he had received two days before from the police headquarters at London. The detective was evidently inspired by the hope of obtaining the splendid reward which would be the prize of success, and awaited with a feverish impatience, easy to understand, the arrival of the steamer “Mongolia.”
“So you say, consul,” asked he for the twentieth time, “that this steamer is never behind time?”
“No, Mr. Fix,” replied the consul. “She was bespoken yesterday at Port Said, and the rest of the way is of no account to such a craft. I repeat that the ‘Mongolia’ has been in advance of the time required by the company’s regulations, and gained the prize awarded for excess of speed.”
“Does she come directly from Brindisi?”
“Directly from Brindisi; she takes on the Indian mails there, and she left there Saturday at five p.m. Have patience, Mr. Fix; she will not be late. But really, I don’t see how, from the description you have, you will be able to recognise your man, even if he is on board the ‘Mongolia.’”
“A man rather feels the presence of these fellows, consul, than recognises them. You must have a scent for them, and a scent is like a sixth sense which combines hearing, seeing, and smelling. I’ve arrested more than one of these gentlemen in my time, and, if my thief is on board, I’ll answer for it; he’ll not slip through my fingers.”
“I hope so, Mr. Fix, for it was a heavy robbery.”
“A magnificent robbery, consul; fifty-five thousand pounds! We don’t often have such windfalls. Burglars are getting to be so contemptible nowadays! A fellow gets hung for a handful of shillings!”
“Mr. Fix,” said the consul, “I like your way of talking, and hope you’ll succeed; but I fear you will find it far from easy. Don’t you see, the description which you have there has a singular resemblance to an honest man?”
“Consul,” remarked the detective, dogmatically, “great robbers always resemble honest folks. Fellows who have rascally faces have only one course to take, and that is to remain honest; otherwise they would be arrested off-hand. The artistic thing is, to unmask honest countenances; it’s no light task, I admit, but a real art.”
Mr. Fix evidently was not wanting in a tinge of self-conceit.

The steamer *Mongolia*, one of the fastest vessels belonging to the Peninsular and Oriental Company, was due at Suez on the 9th of October. She was a screw steamer, of two thousand eight hundred tons burden, and five hundred horse-power, and was one of the regular line plying between Brindisi and Bombay via the Suez Canal.  

On this day, two men were walking up and down the wharves, amidst the crowd of natives and strangers who were flocking to Suez. One was the British consul at this port, who, despite the prophecies of the English Government, and the unfavourable predictions of Stephenson, beheld, every day, English ships passing to and fro through the great canal, which has so shortened the route between England and her Eastern possessions.  

The other was a small, slight-built personage, with a nervous, intelligent face, and bright eyes peering out from under eyebrows which he was incessantly twitching. He was just now manifesting unmistakable signs of impatience, nervously pacing up and down, and unable to stand still for a moment. This was Fix, one of the detectives who had been dispatched from England in search of the bank robber; it was his task to narrowly watch every passenger who arrived at Suez, and to follow up all who seemed to be suspicious characters, or bore a resemblance to the description of the criminal, which he had received two days before from the police headquarters at London.  

The detective was evidently inspired by the hope of obtaining the splendid reward which would be the prize of success, and awaited with a feverish impatience, easy to understand, the arrival of the steamer *Mongolia*.  

"So you say, consul," he asked for the twentieth time, "that this steamer is never behind time?"  

"No, Mr. Fix," replied the consul. "She was signaled yesterday at Port Said, and the rest of the way is of no account to such a craft. I repeat that the *Mongolia* has always gained the reward given by the government for speed."  

"Does she come directly from Brindisi?"  

"Directly from Brindisi, where she took on the India mail, and she left there Saturday at five p.m. Have patience, Mr. Fix; she will not be late in arriving. But really, I don’t see how, from the description you have, you will be able to recognize your man, even if he is on board the *Mongolia*."  

"A man rather feels these people, consul, than recognizes them. You must have a scent for them, and a scent is like a sixth sense which combines hearing, seeing, and smelling. I’ve arrested more than one of these gentlemen in my time, and, if my thief is on board, I’ll answer for it; he’ll not slip through my fingers."  

"I hope so, Mr. Fix, for it was a heavy robbery."  

"A magnificent robbery, consul; fifty-five thousand pounds! We don’t often have such windfalls. Burglars are getting to be so contemptible nowadays! A fellow gets hung for a handful of shillings!"  

"Mr. Fix," said the consul, "I like your way of talking, and hope you’ll succeed; but I fear you will find it far from easy. Don’t you see, the description which you have there resembles a honest man?"  

"Consul," remarked the detective, dogmatically, "great robbers always resemble honest folks. Fellows who have rascally faces have only one course to take, and that is to remain honest; otherwise they would be arrested off-hand. The artistic thing is, to unmask honest countenances; it’s no light task, I admit, but a real art."  

Mr. Fix evidently was not wanting in a tinge of self-conceit.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The circumstances under which this telegraphic dispatch about Phileas Fogg was sent were as follows:  

It was a crisp autumn evening in London when Inspector Fix of Scotland Yard, a man of singular determination and sharp instincts, found himself pacing the dimly lit corridors of the General Post Office. His brow was furrowed, his hands clenched behind his back, as he muttered to himself in frustration. For weeks, he had been pursuing the elusive gentleman, Phileas Fogg, convinced that the man was none other than the notorious bank robber who had absconded with a fortune from the Bank of England.  

Fix had followed Fogg’s trail across continents, from the bustling streets of Suez to the crowded bazaars of Bombay, yet each time he thought he had his quarry cornered, fate intervened. Now, as he stood in the telegraph office, he was determined to send a message that would finally bring Fogg to justice. The inspector had learned from a reliable source—a disgruntled railway clerk in Calcutta—that Fogg and his companions had boarded a steamer bound for Hong Kong. Time was of the essence.  

With a decisive motion, Fix seized a telegraph form and hastily scribbled his message. It was addressed to the Hong Kong police, urging them to detain Fogg upon his arrival on charges of grand larceny. Fix’s hand trembled slightly as he wrote, for he knew that if this gambit failed, Fogg might slip through his fingers forever. The stakes were high—not only for Fix’s professional reputation but for the entire British banking system, which had been shaken by the audacious theft.  

As he handed the dispatch to the telegraph operator, Fix hesitated for a brief moment. A nagging doubt crept into his mind. What if he was wrong? What if Phileas Fogg was indeed the eccentric but innocent gentleman he claimed to be? The inspector shook his head, dismissing the thought. The evidence, though circumstantial, was too compelling to ignore.  

The telegraph operator, a bespectacled man with ink-stained fingers, took the message and began tapping out the coded signals. The rhythmic clicking of the machine filled the small office, each pulse carrying Fix’s desperate plea across thousands of miles of undersea cable. The message would reach Hong Kong in a matter of hours, long before Fogg’s ship could dock.  

Unbeknownst to Fix, however, fate had one more twist in store. The telegraph lines to Hong Kong had recently been damaged in a storm, causing delays in transmission. By the time the message arrived, Fogg’s ship had already departed for Yokohama, leaving the Hong Kong authorities baffled and empty-handed.  

Meanwhile, aboard the steamer *Rangoon*, Phileas Fogg stood calmly on the deck, gazing at the horizon with his usual imperturbable expression. Beside him, Passepartout chattered excitedly about their next destination, utterly unaware of the storm of suspicion brewing behind them. Fogg, ever the man of precision, checked his pocket watch and remarked, “If all goes according to schedule, we shall reach Hong Kong in precisely three days and fourteen hours.”  

Little did he know that Inspector Fix’s telegraphic dispatch—though delayed—would soon set in motion a chain of events that would test his resolve, his fortune, and his very freedom. The race against time was far from over, and the stakes had never been higher.  

Thus, the dispatch that was meant to halt Fogg’s journey instead became another obstacle in his path, another challenge to be overcome in his audacious wager to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days. And as the telegraph wires hummed with unanswered messages, the world held its breath, waiting to see whether Phileas Fogg would triumph—or fall at last.

events.title: Growing Anticipation and Strategic Speculation
detailed_summary: The activity on the quay intensifies with sailors, merchants, porters, and others bustling about in anticipation of the steamer.
The weather is noted as clear and cool, with the town's minarets visible under the sun.
The long jetty extending into the sea and various boats on the Red Sea are described.
Fix, moving through the crowd, habitually scans faces with sharp glances.
The time reaches half-past ten.
Fix voices his impatience about the steamer's delay as the port clock strikes.
The consul reassures him, suggesting the ship must be close.
Fix inquires about the duration of the stop at Suez.
The consul informs him it will be four hours, necessary for refueling coal for the journey to Aden.
Fix confirms the ship travels directly from Suez to Bombay.
Fix speculates that the robber, if aboard, would likely disembark at Suez to seek refuge in non-British territories in Asia, believing India unsafe.
The consul counters that a truly cunning English criminal might find London itself the safest hiding place.
This remark gives Fix something to contemplate as the consul departs for his office.

events.text_segment:
Little by little the scene on the quay became more animated; sailors of various nations, merchants, ship-brokers, porters, fellahs, bustled to and fro as if the steamer were immediately expected. The weather was clear, and slightly chilly. The minarets of the town loomed above the houses in the pale rays of the sun. A jetty pier, some two thousand yards along, extended into the roadstead. A number of fishing-smacks and coasting boats, some retaining the fantastic fashion of ancient galleys, were discernible on the Red Sea.
As he passed among the busy crowd, Fix, according to habit, scrutinised the passers-by with a keen, rapid glance.
It was now half-past ten.
“The steamer doesn’t come!” he exclaimed, as the port clock struck.
“She can’t be far off now,” returned his companion.
“How long will she stop at Suez?”
“Four hours; long enough to get in her coal. It is thirteen hundred and ten miles from Suez to Aden, at the other end of the Red Sea, and she has to take in a fresh coal supply.”
“And does she go from Suez directly to Bombay?”
“Without putting in anywhere.”
“Good!” said Fix. “If the robber is on board he will no doubt get off at Suez, so as to reach the Dutch or French colonies in Asia by some other route. He ought to know that he would not be safe an hour in India, which is English soil.”
“Unless,” objected the consul, “he is exceptionally shrewd. An English criminal, you know, is always better concealed in London than anywhere else.”
This observation furnished the detective food for thought, and meanwhile the consul went away to his office.

The air was thick with the mingled scents of saltwater, spices, and sweat as the crowd swelled along the bustling quay. Sailors in striped jerseys and wide-brimmed hats shouted orders in half a dozen languages, their voices rising above the clamor of creaking ropes and clattering cargo. Children darted between legs, their laughter ringing bright against the deeper tones of commerce and labor. A stray dog nosed at a discarded fish head, while overhead, seagulls wheeled and cried, their sharp eyes fixed on any scrap that might fall from a careless hand.  

The excitement was palpable—everyone knew the steamer was due, and with it, the promise of news, goods, and perhaps even fortune. The quay was alive, a microcosm of the world itself, where East met West in a symphony of movement and sound, all waiting for the distant plume of smoke that would herald the ship’s arrival.

events.title: The 'Mongolia' Arrives and Passengers Disembark
detailed_summary: Alone now, Fix feels increasingly restless, strongly suspecting the robber is on the approaching steamer.
He reasons the robber likely chose the less-monitored Indian route over the Atlantic to reach the New World.
His thoughts are cut short by sharp whistles announcing the 'Mongolia's' arrival.
A rush of porters and boats ensues towards the incoming vessel.
The large hull of the steamer soon appears, and it anchors precisely at eleven o'clock.
A significant number of passengers are aboard; some admire the view from the deck, while most proceed to disembark via smaller boats onto the quay.
Fix positions himself strategically to carefully observe every person coming ashore.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Fix, left alone, was more impatient than ever, having a presentiment that the robber was on board the “Mongolia.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Fix took up a position, and carefully examined each face and figure which made its appearance.

events.text_segment:
Fix, left alone, was more impatient than ever, having a presentiment that the robber was on board the “Mongolia.” If he had indeed left London intending to reach the New World, he would naturally take the route viâ India, which was less watched and more difficult to watch than that of the Atlantic. But Fix’s reflections were soon interrupted by a succession of sharp whistles, which announced the arrival of the “Mongolia.” The porters and fellahs rushed down the quay, and a dozen boats pushed off from the shore to go and meet the steamer. Soon her gigantic hull appeared passing along between the banks, and eleven o’clock struck as she anchored in the road. She brought an unusual number of passengers, some of whom remained on deck to scan the picturesque panorama of the town, while the greater part disembarked in the boats, and landed on the quay.
Fix took up a position, and carefully examined each face and figure which made its appearance.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Fix, left alone, was more impatient than ever, having a presentiment that the robber was on board the *Mongolia*. His instincts as a detective told him that Fogg was the man he sought, yet he lacked proof. The steamer raced toward Suez, and with each passing hour, Fix grew more restless. He paced the deck, watching Fogg’s every move, searching for any clue that might confirm his suspicions.  

The calm demeanor of the English gentleman only deepened Fix’s frustration. Fogg showed no sign of guilt, no nervousness—just the same unshakable composure. Fix wondered if he had made a mistake, but the description in the warrant matched too closely to ignore.  

As the *Mongolia* neared its destination, Fix resolved to act. If Fogg disembarked at Suez, he would request an arrest warrant from the British consul. The chase was far from over, and Fix was determined not to let his quarry escape.

events.title: Fix Encounters Passepartout and Inspects the Passport
detailed_summary: A passenger emerges from the crowd, politely approaches Fix, and asks for directions to the English consulate.
The passenger explains he needs to have a passport visaed and shows it to Fix.
Fix instinctively takes the passport and quickly reads the bearer's description.
He is visibly surprised as the description perfectly matches the one he received for the bank robber.
Fix inquires if the passport belongs to the passenger.
The passenger clarifies it belongs to his master, who has remained on the ship.
Fix insists that the master must personally visit the consulate to establish his identity.
The passenger asks if this is truly necessary.
Fix confirms it is indispensable.
When asked for the consulate's location, Fix points to a nearby building.
The passenger accepts the instruction, mentions his master might be displeased by the disturbance, bows politely, and returns to the steamer to fetch him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Presently one of the passengers, after vigorously pushing his way through the importunate crowd of porters, came up to him and politely asked if he could point out the English consulate, at the same time showing a passport which he wished to have visaed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The passenger bowed to Fix, and returned to the steamer.

events.text_segment:
Presently one of the passengers, after vigorously pushing his way through the importunate crowd of porters, came up to him and politely asked if he could point out the English consulate, at the same time showing a passport which he wished to have visaed. Fix instinctively took the passport, and with a rapid glance read the description of its bearer. An involuntary motion of surprise nearly escaped him, for the description in the passport was identical with that of the bank robber which he had received from Scotland Yard.
“Is this your passport?” asked he.
“No, it’s my master’s.”
“And your master is—”
“He stayed on board.”
“But he must go to the consul’s in person, so as to establish his identity.”
“Oh, is that necessary?”
“Quite indispensable.”
“And where is the consulate?”
“There, on the corner of the square,” said Fix, pointing to a house two hundred steps off.
“I’ll go and fetch my master, who won’t be much pleased, however, to be disturbed.”
The passenger bowed to Fix, and returned to the steamer.

The traveler, a stout gentleman with a perspiring brow, nodded gratefully and tipped his hat. As he hurried off, Passepartout, who had been observing the exchange, remarked, "Another soul in a hurry, eh, Monsieur?" Fogg adjusted his cufflinks impassively. "Time spares no one, Passepartout," he replied, his eyes already scanning the horizon for the next step in their journey. The bustling port of Suez faded into the background as the pair turned their attention to securing passage onward—every second counted in their race against the clock.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER VII. WHICH ONCE MORE DEMONSTRATES THE USELESSNESS OF PASSPORTS AS AIDS TO DETECTIVES

events.title: Fix Expresses Suspicions to the Consul
detailed_summary: Detective Fix promptly went to the British consul's office.
He immediately stated his strong belief that the man he sought, the bank robber, was aboard the 'Mongolia', recounting the earlier encounter with the servant regarding the passport.
The consul expressed skepticism, noting that a clever robber might avoid official channels like getting a passport visaed to avoid leaving a trail.
Fix countered that a shrewd individual, like he believed his quarry to be, would indeed come to get the visa, precisely because it seems counterintuitive.
He argued that passports primarily inconvenience honest people while inadvertently aiding criminals.
Fix urged the consul not to provide the visa, needing to detain the suspect until a warrant arrived from London.
The consul began to state his inability to refuse a legitimate passport if presented.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The detective passed down the quay, and rapidly made his way to the consul’s office, where he was at once admitted to the presence of that official.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah, that’s your look-out. But I cannot—”

events.text_segment:
The detective passed down the quay, and rapidly made his way to the consul’s office, where he was at once admitted to the presence of that official.
“Consul,” said he, without preamble, “I have strong reasons for believing that my man is a passenger on the ‘Mongolia.’” And he narrated what had just passed concerning the passport.
“Well, Mr. Fix,” replied the consul, “I shall not be sorry to see the rascal’s face; but perhaps he won’t come here—that is, if he is the person you suppose him to be. A robber doesn’t quite like to leave traces of his flight behind him; and, besides, he is not obliged to have his passport countersigned.”
“If he is as shrewd as I think he is, consul, he will come.”
“To have his passport visaed?”
“Yes. Passports are only good for annoying honest folks, and aiding in the flight of rogues. I assure you it will be quite the thing for him to do; but I hope you will not visa the passport.”
“Why not? If the passport is genuine I have no right to refuse.”
“Still, I must keep this man here until I can get a warrant to arrest him from London.”
“Ah, that’s your look-out. But I cannot—”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The detective entered the consul’s office with a sense of urgency, his sharp eyes scanning the room as he approached the official. Without wasting a moment, he presented his credentials and stated his purpose.  

“I am in pursuit of a man named Phileas Fogg,” he declared, his voice firm. “He is suspected of robbing the Bank of England and may attempt to leave Hong Kong aboard the next steamer.”  

The consul, a composed man with an air of authority, leaned forward with interest. “Phileas Fogg? The name is unfamiliar, but I shall assist you in any way possible. What do you require?”  

“I need confirmation of his presence in Hong Kong and authority to detain him if he attempts to depart,” the detective replied.  

The consul nodded thoughtfully. “Very well. I will issue the necessary orders. However, without concrete evidence, we must proceed carefully.”  

Satisfied, the detective tipped his hat. “Time is of the essence. I must return to the docks at once.” With that, he turned on his heel and strode out, determined not to let Fogg slip through his grasp.

events.title: Fogg Obtains a Visa at the Consulate
detailed_summary: The consul's sentence was cut short by a knock; Passepartout entered, accompanied by his master.
The master, Phileas Fogg, presented his passport, requesting the consul's visa.
While the consul examined the passport, Fix intently watched Fogg from a corner.
The consul confirmed Fogg's identity, his servant's name (Passepartout), their origin (London), and their destination (Bombay).
The consul pointed out that the visa was unnecessary for Suez.
Fogg acknowledged this but stated he wanted the visa specifically to prove his passage through Suez.
The consul complied, signing, dating, and sealing the passport.
Fogg paid the required fee, gave a reserved bow, and departed with Passepartout.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The consul did not finish his sentence, for as he spoke a knock was heard at the door, and two strangers entered, one of whom was the servant whom Fix had met on the quay.

events.text_segment:
The consul did not finish his sentence, for as he spoke a knock was heard at the door, and two strangers entered, one of whom was the servant whom Fix had met on the quay. The other, who was his master, held out his passport with the request that the consul would do him the favour to visa it. The consul took the document and carefully read it, whilst Fix observed, or rather devoured, the stranger with his eyes from a corner of the room.
“You are Mr. Phileas Fogg?” said the consul, after reading the passport.
“I am.”
“And this man is your servant?”
“He is: a Frenchman, named Passepartout.”
“You are from London?”
“Yes.”
“And you are going—”
“To Bombay.”
“Very good, sir. You know that a visa is useless, and that no passport is required?”
“I know it, sir,” replied Phileas Fogg; “but I wish to prove, by your visa, that I came by Suez.”
“Very well, sir.”
The consul proceeded to sign and date the passport, after which he added his official seal. Mr. Fogg paid the customary fee, coldly bowed, and went out, followed by his servant.

The consul looked up in surprise as the two strangers stepped into the room. The first was a tall, well-dressed man with an air of quiet confidence, while the other was clearly his servant—the same man Fix had encountered earlier on the quay.

events.title: Fix Plans to Interrogate Passepartout
detailed_summary: Fix immediately asked the consul for his assessment.
The consul remarked that Fogg appeared completely honest.
Fix conceded Fogg's appearance but stressed the resemblance to the robber's description.
He dismissed the consul's caveat about the unreliability of descriptions, stating he would confirm his suspicions.
Fix judged the servant, Passepartout, to be less enigmatic than Fogg.
He noted Passepartout's French nationality, predicting he would be talkative.
Fix excused himself to locate and likely question Passepartout.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well?” queried the detective.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Fix started off in search of Passepartout.

events.text_segment:
“Well?” queried the detective.
“Well, he looks and acts like a perfectly honest man,” replied the consul.
“Possibly; but that is not the question. Do you think, consul, that this phlegmatic gentleman resembles, feature by feature, the robber whose description I have received?”
“I concede that; but then, you know, all descriptions—”
“I’ll make certain of it,” interrupted Fix. “The servant seems to me less mysterious than the master; besides, he’s a Frenchman, and can’t help talking. Excuse me for a little while, consul.”
Fix started off in search of Passepartout.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Well?” queried the detective, his sharp eyes fixed on Phileas Fogg.  

“I have nothing to say,” replied Fogg calmly, adjusting his cuffs.  

“You are accused of robbing the Bank of England,” insisted Fix.  

“Absurd,” Fogg said, unruffled. “I am a gentleman traveling the world in eighty days—nothing more.”  

Passepartout, fuming, stepped forward. “Monsieur Fogg is innocent! This is a mistake!”  

Fix smirked. “Then why the haste? Why the secrecy?”  

Fogg merely checked his watch. “Time, sir, waits for no man—not even detectives.”

events.title: Fogg Updates His Itinerary and Remains On Schedule
detailed_summary: After departing the consulate, Fogg went to the quay.
He issued instructions to Passepartout.
Fogg then took a boat back to the 'Mongolia' and went directly to his cabin.
He consulted his notebook, which contained detailed memoranda of his journey.
The notes tracked his departures and arrivals: London, Paris, Turin, Brindisi, and Suez, noting the exact times and dates.
He calculated the total time spent so far as 158.5 hours, or six and a half days.
His itinerary was structured in columns, showing scheduled vs. actual arrival times for key points across the globe, with space to note time gained or lost.
This methodical record allowed Fogg to constantly monitor his progress.
On reaching Suez on October 9th, he recorded his arrival and noted he was precisely on schedule, having neither gained nor lost time.
Fogg then settled down for breakfast in his cabin, displaying no intention of exploring Suez, illustrating his tendency to experience foreign locations vicariously through his servant.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meanwhile Mr. Fogg, after leaving the consulate, repaired to the quay, gave some orders to Passepartout, went off to the “Mongolia” in a boat, and descended to his cabin.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He sat down quietly to breakfast in his cabin, never once thinking of inspecting the town, being one of those Englishmen who are wont to see foreign countries through the eyes of their domestics.

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile Mr. Fogg, after leaving the consulate, repaired to the quay, gave some orders to Passepartout, went off to the “Mongolia” in a boat, and descended to his cabin. He took up his note-book, which contained the following memoranda:
“Left London, Wednesday, October 2nd, at 8.45 p.m.
“Reached Paris, Thursday, October 3rd, at 7.20 a.m.
“Left Paris, Thursday, at 8.40 a.m.
“Reached Turin by Mont Cenis, Friday, October 4th, at 6.35 a.m.
“Left Turin, Friday, at 7.20 a.m.
“Arrived at Brindisi, Saturday, October 5th, at 4 p.m.
“Sailed on the ‘Mongolia,’ Saturday, at 5 p.m.
“Reached Suez, Wednesday, October 9th, at 11 a.m.
“Total of hours spent, 158½; or, in days, six days and a half.”
These dates were inscribed in an itinerary divided into columns, indicating the month, the day of the month, and the day for the stipulated and actual arrivals at each principal point Paris, Brindisi, Suez, Bombay, Calcutta, Singapore, Hong Kong, Yokohama, San Francisco, New York, and London—from the 2nd of October to the 21st of December; and giving a space for setting down the gain made or the loss suffered on arrival at each locality. This methodical record thus contained an account of everything needed, and Mr. Fogg always knew whether he was behind-hand or in advance of his time. On this Friday, October 9th, he noted his arrival at Suez, and observed that he had as yet neither gained nor lost. He sat down quietly to breakfast in his cabin, never once thinking of inspecting the town, being one of those Englishmen who are wont to see foreign countries through the eyes of their domestics.

> Arrived at Brindisi, Saturday, October 5th, at 4 p.m.  
> Sailed on the *Mongolia*, Saturday, at 5 p.m.  
> Reached Suez, Wednesday, October 9th, at 11 a.m.  
> Total of hours spent, 158½, or six days and a half."  

These dates were recorded in an itinerary divided into columns, indicating the month, the day of the month, and the day for the stipulated and actual arrival at each principal point—Paris, Brindisi, Suez, Bombay, Calcutta, Singapore, Hong Kong, Yokohama, San Francisco, New York, and London—from the 2nd of October to the 21st of December; and giving a space to set down the gain made or the loss suffered on arrival at each locality. This methodical record thus contained an account of everything needed, and Mr. Fogg always knew whether he was behindhand or in advance of his time. On this day, October 9th, he noted his arrival at Suez, and observed that he had as yet neither gained nor lost. He sat down quietly to breakfast in his cabin, never once thinking of inspecting the town, being one of those Englishmen who are wont to see foreign countries through the eyes of their domestics.  

---

Meanwhile Mr. Fogg, after leaving the consulate, repaired to the quay, gave some orders to Passepartout, went off to the “Mongolia” in a boat, and descended to his cabin.  

There, with his usual composure, he reviewed the details of his journey thus far. The steamer was due to depart shortly, and he had no intention of allowing even the slightest delay to disrupt his meticulously planned schedule. Passepartout, ever the dutiful valet, bustled about the deck, ensuring their luggage was properly stowed and that all necessary arrangements had been made for the voyage ahead.  

As the ship’s whistle sounded, signaling the imminent departure, Mr. Fogg remained undisturbed, absorbed in his newspaper. The bustle of the port, the shouts of sailors, and the creaking of ropes were mere background noise to him. His mind was fixed solely on the next leg of his journey—the passage across the Red Sea to Suez.  

Passepartout, meanwhile, marveled at the sights and sounds of Bombay, though he dared not linger too long, knowing his master’s strict adherence to punctuality. With a final glance at the receding shoreline, he hurried below deck to attend to his duties, wondering what further adventures lay ahead in their race against time.  

The “Mongolia” steamed steadily onward, cutting through the waves as Phileas Fogg, unshaken as ever, continued his quest to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER VIII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT TALKS RATHER MORE, PERHAPS, THAN IS PRUDENT

events.title: Fix and Passepartout Converse in Suez
detailed_summary: Detective Fix approaches Phileas Fogg's servant, Passepartout, who is observing the surroundings on the quay at Suez.
Fix confirms that Passepartout's passport has received the necessary visa.
Passepartout expresses astonishment at the speed of their journey and their current location in Suez, Egypt, which is part of Africa.
He reflects on his limited view of Paris during their brief passage and regrets not seeing famous landmarks.
Passepartout clarifies that while he is not personally in a hurry, his master, Mr. Fogg, certainly is.
He mentions needing to purchase essential clothing items like shoes and shirts, as they started their journey with only a carpet-bag.
Fix kindly offers to guide Passepartout to a suitable shop.
The two men set off walking together, with Passepartout talking animatedly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Fix soon rejoined Passepartout, who was lounging and looking about on the quay, as if he did not feel that he, at least, was obliged not to see anything.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And they walked off together, Passepartout chatting volubly as they went along.

events.text_segment:
Fix soon rejoined Passepartout, who was lounging and looking about on the quay, as if he did not feel that he, at least, was obliged not to see anything.
“Well, my friend,” said the detective, coming up with him, “is your passport visaed?”
“Ah, it’s you, is it, monsieur?” responded Passepartout. “Thanks, yes, the passport is all right.”
“And you are looking about you?”
“Yes; but we travel so fast that I seem to be journeying in a dream. So this is Suez?”
“Yes.”
“In Egypt?”
“Certainly, in Egypt.”
“And in Africa?”
“In Africa.”
“In Africa!” repeated Passepartout. “Just think, monsieur, I had no idea that we should go farther than Paris; and all that I saw of Paris was between twenty minutes past seven and twenty minutes before nine in the morning, between the Northern and the Lyons stations, through the windows of a car, and in a driving rain! How I regret not having seen once more Père la Chaise and the circus in the Champs Elysées!”
“You are in a great hurry, then?”
“I am not, but my master is. By the way, I must buy some shoes and shirts. We came away without trunks, only with a carpet-bag.”
“I will show you an excellent shop for getting what you want.”
“Really, monsieur, you are very kind.”
And they walked off together, Passepartout chatting volubly as they went along.
