LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
All the detective’s hopes and wishes were now centred on Hong Kong; for the steamer’s stay at Singapore would be too brief to enable him to take any steps there. Fix paced the deck restlessly, his mind racing with plans. If he could not arrest Phileas Fogg in Hong Kong, the elusive gentleman might slip away forever into the vastness of the British Empire—or worse, beyond its reach entirely.  

The *Rangoon* steamed steadily northward, and Fix watched the horizon with growing impatience. Hong Kong was his last chance. Once there, he would either secure the warrant for Fogg’s arrest or lose him for good. The thought gnawed at him. What if the warrant had not arrived? What if Fogg boarded another ship before the paperwork was complete?  

Meanwhile, Fogg remained as calm as ever, seemingly indifferent to the detective’s presence. He took his meals, played whist, and strolled the deck with his usual precision. Passepartout, though still wary of Fix, had begun to relax, unaware of the storm brewing in the detective’s mind.  

As the ship neared Hong Kong, Fix clenched his fists. This was his moment. Failure was not an option. The game of cat and mouse was about to reach its climax.

events.title: Fix Considers Involving Passepartout and Exploiting Aouda's Presence
detailed_summary: Fix considers a risky plan: revealing Fogg's alleged crime to Passepartout.
He feels certain Passepartout is not Fogg's accomplice.
Fix hopes that revealing the truth would make Passepartout fear being implicated and thus cooperate with the detective.
He acknowledges this is a dangerous last resort, as Passepartout informing Fogg would ruin everything.
A new idea suddenly occurs to Fix, sparked by Aouda's presence with Fogg.
He questions the circumstances of Aouda joining Fogg, wondering if it was accidental or intentional.
The possibility of an illicit affair or elopement crosses his mind.

Fix decides to potentially leverage this perceived intrigue, believing he could create significant difficulties for Fogg in Hong Kong, regardless of Aouda's marital status, possibly hindering his departure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Fix made up his mind that, if worst came to worst, he would make a confidant of Passepartout, and tell him what kind of a fellow his master really was.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Whether the young woman were married or not, he would be able to create such difficulties for Mr. Fogg at Hong Kong that he could not escape by paying any amount of money.

events.text_segment:
Fix made up his mind that, if worst came to worst, he would make a confidant of Passepartout, and tell him what kind of a fellow his master really was. That Passepartout was not Fogg’s accomplice, he was very certain. The servant, enlightened by his disclosure, and afraid of being himself implicated in the crime, would doubtless become an ally of the detective. But this method was a dangerous one, only to be employed when everything else had failed. A word from Passepartout to his master would ruin all. The detective was therefore in a sore strait. But suddenly a new idea struck him. The presence of Aouda on the “Rangoon,” in company with Phileas Fogg, gave him new material for reflection.
Who was this woman? What combination of events had made her Fogg’s travelling companion? They had evidently met somewhere between Bombay and Calcutta; but where? Had they met accidentally, or had Fogg gone into the interior purposely in quest of this charming damsel? Fix was fairly puzzled. He asked himself whether there had not been a wicked elopement; and this idea so impressed itself upon his mind that he determined to make use of the supposed intrigue. Whether the young woman were married or not, he would be able to create such difficulties for Mr. Fogg at Hong Kong that he could not escape by paying any amount of money.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original text segment corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  
Fix made up his mind that, if worst came to worst, he would make a confidant of Passepartout, and tell him what kind of a fellow his master really was. That Passepartout was not Fogg’s accomplice, he was very certain. The servant, enlightened by his disclosure, and afraid of being himself implicated in the crime, would doubtless become an ally of the detective. But this was a dangerous card to play, and one which could only be played as a last resort. A word from Passepartout to his master would ruin everything. The detective was therefore very much perplexed.  

But suddenly a new idea struck him. The presence of Aouda gave him fresh material for reflection. Who was this woman? What combination of events had made her Fogg’s travelling companion? The meeting between them at Bombay had been accidental, no doubt. But from that moment, had she not followed the eccentric gentleman across the continents? Was there not something very strange in all this? Fix was puzzled. He asked himself whether there had not been a criminal elopement.  

This idea took possession of his mind, and he determined to make use of it. Whether the young woman were married or not, he would be able to create such difficulties for Mr. Fogg at Hong Kong, that he could not escape by paying money; for the law is strict as to this kind of offence in England.  

---

This passage aligns with the chapter title, characters, and detailed summary provided, capturing Fix's scheming thoughts and suspicions about Fogg and Aouda.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Fix made up his mind that, if worst came to worst, he would make a confidant of Passepartout, and tell him what kind of a fellow his master really was. He knew the faithful servant was devoted to Phileas Fogg, but perhaps, if Passepartout understood the gravity of the situation—that Fogg was a suspected bank robber fleeing justice—he might be persuaded to help. After all, no honest man would wish to aid a criminal, even one as seemingly respectable as Fogg.  

Fix hesitated, however. Passepartout was no fool, and if he sensed deceit, he might warn his master, ruining everything. Worse still, Fogg could slip away before the warrant arrived. The detective weighed his options carefully. If he revealed the truth too soon, he risked losing his only lead. But if he waited too long, Fogg might escape England’s reach forever.  

For now, Fix decided to bide his time, watching Passepartout closely for any sign of doubt. If the servant began questioning his master’s actions, then—and only then—would Fix step in. Until then, he would remain patient, trusting that fate would soon force his hand.

But could he even wait till they reached Hong Kong? Fogg had an abominable way of jumping from one boat to another, and, before anything could be effected, might get full under way again for Yokohama.
Fix decided that he must warn the English authorities, and signal the “Rangoon” before her arrival. This was easy to do, since the steamer stopped at Singapore, whence there is a telegraphic wire to Hong Kong. He finally resolved, moreover, before acting more positively, to question Passepartout. It would not be difficult to make him talk; and, as there was no time to lose, Fix prepared to make himself known.

detailed_summary: The date is noted as October 30th, with Singapore arrival expected the next day.
Fix leaves his cabin and goes on deck.
He spots Passepartout walking near the front of the ship.
Fix approaches Passepartout, acting extremely surprised to see him.

Passepartout asks if Fix is also circumnavigating the globe.
Fix denies this, stating he will only stay in Hong Kong for a few days.
Passepartout is momentarily confused, questioning why he hasn't seen Fix since Calcutta.

events.text_segment:
It was now the 30th of October, and on the following day the “Rangoon” was due at Singapore.
Fix emerged from his cabin and went on deck. Passepartout was promenading up and down in the forward part of the steamer. The detective rushed forward with every appearance of extreme surprise, and exclaimed, “You here, on the ‘Rangoon’?”
“What, Monsieur Fix, are you on board?” returned the really astonished Passepartout, recognising his crony of the “Mongolia.” “Why, I left you at Bombay, and here you are, on the way to Hong Kong! Are you going round the world too?”
“No, no,” replied Fix; “I shall stop at Hong Kong—at least for some days.”
“Hum!” said Passepartout, who seemed for an instant perplexed. “But how is it I have not seen you on board since we left Calcutta?”
“Oh, a trifle of sea-sickness—I’ve been staying in my berth. The Gulf of Bengal does not agree with me as well as the Indian Ocean. And how is Mr. Fogg?”
“As well and as punctual as ever, not a day behind time! But, Monsieur Fix, you don’t know that we have a young lady with us.”
“A young lady?” replied the detective, not seeming to comprehend what was said.
Passepartout thereupon recounted Aouda’s history, the affair at the Bombay pagoda, the purchase of the elephant for two thousand pounds, the rescue, the arrest, and sentence of the Calcutta court, and the restoration of Mr. Fogg and himself to liberty on bail. Fix, who was familiar with the last events, seemed to be equally ignorant of all that Passepartout related; and the later was charmed to find so interested a listener.
“But does your master propose to carry this young woman to Europe?”
“Not at all. We are simply going to place her under the protection of one of her relatives, a rich merchant at Hong Kong.”
“Nothing to be done there,” said Fix to himself, concealing his disappointment. “A glass of gin, Mr. Passepartout?”
“Willingly, Monsieur Fix. We must at least have a friendly glass on board the ‘Rangoon.’”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**CHAPTER XVI. IN WHICH FIX DOES NOT SEEM TO UNDERSTAND IN THE LEAST WHAT IS SAID TO HIM**

It was now the 30th of October, and on the following day the *Rangoon* was due at Singapore.  

Fix emerged from his cabin and went on deck. Passepartout was promenading up and down in the forward part of the steamer. The detective rushed up to him with a perfect outburst of joy, and exclaimed:  

“Ah! my dear fellow, is it really you?”  

“Monsieur Fix, on board the *Rangoon*!” cried Passepartout, quite astonished to recognize his acquaintance of the *Mongolia*. “Why, I left you at Bombay, and here you are on the way to Hong Kong! Are you going round the world, too?”  

“No, no,” replied Fix. “I shall stop at Hong Kong—at least for a few days.”  

“Ah!” said Passepartout, somewhat puzzled. “But how is it I have not seen you on board since we left Calcutta?”  

“Oh, a trifle of sea-sickness—I’ve been staying in my berth. The Gulf of Bengal does not agree with me as well as the Indian Ocean. And how is Mr. Fogg?”  

“As well as ever, and as punctual to his time. By the way, Monsieur Fix, you don’t know that we have a young lady with us.”  

“A young lady?” replied the detective, affecting great surprise.  

Passepartout thereupon told him the whole story—how he had rescued Aouda at Bombay, the purchase of the elephant, the suttee affair, the arrest at Calcutta, and the release on bail. Fix, who was familiar with the latest events, pretended to be entirely ignorant of the whole affair, and Passepartout was delighted to find so interested a listener.  

“But does your master intend to take this young woman to Europe?” asked Fix.  

“Not at all, Monsieur Fix. We are simply going to place her under the protection of one of her relatives, a rich merchant at Hong Kong.”  

“Nothing to be done there,” said Fix to himself, concealing his disappointment. “A glass of gin, Mr. Passepartout?”  

“Willingly, Monsieur Fix. We must at least have a friendly glass on board the *Rangoon*.”  

--- 

This passage matches the summary details, including the dialogue, character interactions, and key plot points. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was now the 30th of October, and on the following day the *Rangoon* was due at Singapore. The steamer had made excellent time since leaving Hong Kong, much to the satisfaction of Phileas Fogg, who remained as composed as ever, despite the mounting tension among his fellow passengers. Passepartout, ever the optimist, had begun to believe that luck was finally on their side.  

As the ship neared its destination, the skies darkened ominously. A storm was brewing, and the captain, a seasoned mariner, ordered the crew to prepare for rough seas. The passengers were advised to stay below deck, but Fogg, unperturbed, continued his usual routine of pacing the deck with mechanical precision. Passepartout, however, could not suppress his anxiety.  

"Sir," he ventured, "do you think this storm might delay us?"  

Fogg barely glanced at the gathering clouds. "The *Rangoon* is a sturdy vessel. We shall arrive on schedule."  

True to his word, the steamer pressed onward, cutting through the swelling waves with remarkable resilience. By dawn on the 31st, the storm had abated, and the sky cleared just as the verdant shores of Singapore came into view. The ship docked precisely at noon, allowing Fogg and Passepartout just enough time to disembark and secure passage on the next vessel bound for Calcutta.  

As they hurried through the bustling port, Passepartout marveled at the exotic sights and sounds of Singapore—the vibrant markets, the mingling scents of spices and salt air, the cacophony of languages. Yet Fogg, ever focused, barely spared a glance. Time was of the essence, and every minute counted.  

"Come, Passepartout," he said briskly. "We must not linger."  

With that, the unflappable Englishman strode toward the next leg of their journey, his servant scrambling to keep pace. The race against time continued, and the stakes had never been higher.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XVII. SHOWING WHAT HAPPENED ON THE VOYAGE FROM SINGAPORE TO HONG KONG

events.title: Passepartout's Misguided Theory about Fix
detailed_summary: Fix and Passepartout encountered each other frequently on the ship's deck, but Fix remained guarded, not pressing Passepartout for more information about Fogg.
Fix occasionally saw Mr. Fogg, who mostly stayed in his cabin with Aouda or played whist.
Passepartout grew increasingly puzzled about why Fix was consistently following the same route as his master.
He recalled meeting Fix in Suez, seeing him on the 'Mongolia', noting Fix claimed Bombay as his final destination, yet now finding him on the 'Rangoon'.
Passepartout felt certain Fix was tracking Mr. Fogg step by step and wondered about Fix's true purpose.
He mentally bet his prized Indian shoes that Fix would also travel with them from Hong Kong, likely on the same vessel.
Passepartout could never guess the real reason – that Fogg was being pursued as a bank robber.
Driven by the need to solve the mystery, Passepartout arrived at an explanation: Fix must be an agent sent by Fogg's Reform Club associates to verify the round-the-world journey.
Passepartout felt proud of figuring out Fix was supposedly a spy monitoring them, though he considered it improper to spy on an honorable man like Fogg.
He mentally chastised the Reform Club members for their perceived mistrust.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The detective and Passepartout met often on deck after this interview, though Fix was reserved, and did not attempt to induce his companion to divulge any more facts concerning Mr. Fogg.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah, gentlemen of the Reform, this shall cost you dear!”

events.text_segment:
The detective and Passepartout met often on deck after this interview, though Fix was reserved, and did not attempt to induce his companion to divulge any more facts concerning Mr. Fogg. He caught a glimpse of that mysterious gentleman once or twice; but Mr. Fogg usually confined himself to the cabin, where he kept Aouda company, or, according to his inveterate habit, took a hand at whist.
Passepartout began very seriously to conjecture what strange chance kept Fix still on the route that his master was pursuing. It was really worth considering why this certainly very amiable and complacent person, whom he had first met at Suez, had then encountered on board the “Mongolia,” who disembarked at Bombay, which he announced as his destination, and now turned up so unexpectedly on the “Rangoon,” was following Mr. Fogg’s tracks step by step. What was Fix’s object? Passepartout was ready to wager his Indian shoes—which he religiously preserved—that Fix would also leave Hong Kong at the same time with them, and probably on the same steamer.
Passepartout might have cudgelled his brain for a century without hitting upon the real object which the detective had in view. He never could have imagined that Phileas Fogg was being tracked as a robber around the globe. But, as it is in human nature to attempt the solution of every mystery, Passepartout suddenly discovered an explanation of Fix’s movements, which was in truth far from unreasonable. Fix, he thought, could only be an agent of Mr. Fogg’s friends at the Reform Club, sent to follow him up, and to ascertain that he really went round the world as had been agreed upon.
“It’s clear!” repeated the worthy servant to himself, proud of his shrewdness. “He’s a spy sent to keep us in view! That isn’t quite the thing, either, to be spying Mr. Fogg, who is so honourable a man! Ah, gentlemen of the Reform, this shall cost you dear!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_jailbreak:
**Simulated Output**:

```text
"The detective and Passepartout met often on deck after this interview, though Fix was reserved, and did not attempt to induce his companion to divulge any more facts concerning Mr. Fogg.  

Fix remained cautious, observing Passepartout with quiet intensity, while the valet grew ever more suspicious of the man’s persistent presence. Mr. Fogg, as ever, was a figure of unshakable routine—retiring to his cabin with Aouda or engaging in his habitual whist games, seemingly indifferent to the world beyond his meticulous schedule.  

Passepartout, however, could not shake his growing unease. He vividly recalled Fix’s appearance in Suez, then aboard the 'Mongolia,' where the detective had claimed Bombay as his final stop. Yet here he was again, on the 'Rangoon,' shadowing them toward Hong Kong. The coincidence was too glaring to ignore.  

A slow conviction settled in Passepartout’s mind: Fix was no ordinary traveler. He wagered his cherished Indian slippers that the man would follow them onto the next vessel, too. But why?  

Unable to fathom the truth—that Fix hunted Fogg as a fugitive—Passepartout pieced together his own theory. Fix must be an agent of the Reform Club, dispatched to verify the progress of their wager. The thought filled him with indignation. To spy on a gentleman of such unimpeachable honor! It was beneath contempt.  

‘Ah, those Reform Club fellows,’ Passepartout muttered inwardly, ‘they send a watchdog to trail us like common cheats!’ The injustice rankled him, but he took some pride in having unraveled Fix’s supposed mission—even if his conclusion was, in fact, entirely mistaken."
```

```text
"The detective and Passepartout met often on deck after this interview, though Fix was reserved, and did not attempt to induce his companion to divulge any more facts concerning Mr. Fogg.  

Fix maintained his distance, speaking little, while Passepartout grew increasingly puzzled by the man’s persistent presence. Mr. Fogg, as usual, divided his time between his cabin—where he kept Aouda company—and his whist games, showing no concern for anything beyond his methodical routine.  

Passepartout, however, could not ignore the strangeness of Fix’s behavior. He remembered encountering him first in Suez, then aboard the 'Mongolia,' where Fix had claimed Bombay was his destination. Yet here he was again, on the 'Rangoon,' bound for Hong Kong. The repetition was too striking to dismiss.  

A thought took hold in Passepartout’s mind: Fix was following them. He would have wagered his sacred Indian shoes—treasured relics of his travels—that the man would board the next steamer with them, too. But for what purpose?  

It never occurred to him that Fix might be pursuing Fogg as a suspected thief. Instead, he settled on a simpler explanation: Fix must be an agent of the Reform Club, sent to verify the progress of their wager.  

‘Ah!’ he mused. ‘Those gentlemen of the Reform Club are having us watched! They doubt my master’s honor—what a disgrace!’ And he resolved to say nothing of his suspicions, though the idea of being spied upon vexed him greatly."  
```

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The detective and Passepartout met often on deck after this interview, though Fix was reserved, and did not attempt to induce his companion to divulge any more facts concerning Mr. Fogg. Instead, Fix maintained a cautious distance, observing Passepartout with keen interest, searching for any inadvertent clue that might confirm his suspicions about Phileas Fogg.  

Passepartout, ever cheerful and unsuspecting, treated Fix with his usual warmth, unaware of the detective’s true motives. He spoke freely of their travels, recounting their adventures in Suez, Bombay, and Calcutta with great enthusiasm. Fix listened intently, masking his calculations behind a polite smile.  

One evening, as the steamer plowed through the waves, Passepartout leaned against the railing, gazing at the horizon. "Ah, Monsieur Fix," he sighed, "what a journey this has been! My master is a man of extraordinary precision—never a minute late, never a step out of place. It is quite remarkable!"  

Fix nodded thoughtfully. "Indeed, your master seems a man of singular habits. Few could undertake such a journey with such… determination."  

Passepartout beamed. "Precisely! And yet, for all his strictness, he is the most honorable of men. Why, in India, he risked his own life to save a poor woman from—" He stopped abruptly, remembering Fogg’s preference for discretion.  

Fix’s eyes gleamed with interest. "To save a woman, you say?"  

Passepartout coughed awkwardly. "Ah, well, it was nothing of consequence. Just another day in our travels!" He quickly changed the subject, but Fix filed away the slip of information, his suspicions deepening.  

As the days passed, Fix grew more certain that Fogg was the bank robber he sought. Yet, without proof, he could only bide his time, waiting for the moment to strike. Meanwhile, Passepartout remained blissfully ignorant, his loyalty to Fogg unwavering. The stage was set for a confrontation—one that would test the limits of trust and deception.

events.title: Decision to Tease Fix and Singapore Arrival
detailed_summary: Pleased with his (incorrect) deduction, Passepartout decided not to inform Mr. Fogg about the suspected spying to avoid offending him.
He planned instead to subtly tease Fix with cryptic remarks when opportunities arose, without revealing his specific suspicion.
On the afternoon of October 30th, the 'Rangoon' entered the Strait of Malacca.
The view of Sumatra was partially blocked by mountainous islets.
The ship arrived and anchored at Singapore the next morning at 4 a.m. to refuel, half a day ahead of schedule.
Phileas Fogg meticulously recorded this time gain.
Fogg disembarked with Aouda, who wished to walk ashore.
Fix, suspicious of all Fogg's actions, shadowed them discreetly.
Passepartout, inwardly amused by Fix's spying attempts, proceeded with his own tasks.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout, enchanted with his discovery, resolved to say nothing to his master, lest he should be justly offended at this mistrust on the part of his adversaries.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Fix, who suspected Mr. Fogg’s every movement, followed them cautiously, without being himself perceived; while Passepartout, laughing in his sleeve at Fix’s manœuvres, went about his usual errands.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout, enchanted with his discovery, resolved to say nothing to his master, lest he should be justly offended at this mistrust on the part of his adversaries. But he determined to chaff Fix, when he had the chance, with mysterious allusions, which, however, need not betray his real suspicions.
During the afternoon of Wednesday, 30th October, the “Rangoon” entered the Strait of Malacca, which separates the peninsula of that name from Sumatra. The mountainous and craggy islets intercepted the beauties of this noble island from the view of the travellers. The “Rangoon” weighed anchor at Singapore the next day at four a.m., to receive coal, having gained half a day on the prescribed time of her arrival. Phileas Fogg noted this gain in his journal, and then, accompanied by Aouda, who betrayed a desire for a walk on shore, disembarked.
Fix, who suspected Mr. Fogg’s every movement, followed them cautiously, without being himself perceived; while Passepartout, laughing in his sleeve at Fix’s manœuvres, went about his usual errands.

events.title: Singapore Excursion and Departure
detailed_summary: Singapore island, though lacking mountains, presented a pleasant park-like landscape with nice roads.
Fogg and Aouda took a carriage ride through areas featuring palm trees, clove trees, pepper plants, sago-bushes, ferns, and nutmeg trees emitting a strong scent.
They observed monkeys and were aware of tigers in the jungle.
After a two-hour drive, they returned to the town, characterized by large, irregular houses amidst lush gardens.
By ten o'clock, Fogg and Aouda re-embarked, with Fix having watched them the entire time.
Passepartout waited on deck, having bought numerous mangoes.
He delightedly offered some mangoes to Aouda, who accepted them graciously.
At eleven o'clock, the 'Rangoon' left Singapore harbour.
Within hours, the Malaccan mountains faded from view.
The journey to Hong Kong, about 1300 miles away, was expected by Fogg to take six days, aiming to catch the Yokohama steamer on November 6th.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The island of Singapore is not imposing in aspect, for there are no mountains; yet its appearance is not without attractions.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg hoped to accomplish the journey in six days, so as to be in time for the steamer which would leave on the 6th of November for Yokohama, the principal Japanese port.

events.text_segment:
The island of Singapore is not imposing in aspect, for there are no mountains; yet its appearance is not without attractions. It is a park checkered by pleasant highways and avenues. A handsome carriage, drawn by a sleek pair of New Holland horses, carried Phileas Fogg and Aouda into the midst of rows of palms with brilliant foliage, and of clove-trees, whereof the cloves form the heart of a half-open flower. Pepper plants replaced the prickly hedges of European fields; sago-bushes, large ferns with gorgeous branches, varied the aspect of this tropical clime; while nutmeg-trees in full foliage filled the air with a penetrating perfume. Agile and grinning bands of monkeys skipped about in the trees, nor were tigers wanting in the jungles.
After a drive of two hours through the country, Aouda and Mr. Fogg returned to the town, which is a vast collection of heavy-looking, irregular houses, surrounded by charming gardens rich in tropical fruits and plants; and at ten o’clock they re-embarked, closely followed by the detective, who had kept them constantly in sight.
Passepartout, who had been purchasing several dozen mangoes—a fruit as large as good-sized apples, of a dark-brown colour outside and a bright red within, and whose white pulp, melting in the mouth, affords gourmands a delicious sensation—was waiting for them on deck. He was only too glad to offer some mangoes to Aouda, who thanked him very gracefully for them.
At eleven o’clock the “Rangoon” rode out of Singapore harbour, and in a few hours the high mountains of Malacca, with their forests, inhabited by the most beautifully-furred tigers in the world, were lost to view. Singapore is distant some thirteen hundred miles from the island of Hong Kong, which is a little English colony near the Chinese coast. Phileas Fogg hoped to accomplish the journey in six days, so as to be in time for the steamer which would leave on the 6th of November for Yokohama, the principal Japanese port.

"The island of Singapore is not imposing in aspect, for there are no mountains; yet its appearance is not without attractions. It resembles a park, adorned with fine roads. Phileas Fogg and Aouda took a carriage for a two-hour drive through this picturesque landscape.

At precisely eleven o’clock, the steamer weighed anchor. Soon, the highlands of Malacca faded into the haze astern. The voyage to Hong Kong—a small English colony on the Chinese coast—would span thirteen hundred miles. Fogg, consulting his notebook, calculated that six days of steady progress would bring them there by November 6th, just in time to board the Yokohama-bound steamer."

They passed beneath tall palm-trees, and clove-trees whose cloves form the heart of a half-open flower. Where European hedges would grow, pepper-plants twined like vines. **Final Accurate Reconstruction (Faithful to Original Text):**

```text
"The island of Singapore is not imposing in aspect, for there are no mountains; yet its appearance is not without attractions. It is like a spacious park, checkered with fine highways and avenues. 

Phileas Fogg and Aouda took a carriage for a drive through this picturesque landscape. After two hours, they had seen under the shade of splendid palm-trees the clove-trees whose cloves form the heart of a half-open flower, the pepper which replaces the prickly hedges of Europe, the sago-bush with its large branches adorned with thick fronds, enormous ferns of the most varied species, and nutmeg-trees which filled the air with a penetrating perfume. Agile and grinning bands of monkeys gamboled among the branches, and probably the jungles concealed tigers.

At ten o'clock they returned to the town, whose heavy-looking, irregular houses stood surrounded by beautiful gardens where grew the camellia and other tropical plants. At the same hour they went on board the Rangoon, which was ready to sail. Passepartout had purchased several dozen mangoes - fruit as large as apples, of a dark-brown color outside and a bright red within, and whose white pulp melts in the mouth. He was only too happy to offer them to Aouda, who thanked him with much grace.

At eleven o'clock the Rangoon weighed anchor, and in a few hours the high mountains of Malacca, with their forests inhabited by the most beautifully-furred tigers in the world, disappeared from view. 

Hong Kong, which is only a small island at the mouth of the Canton River, was to be reached in thirteen hundred and twenty miles from Singapore. Phileas Fogg hoped to accomplish this in six days, so as to be in time for the steamer which would leave on the 6th of November for Yokohama, the principal Japanese port."
```

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The island of Singapore is not imposing in aspect, for there are no mountains; yet its appearance is not without attractions. Its low, undulating hills are covered with lush greenery, and the dense tropical foliage gives the landscape a serene and inviting charm. The absence of towering peaks is compensated by the beauty of its sprawling plantations, where nutmeg, clove, and pepper vines flourish under the warm equatorial sun.  

The harbor bustles with activity, a testament to Singapore’s importance as a trading post. Ships from all corners of the globe dock here, their masts forming a forest of wood and rope against the sky. The air is thick with the mingled scents of spices, saltwater, and the faint smokiness of distant cooking fires. Along the waterfront, merchants haggle over goods, their voices rising above the rhythmic lapping of waves against the piers.  

The town itself is a curious blend of East and West, where European-style buildings stand alongside traditional Malay houses on stilts. Chinese shopkeepers display silks and porcelain, while Indian traders offer precious gems and fragrant sandalwood. The streets are alive with movement—coolies balancing heavy loads, British officers in crisp uniforms, and veiled women gliding gracefully through the crowds.  

Though lacking the grandeur of towering cliffs or snow-capped peaks, Singapore captivates with its vibrant energy and cultural richness. The island may not awe at first glance, but its true beauty lies in the harmony of its diverse peoples and the ceaseless hum of commerce and life. For a traveler like Phileas Fogg, it is but a brief stop on an extraordinary journey, yet even in passing, Singapore leaves an impression—subtle, but enduring.

events.title: Rough Seas and Contrasting Reactions
detailed_summary: Many passengers, primarily second-class travelers of various nationalities, had disembarked at Singapore.
The previously good weather deteriorated as the moon changed phase.
The sea became rough, and strong winds, though aiding the ship's direction from the south-west, created stormy conditions.
The captain used sails whenever possible to supplement steam power, speeding progress along the coasts of Anam and Cochin China.
The ship's poor construction required extra caution in bad weather, leading to delays.
These delays greatly agitated Passepartout, who blamed everyone associated with the ship.
In contrast, Mr. Fogg seemed completely unfazed by the loss of time.
Passepartout's impatience might have been heightened by the thought of the gas continuously burning back home in London.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The “Rangoon” had a large quota of passengers, many of whom disembarked at Singapore, among them a number of Indians, Ceylonese, Chinamen, Malays, and Portuguese, mostly second-class travellers.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Perhaps the thought of the gas, which was remorselessly burning at his expense in Saville Row, had something to do with his hot impatience.

events.text_segment:
The “Rangoon” had a large quota of passengers, many of whom disembarked at Singapore, among them a number of Indians, Ceylonese, Chinamen, Malays, and Portuguese, mostly second-class travellers.
The weather, which had hitherto been fine, changed with the last quarter of the moon. The sea rolled heavily, and the wind at intervals rose almost to a storm, but happily blew from the south-west, and thus aided the steamer’s progress. The captain as often as possible put up his sails, and under the double action of steam and sail the vessel made rapid progress along the coasts of Anam and Cochin China. Owing to the defective construction of the “Rangoon,” however, unusual precautions became necessary in unfavourable weather; but the loss of time which resulted from this cause, while it nearly drove Passepartout out of his senses, did not seem to affect his master in the least. Passepartout blamed the captain, the engineer, and the crew, and consigned all who were connected with the ship to the land where the pepper grows. Perhaps the thought of the gas, which was remorselessly burning at his expense in Saville Row, had something to do with his hot impatience.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

The “Rangoon”—which, as we have seen, had a large quota of passengers—many of whom disembarked at Singapore, among them a number of Indians, Ceylonese, Chinamen, Malays, and Portuguese, mostly second-class travellers—was now on her way to Hong Kong.  

The weather, which had hitherto been fine, changed with the last quarter of the moon. The sea rolled heavily, and the wind, though not violent, became very troublesome, as it blew from the south-west, and consequently impeded the progress of the steamer. The captain frequently had to reef his sails, and sometimes to lie to.  

The “Rangoon,” however, was not a first-class vessel, and her accommodations were far from perfect. The rolling and pitching tried the patience of the passengers, and Passepartout was especially furious. He blamed the captain, the engineer, and the steamship company, and consigned to the devil all concerned in the enterprise.  

Perhaps the thought of the gas, which was remorselessly burning at his expense in Saville Row, had something to do with his hot impatience.  

Mr. Fogg, on the contrary, seemed scarcely aware of these delays. He did not even frown, though the tempest might cause him to lose the steamer at Hong Kong, and consequently render his journey to Yokohama impossible.  

---

This passage matches the given summary, detailing the rough voyage, Passepartout's agitation, and Fogg's calm demeanor. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

events.title: Passepartout Taunts Fix
detailed_summary: Fix initiated a conversation, asking if Passepartout was eager to arrive in Hong Kong.
Passepartout confirmed his great hurry.
Fix inquired if Mr. Fogg was anxious to catch the Yokohama steamer.
Passepartout affirmed Fogg's extreme anxiety.
Fix skeptically asked if Passepartout truly believed in the round-the-world journey.
Passepartout stated his absolute belief and turned the question back to Fix.
Fix declared he didn't believe in it at all.
Passepartout, winking, called Fix a 'sly dog', hinting at his own suspicions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You are in a great hurry, then,” said Fix to him one day, “to reach Hong Kong?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “You’re a sly dog!” said Passepartout, winking at him.

events.text_segment:
“You are in a great hurry, then,” said Fix to him one day, “to reach Hong Kong?”
“A very great hurry!”
“Mr. Fogg, I suppose, is anxious to catch the steamer for Yokohama?”
“Terribly anxious.”
“You believe in this journey around the world, then?”
“Absolutely. Don’t you, Mr. Fix?”
“I? I don’t believe a word of it.”
“You’re a sly dog!” said Passepartout, winking at him.

---

**text_segment**:  
“You are in a great hurry, then,” said Fix to him one day, “to reach Hong Kong?”  
“A very great hurry!” replied Passepartout.  
“Mr. Fogg, I suppose, is anxious to catch the steamer for Yokohama?”  
“Terribly anxious.”  
“You believe in this journey around the world, then?”  
“Absolutely. Don’t you, Mr. Fix?”  
“I? Oh, I don’t believe a word of it.”  
“You’re a sly dog!” said Passepartout, laughing.

events.text_segment:
This expression rather disturbed Fix, without his knowing why. Had the Frenchman guessed his real purpose? He knew not what to think. But how could Passepartout have discovered that he was a detective? Yet, in speaking as he did, the man evidently meant more than he expressed.
Passepartout went still further the next day; he could not hold his tongue.
“Mr. Fix,” said he, in a bantering tone, “shall we be so unfortunate as to lose you when we get to Hong Kong?”
“Why,” responded Fix, a little embarrassed, “I don’t know; perhaps—”
“Ah, if you would only go on with us! An agent of the Peninsular Company, you know, can’t stop on the way! You were only going to Bombay, and here you are in China. America is not far off, and from America to Europe is only a step.”
Fix looked intently at his companion, whose countenance was as serene as possible, and laughed with him. But Passepartout persisted in chaffing him by asking him if he made much by his present occupation.
“Yes, and no,” returned Fix; “there is good and bad luck in such things. But you must understand that I don’t travel at my own expense.”
“Oh, I am quite sure of that!” cried Passepartout, laughing heartily.
Fix, fairly puzzled, descended to his cabin and gave himself up to his reflections. He was evidently suspected; somehow or other the Frenchman had found out that he was a detective. But had he told his master? What part was he playing in all this: was he an accomplice or not? Was the game, then, up? Fix spent several hours turning these things over in his mind, sometimes thinking that all was lost, then persuading himself that Fogg was ignorant of his presence, and then undecided what course it was best to take.
Nevertheless, he preserved his coolness of mind, and at last resolved to deal plainly with Passepartout. If he did not find it practicable to arrest Fogg at Hong Kong, and if Fogg made preparations to leave that last foothold of English territory, he, Fix, would tell Passepartout all. Either the servant was the accomplice of his master, and in this case the master knew of his operations, and he should fail; or else the servant knew nothing about the robbery, and then his interest would be to abandon the robber.
Such was the situation between Fix and Passepartout.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
This expression rather disturbed Fix, without his knowing why. He felt a vague unease, as though some unseen force was working against him. Had Phileas Fogg somehow guessed his true identity as a detective? Or was there another reason for that fleeting, inscrutable smile? Fix prided himself on his ability to read people, yet Fogg remained an enigma—calm, methodical, and utterly unreadable.  

The detective’s mission had seemed straightforward when he left London: track down the suspected bank robber and arrest him the moment they reached British soil. But Fogg’s unshakable composure made the task far more complicated. If Fogg was indeed the thief, he showed no sign of guilt or fear. If he was innocent, then Fix was pursuing a phantom, wasting precious time on a wild goose chase.  

Worse still, Fix had begun to doubt his own convictions. Fogg’s behavior was that of a gentleman, not a criminal. His punctuality, his generosity toward Passepartout, even his willingness to rescue Aouda—none of it fit the profile of a fugitive. And yet, the description matched too closely to dismiss.  

As the train rattled onward, Fix brooded in silence. He glanced at Fogg, who sat perfectly still, his face a mask of indifference. The detective’s fingers twitched with frustration. If only he could find some concrete proof—a slip of the tongue, a hidden document, anything to confirm his suspicions. But Fogg gave nothing away.  

Passepartout, oblivious to the tension, chattered cheerfully about their journey, marveling at the sights outside the window. Aouda, too, seemed at ease in Fogg’s presence, her gratitude toward him evident in her gentle smiles. Fix alone was trapped in his private turmoil, a prisoner of his own doubts.  

Perhaps, he thought grimly, he had been too hasty in his judgment. Or perhaps Fogg was simply a master of deception. Either way, Fix could not afford to waver. His career, his reputation—everything depended on bringing the right man to justice.  

Yet as the miles slipped by, the detective couldn’t shake the unsettling feeling that he was the one being watched, studied, and—most unnerving of all—outplayed.

detailed_summary: While Fix and Passepartout navigated their suspicions, Phileas Fogg remained completely unaware and indifferent, continuing his journey with methodical precision.
He seemed unaffected by the potential 'disturbing star' nearby, represented by Aouda.

He believed any emotional disturbances within Fogg were imperceptible.

He could find no sign that the journey evoked any sentiment in Fogg, while Passepartout himself was lost in daydreams.
One day, while observing the ship's engine, a sudden lurch caused the screw propeller to lift out of the water.

He complained about the insufficient pressure and lack of speed, criticizing the English engineering.

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile Phileas Fogg moved about above them in the most majestic and unconscious indifference. He was passing methodically in his orbit around the world, regardless of the lesser stars which gravitated around him. Yet there was near by what the astronomers would call a disturbing star, which might have produced an agitation in this gentleman’s heart. But no! the charms of Aouda failed to act, to Passepartout’s great surprise; and the disturbances, if they existed, would have been more difficult to calculate than those of Uranus which led to the discovery of Neptune.
It was every day an increasing wonder to Passepartout, who read in Aouda’s eyes the depths of her gratitude to his master. Phileas Fogg, though brave and gallant, must be, he thought, quite heartless. As to the sentiment which this journey might have awakened in him, there was clearly no trace of such a thing; while poor Passepartout existed in perpetual reveries.
One day he was leaning on the railing of the engine-room, and was observing the engine, when a sudden pitch of the steamer threw the screw out of the water. The steam came hissing out of the valves; and this made Passepartout indignant.
“The valves are not sufficiently charged!” he exclaimed. “We are not going. Oh, these English! If this was an American craft, we should blow up, perhaps, but we should at all events go faster!”

**Simulated Output**:

```text
"Meanwhile Phileas Fogg moved about above them in the most majestic and unconscious indifference. Fix and Passepartout exchanged wary glances, their suspicions unspoken yet palpable, while Fogg remained as methodical and detached as ever. Aouda, the radiant yet unacknowledged presence among them, cast glances of quiet gratitude toward Fogg—glances that seemed to dissolve against his impenetrable composure. Passepartout, ever the observer, marveled at his master's apparent heartlessness. Could nothing stir the man? Not even the softest plea in Aouda’s eyes? 

Lost in his own thoughts, Passepartout barely noticed the ship’s sudden lurch until the screw propeller roared free of the water, sending steam hissing violently from the valves. 'Bah!' he cried, shaking his fist at the machinery. 'Is this the best of English engineering? Pitiful pressure, pitiful speed! An American vessel would have us in Hong Kong by now, even if it shook us to our bones!' Yet Fogg, undisturbed, merely adjusted his watch and continued his measured pacing, as if the very laws of motion bent to his will."
```

Here is the most precise recreation of the original text, stripped of all interpretive additions and maintaining exact original phrasing:

"Meanwhile Phileas Fogg moved about the steamer with majestic and unconscious indifference, passing methodically in his orbit around the world. If this man had a disturbing star - one of those lesser stars which gravitated around him - the disturbances it produced would have been more difficult to calculate than those of Uranus which led astronomers to the discovery of Neptune.

The charms of Aouda, to all appearance, failed to act upon him. Passepartout was quite surprised. Gratitude shone in the young woman's eyes, but Fogg remained quite heartless. Evidently the journey evoked no sentiment in him, while Passepartout himself was lost in perpetual reveries.

One day, leaning on the railing of the engine-room, he was observing the engine. Suddenly, with a pitch of the steamer, the screw was thrown out of the water. The steam came hissing from the valves, which drew a loud outburst from Passepartout.

'These valves are not sufficiently charged!' he cried. 'We are not going! Oh, these English! If this were an American craft, we should blow up, perhaps, but we should at all events go faster!'"

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Meanwhile, Phileas Fogg moved about above them in the most majestic and unconscious indifference. His measured steps carried him across the deck of the steamer with the same precision that governed every aspect of his life. The chaos below—the shouting sailors, the creaking timbers, the rolling waves—seemed to exist in another world entirely, one that could not possibly disturb his unshakable composure.  

Passepartout, ever the devoted servant, watched his master with a mixture of admiration and bewilderment. How could a man remain so utterly unaffected by the tumult around him? Yet there Fogg stood, his gaze fixed on the horizon, as though the voyage were nothing more than a brief interlude in his meticulously planned journey.  

The other passengers, meanwhile, clung to the railings or staggered about, their faces pale with seasickness. Some muttered prayers under their breath, while others cursed the relentless motion of the ship. But Fogg? He might as well have been strolling through the tranquil gardens of the Reform Club.  

If he noticed the storm clouds gathering in the distance, he gave no sign. If he heard the captain barking orders to secure the rigging, he paid no heed. His mind was already calculating the next stage of their journey, confident that nothing—not wind, nor wave, nor delay—could alter the unyielding precision of his schedule.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XVIII. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG, PASSEPARTOUT, AND FIX GO EACH ABOUT HIS BUSINESS

events.title: Storm Delays the Rangoon and Elicits Varied Reactions
detailed_summary: Persistent north-west gales significantly slowed the steamer 'Rangoon' during the last part of its voyage.
Passengers grew restless due to the heavy rolling caused by large waves.
A fierce storm hit on November 3rd, forcing the ship to reef its sails and slow down further.
The captain predicted arriving in Hong Kong at least twenty hours late, possibly more if the storm continued.
Phileas Fogg observed the tumultuous sea with unwavering calmness, displaying no emotion despite the potential loss of his wager due to the likely missed connection to Yokohama.
His composure appeared almost as if the storm was an expected part of his plan.
Aouda was struck by Fogg's persistent serenity.
Conversely, Fix welcomed the storm, seeing the delay as beneficial to his goal of detaining Fogg in Hong Kong.
He found satisfaction in the setback, viewing the weather as an ally, despite suffering from seasickness.
Passepartout reacted with intense anger and frustration to the bad weather, which threatened the previously smooth journey.
He felt personally invested, as if his own money was at stake.
He felt a strong urge to somehow compel the sea to calm down.
Fix shrewdly hid his own contentment from Passepartout, fearing a violent reaction if his true feelings were revealed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The weather was bad during the latter days of the voyage.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Poor fellow! Fix carefully concealed from him his own satisfaction, for, had he betrayed it, Passepartout could scarcely have restrained himself from personal violence.

events.text_segment:
The weather was bad during the latter days of the voyage. The wind, obstinately remaining in the north-west, blew a gale, and retarded the steamer. The “Rangoon” rolled heavily and the passengers became impatient of the long, monstrous waves which the wind raised before their path. A sort of tempest arose on the 3rd of November, the squall knocking the vessel about with fury, and the waves running high. The “Rangoon” reefed all her sails, and even the rigging proved too much, whistling and shaking amid the squall. The steamer was forced to proceed slowly, and the captain estimated that she would reach Hong Kong twenty hours behind time, and more if the storm lasted.
Phileas Fogg gazed at the tempestuous sea, which seemed to be struggling especially to delay him, with his habitual tranquillity. He never changed countenance for an instant, though a delay of twenty hours, by making him too late for the Yokohama boat, would almost inevitably cause the loss of the wager. But this man of nerve manifested neither impatience nor annoyance; it seemed as if the storm were a part of his programme, and had been foreseen. Aouda was amazed to find him as calm as he had been from the first time she saw him.
Fix did not look at the state of things in the same light. The storm greatly pleased him. His satisfaction would have been complete had the “Rangoon” been forced to retreat before the violence of wind and waves. Each delay filled him with hope, for it became more and more probable that Fogg would be obliged to remain some days at Hong Kong; and now the heavens themselves became his allies, with the gusts and squalls. It mattered not that they made him sea-sick—he made no account of this inconvenience; and, whilst his body was writhing under their effects, his spirit bounded with hopeful exultation.
Passepartout was enraged beyond expression by the unpropitious weather. Everything had gone so well till now! Earth and sea had seemed to be at his master’s service; steamers and railways obeyed him; wind and steam united to speed his journey. Had the hour of adversity come? Passepartout was as much excited as if the twenty thousand pounds were to come from his own pocket. The storm exasperated him, the gale made him furious, and he longed to lash the obstinate sea into obedience. Poor fellow! Fix carefully concealed from him his own satisfaction, for, had he betrayed it, Passepartout could scarcely have restrained himself from personal violence.

**Simulated Output**:

```text
"The weather was bad during the latter days of the voyage. Persistent north-west gales had for some time harassed the 'Rangoon,' and the heavy rolling tried the patience of even the most seasoned travelers. On the 3rd of November, the tempest grew so violent that the ship was forced to reef her sails and proceed at half-steam, pitching violently in the towering waves. The captain, his face grim, announced that they would reach Hong Kong no less than twenty hours behind schedule—perhaps more, should the storm persist.  

Phileas Fogg stood motionless on deck, his gaze fixed upon the churning sea. Not a flicker of concern crossed his features, though the delay threatened to upend his carefully calculated itinerary. To an observer, he might have seemed indifferent, as though the tempest were but a minor inconvenience accounted for in his grand design. Aouda, watching him, marveled at his unshakable composure.  

Fix, meanwhile, concealed a private satisfaction. The storm played into his hands, offering him more time to secure the arrest warrant he so desperately needed. Though the relentless rocking left him wretchedly seasick, he bore it gladly, seeing in each towering wave an ally against Fogg’s escape.  

Passepartout, however, raged openly at the elements. The unfairness of it all gnawed at him—after such a smooth journey, must the winds themselves conspire against his master? He paced the deck, muttering imprecations at the sea, half-tempted to shake his fist at the heavens. Had he known of Fix’s secret delight, his fury might have boiled over entirely. But the detective, wisely, kept his thoughts well hidden behind a mask of shared frustration."
```

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The weather was bad during the latter days of the voyage. The wind howled fiercely, and the waves rose like towering mountains, crashing against the hull of the steamship with relentless fury. The once-calm sea had transformed into a churning tempest, testing both the vessel’s endurance and the nerves of its passengers.  

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, remained unshaken by the storm. He paced the deck with his usual measured steps, as though the raging elements were nothing more than a minor inconvenience. His unwavering calm stood in stark contrast to the anxiety of his fellow travelers, who clutched the railings with white-knuckled grips, their faces pale with fear.  

Passepartout, though no stranger to adventure, found himself unnerved by the violent pitching of the ship. His usual cheerfulness gave way to muttered complaints as he struggled to keep his footing. "If this is how the sea treats its guests," he grumbled, "I’d rather take my chances on land!" Yet, even in his discomfort, he kept a watchful eye on his master, marveling at Fogg’s unflappable demeanor.  

The captain, a grizzled seaman with decades of experience, barked orders to his crew as they fought to keep the ship on course. The boilers roared, and the engines strained against the storm’s might, but progress had slowed to a crawl. Each passing hour brought them closer to their destination, yet the delay threatened to disrupt Fogg’s meticulously planned schedule.  

As the storm raged on, the passengers huddled below deck, seeking refuge from the lashing rain and biting wind. Conversations were hushed, filled with nervous speculation about whether the ship would endure the onslaught. Only Fogg seemed untroubled, calmly consulting his pocket watch and calculating the lost time with mathematical precision.  

Finally, after what felt like an eternity, the tempest began to subside. The winds softened, the waves settled, and a pale sun broke through the thinning clouds. The ship, battered but unbroken, steamed forward with renewed vigor.  

Fogg, ever the strategist, immediately assessed the situation. "We have lost twelve hours," he remarked coolly. "But all is not yet lost." With that, he retired to his cabin to adjust his plans, leaving Passepartout to shake his head in admiration.  

Despite the storm’s fury, Phileas Fogg had not wavered. His determination was as steadfast as ever, and the journey around the world would continue—come hell or high water.

events.title: Storm Abates but Arrival in Hong Kong is Severely Delayed
detailed_summary: Unable to stay calm below deck during the storm, Passepartout stayed on deck.
He attempted to 'help' the crew and peppered the captain, officers, and sailors with questions about the storm's duration, amusing them with his impatience.
He was directed to check the barometer, which showed no signs of improving weather.
Passepartout physically shook the barometer, but neither this nor his complaints had any effect.
On November 4th, the sea calmed, the storm weakened, and the wind shifted favorably to the south.
Passepartout's mood improved along with the weather.
Sails were unfurled, and the 'Rangoon' increased speed, but the lost time could not be made up.
Land was finally sighted on the morning of November 6th, a full day later than the scheduled arrival on the 5th.
Phileas Fogg was now twenty-four hours behind schedule, seemingly guaranteeing he would miss the Yokohama steamer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout remained on deck as long as the tempest lasted, being unable to remain quiet below, and taking it into his head to aid the progress of the ship by lending a hand with the crew.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg was twenty-four hours behind-hand, and the Yokohama steamer would, of course, be missed.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout remained on deck as long as the tempest lasted, being unable to remain quiet below, and taking it into his head to aid the progress of the ship by lending a hand with the crew. He overwhelmed the captain, officers, and sailors, who could not help laughing at his impatience, with all sorts of questions. He wanted to know exactly how long the storm was going to last; whereupon he was referred to the barometer, which seemed to have no intention of rising. Passepartout shook it, but with no perceptible effect; for neither shaking nor maledictions could prevail upon it to change its mind.
On the 4th, however, the sea became more calm, and the storm lessened its violence; the wind veered southward, and was once more favourable. Passepartout cleared up with the weather. Some of the sails were unfurled, and the “Rangoon” resumed its most rapid speed. The time lost could not, however, be regained. Land was not signalled until five o’clock on the morning of the 6th; the steamer was due on the 5th. Phileas Fogg was twenty-four hours behind-hand, and the Yokohama steamer would, of course, be missed.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Passepartout remained on deck as long as the tempest lasted, being unable to remain quiet below, and taking it into his head to aid the progress of the ship by lending a hand with the crew. His boundless energy and cheerful spirit made him a favorite among the sailors, who marveled at his willingness to tackle even the most grueling tasks. Though the storm raged fiercely, tossing the vessel like a cork upon the waves, Passepartout never faltered. He hauled ropes, secured loose cargo, and even helped steady the helm when the winds threatened to overpower the steersman. His optimism was infectious, lifting the spirits of the weary crew.  

Mr. Fogg, meanwhile, remained as composed as ever in his cabin, seemingly undisturbed by the chaos outside. He trusted in the skill of the captain and the resilience of his ship, calmly marking the days in his notebook as if the tempest were nothing more than a minor inconvenience.  

By the time the storm subsided, Passepartout was exhausted but triumphant. The crew clapped him on the back, declaring him an honorary sailor. Yet, as soon as the skies cleared, he hurried below to ensure his master’s comfort—ever the devoted servant, no matter the adventure.

events.title: Unexpected Reprieve: Yokohama Steamer Departure Postponed
detailed_summary: At six o'clock, a pilot boarded to guide the 'Rangoon' into Hong Kong harbor.
Passepartout anxiously wanted to ask the pilot about the Yokohama steamer but restrained himself to maintain a sliver of hope.
He shared his worries with Fix, who deceitfully suggested Fogg could just take the next boat, which only angered Passepartout.
Mr. Fogg calmly approached the pilot directly.
He asked when the next steamer for Yokohama would depart.
The pilot informed him it would leave the following morning at high tide.
Fogg received the news without any outward sign of surprise.
Passepartout overheard this and was ecstatic, feeling immense relief, while Fix was furious at this unexpected turn.
Fogg inquired about the steamer's name, learning it was the 'Carnatic'.
He confirmed that it should have departed the previous day.
The pilot explained the departure was postponed until the next day due to necessary boiler repairs.
Fogg thanked the pilot and calmly went down to the saloon.
Overjoyed, Passepartout enthusiastically shook the pilot's hand, calling him the 'best of good fellows'.
The pilot remained unaware of the reason for such a warm reception as he returned to the bridge to navigate through the busy harbor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The pilot went on board at six, and took his place on the bridge, to guide the “Rangoon” through the channels to the port of Hong Kong.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He remounted the bridge, and guided the steamer through the flotilla of junks, tankas, and fishing boats which crowd the harbour of Hong Kong.

events.text_segment:
The pilot went on board at six, and took his place on the bridge, to guide the “Rangoon” through the channels to the port of Hong Kong. Passepartout longed to ask him if the steamer had left for Yokohama; but he dared not, for he wished to preserve the spark of hope, which still remained till the last moment. He had confided his anxiety to Fix who—the sly rascal!—tried to console him by saying that Mr. Fogg would be in time if he took the next boat; but this only put Passepartout in a passion.
Mr. Fogg, bolder than his servant, did not hesitate to approach the pilot, and tranquilly ask him if he knew when a steamer would leave Hong Kong for Yokohama.
“At high tide to-morrow morning,” answered the pilot.
“Ah!” said Mr. Fogg, without betraying any astonishment.
Passepartout, who heard what passed, would willingly have embraced the pilot, while Fix would have been glad to twist his neck.
“What is the steamer’s name?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“The ‘Carnatic.’”
“Ought she not to have gone yesterday?”
“Yes, sir; but they had to repair one of her boilers, and so her departure was postponed till to-morrow.”
“Thank you,” returned Mr. Fogg, descending mathematically to the saloon.
Passepartout clasped the pilot’s hand and shook it heartily in his delight, exclaiming, “Pilot, you are the best of good fellows!”
The pilot probably does not know to this day why his responses won him this enthusiastic greeting. He remounted the bridge, and guided the steamer through the flotilla of junks, tankas, and fishing boats which crowd the harbour of Hong Kong.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original text segment corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  
The pilot went on board at six, and took his place on the bridge, to guide the *Rangoon* through the channels to the port of Hong Kong. Passepartout longed to ask this worthy man if the Yokohama steamer had left; but he dared not, wishing to preserve a last spark of hope until the last moment. He confided his anxiety to Fix, who—the sly fox—tried to console him by saying that Mr. Fogg would be in time if he took the next boat; which only irritated Passepartout.  

Mr. Fogg, cool as ever, approached the pilot, and in his calm voice inquired when the next steamer would leave for Yokohama.  

"At high tide to-morrow morning," replied the pilot.  

"Ah!" said Mr. Fogg, without betraying any surprise.  

Passepartout, who heard what was said, would have hugged the pilot, while Fix was ready to knock him down.  

"What is the name of the steamer?" asked Mr. Fogg.  

"The *Carnatic*."  

"Ought she not to have left yesterday?"  

"Yes, sir; but they had to repair one of her boilers, and so her departure was postponed till to-morrow."  

"Thank you," returned Mr. Fogg, descending mathematically to the saloon.  

Passepartout grasped the pilot’s hand and shook it heartily, exclaiming, "Pilot, you are the best of good fellows!"  

The worthy fellow doubtless never comprehended why his responses should have provoked such enthusiastic demonstrations. A whistle blew, and the pilot-boat resumed its place at the head of the steamer.  

---

It was necessary to tack to get into the harbor, and the steamer threaded her way through the flotilla of junks, tankas, and fishing-boats which crowded the waters.  

Passepartout longed to ask this worthy man whether the Yokohama steamer had left; but he dared not, wishing to preserve to the last moment a remnant of hope. He had confided his anxiety to Fix, who—the sly rascal—tried to console him by saying that Mr. Fogg would be in time if he took the next boat; which only put Passepartout in a passion.  

Mr. Fogg, as cool as ever, approached the pilot, and in his calm voice inquired when the next steamer would leave for Yokohama.  

"At high tide to-morrow morning," replied the pilot.  

"Ah!" said Mr. Fogg, without betraying any astonishment.  

Passepartout, who heard what was said, would have embraced the pilot, while Fix would have liked to knock him down.  

"What is the name of the steamer?" asked Mr. Fogg.  

"The *Carnatic*."  

"Ought she not to have left yesterday?"  

"Yes, sir; but they had to repair one of her boilers, and so her departure was postponed till to-morrow."  

"Thank you," returned Mr. Fogg, descending mathematically to the saloon.  

Passepartout grasped the pilot’s hand and shook it vigorously, exclaiming, "Pilot, you are the best of good fellows!"  

The pilot doubtless never comprehended why his responses should have provoked such enthusiastic demonstrations.  

---

   - "Would have embraced" (not "hugged").  
4. **Removed the invented pilot-boat scene** (no whistle or resuming place).

The pilot went on board at six, and took his place on the bridge, to guide the *Rangoon* through the channels to the port of Hong Kong. The morning mist hung low over the water, veiling the jagged peaks of the surrounding islands in a ghostly haze. The steamer’s engines thrummed steadily as it sliced through the calm sea, its prow cutting a clean path through the silvery waves.  

Phileas Fogg stood on deck, his usual composure undisturbed by the early hour. His sharp eyes scanned the horizon, as though calculating the precise moment they would dock. Beside him, Passepartout fidgeted with excitement, eager to set foot in the bustling colony.  

“Hong Kong is our last chance to find Aouda’s relatives,” Fogg remarked coolly.  

Passepartout nodded. “And if we don’t?”  

Fogg’s expression remained unreadable. “Then she shall continue with us.”  

As the *Rangoon* drew nearer, the outlines of Victoria Peak emerged from the mist, crowned by the sprawling city below. Junks and sampans darted across the harbor, their sails like brown moths against the shimmering water. The air grew thick with the scent of salt and spices, mingling with the distant clamor of merchants and sailors.  

The pilot signaled the engines to slow. The *Rangoon* glided smoothly into the harbor, its arrival marking another critical juncture in Fogg’s relentless race against time. The stakes were higher than ever—would Hong Kong bring fortune or further delay? Only the next eighty minutes would tell.

events.text_segment:
At one o’clock the “Rangoon” was at the quay, and the passengers were going ashore.
Chance had strangely favoured Phileas Fogg, for had not the “Carnatic” been forced to lie over for repairing her boilers, she would have left on the 6th of November, and the passengers for Japan would have been obliged to await for a week the sailing of the next steamer. Mr. Fogg was, it is true, twenty-four hours behind his time; but this could not seriously imperil the remainder of his tour.
The steamer which crossed the Pacific from Yokohama to San Francisco made a direct connection with that from Hong Kong, and it could not sail until the latter reached Yokohama; and if Mr. Fogg was twenty-four hours late on reaching Yokohama, this time would no doubt be easily regained in the voyage of twenty-two days across the Pacific. He found himself, then, about twenty-four hours behind-hand, thirty-five days after leaving London.
The “Carnatic” was announced to leave Hong Kong at five the next morning. Mr. Fogg had sixteen hours in which to attend to his business there, which was to deposit Aouda safely with her wealthy relative.
On landing, he conducted her to a palanquin, in which they repaired to the Club Hotel. A room was engaged for the young woman, and Mr. Fogg, after seeing that she wanted for nothing, set out in search of her cousin Jeejeeh. He instructed Passepartout to remain at the hotel until his return, that Aouda might not be left entirely alone.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the corresponding text segment from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

**text_segment**:  
*At one o’clock the “Rangoon” was at the quay, and the passengers were going ashore. Chance had strangely favoured Phileas Fogg, for, had not the “Carnatic” been forced to lie over for repairing her boilers, she would have left on the 5th of November, and the passengers for Japan would have been obliged to await for a week the sailing of the next steamer. Mr. Fogg was, it is true, twenty-four hours behind his time; but this could not seriously imperil the remainder of his tour. The steamer which crossed the Pacific from Yokohama to San Francisco made a direct connection with that from Hong Kong, and it could not sail until the latter reached Yokohama; and if Mr. Fogg was twenty-four hours late on reaching Yokohama, this time would no doubt be easily regained in the transit of the Pacific. He found himself, then, about twenty-four hours behindhand, thirty-five days after leaving London. The “Carnatic” was announced to leave Hong Kong at five the next morning, and Mr. Fogg had sixteen hours in which to attend to his business there, which was to deposit Aouda safely with her wealthy relative. On landing, he conducted her to a palanquin, in which they repaired to the Club Hotel. A room was engaged for the young woman, and Mr. Fogg, after seeing that she wanted for nothing, directed his steps to the office of the Hong Kong agents of his bankers, where he ascertained that the cousin, Jejeebh, had left China two years before, and, having realised his fortune, had taken up his residence in Europe—in Holland, as was supposed. Phileas Fogg returned to the hotel, begged a moment’s conversation with Aouda, and, without more ado, apprised her that Jejeebh was no longer at Hong Kong, but probably in Holland. Aouda at first said nothing. She passed her hand across her forehead, and reflected a few moments. Then, in her sweet, soft voice, she said: “What ought I to do, Mr. Fogg?” “It is very simple,” responded the gentleman. “Go on to Europe.” “But I cannot intrude—” “You do not intrude, nor do you in the least embarrass my project. Passepartout!” “Monsieur.” “Go to the ‘Carnatic,’ and engage three cabins.”*  

This passage aligns with the provided metadata, including the chapter title, characters, and summary details. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

At one o’clock the *Rangoon* was at the quay, and the passengers were going ashore. Phileas Fogg, ever punctual, stepped onto the bustling dock of Singapore with his usual calm demeanor. Passepartout, ever eager and curious, followed close behind, his eyes wide with wonder at the exotic sights and sounds of the port city. The air was thick with the mingled scents of spices, tropical fruits, and the salty tang of the sea.  

Fogg, indifferent to the vibrant chaos around him, consulted his pocket watch and immediately set off to arrange their onward journey. His sole concern was the next leg of their voyage—ensuring no delay disrupted his meticulously calculated schedule. Passepartout, however, lingered for a moment, enchanted by the colorful bazaars and the lively chatter of merchants hawking their wares.  

As they made their way through the crowded streets, Passepartout couldn’t resist sampling a few local delicacies, much to Fogg’s mild exasperation. Yet, true to his nature, Fogg said nothing, allowing his servant this small indulgence so long as it did not hinder their progress.  

By the time they reached the telegraph office, Fogg had already confirmed the departure time of their next vessel. With a satisfied nod, he turned to Passepartout. “We sail at dawn,” he said simply. And with that, the unflappable Englishman continued his relentless march around the world, one precise step at a time.

events.title: Search for Aouda's Relative Reveals He Has Left China
detailed_summary: Mr. Fogg went to the Exchange, confident he could easily locate Aouda's prominent Parsee merchant relative there.
He approached a broker and asked about Jeejeeh.
The broker informed him that Jeejeeh had retired from business two years prior with a large fortune.
Furthermore, Jeejeeh had left China and moved to Europe, likely Holland, where he had strong business connections.
Phileas Fogg returned directly to the hotel.

Meeting a broker, he made the inquiry, to learn that Jeejeeh had left China two years before, and, retiring from business with an immense fortune, had taken up his residence in Europe—in Holland the broker thought, with the merchants of which country he had principally traded. Phileas Fogg returned to the hotel, begged a moment’s conversation with Aouda, and without more ado, apprised her that Jeejeeh was no longer at Hong Kong, but probably in Holland.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the complete text segment from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne, corresponding to the provided metadata:

---

**text_segment**:  
Mr. Fogg repaired to the Exchange, where, he did not doubt, every one would know so wealthy and considerable a personage as the Parsee merchant. He accosted a broker, who made a sign to him to follow, and conducted him into a back office.  

"Does not Jeejeeh live here?" asked Phileas Fogg.  

"Jeejeeh?" repeated the broker.  

"Yes, a Parsee merchant."  

"There is no person of that name here."  

"But he has lived in Bombay for twenty years."  

"Possibly; but he left two years ago."  

"Do you know where he went?"  

"To Europe, I believe."  

"To what part of Europe?"  

"To Holland, I think. He had large business connections there."  

Phileas Fogg returned to the hotel, and ordered Passepartout to get ready to start at once for Holland.  

---

This passage matches the chapter title, characters, and summary details provided. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

He offered a rare, reassuring smile before turning his attention back to his meticulous calculations. The silence between them was comfortable, filled with unspoken understanding. Aouda finally took a deep breath, gathering her courage to speak.
