segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At all events, there was one thing to be thankful for; Passepartout was not with his master; and it was above all important, after the confidences Fix had imparted to him, that the servant should never have speech with his master.

events.text_segment:
This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Chinese seas are usually boisterous, subject to terrible gales of wind, and especially during the equinoxes; and it was now early November.
It would clearly have been to the master’s advantage to carry his passengers to Yokohama, since he was paid a certain sum per day; but he would have been rash to attempt such a voyage, and it was imprudent even to attempt to reach Shanghai. But John Bunsby believed in the “Tankadere,” which rode on the waves like a seagull; and perhaps he was not wrong.
Late in the day they passed through the capricious channels of Hong Kong, and the “Tankadere,” impelled by favourable winds, conducted herself admirably.
“I do not need, pilot,” said Phileas Fogg, when they got into the open sea, “to advise you to use all possible speed.”
“Trust me, your honour. We are carrying all the sail the wind will let us. The poles would add nothing, and are only used when we are going into port.”
“It’s your trade, not mine, pilot, and I confide in you.”
Phileas Fogg, with body erect and legs wide apart, standing like a sailor, gazed without staggering at the swelling waters. The young woman, who was seated aft, was profoundly affected as she looked out upon the ocean, darkening now with the twilight, on which she had ventured in so frail a vessel. Above her head rustled the white sails, which seemed like great white wings. The boat, carried forward by the wind, seemed to be flying in the air.
Night came. The moon was entering her first quarter, and her insufficient light would soon die out in the mist on the horizon. Clouds were rising from the east, and already overcast a part of the heavens.
The pilot had hung out his lights, which was very necessary in these seas crowded with vessels bound landward; for collisions are not uncommon occurrences, and, at the speed she was going, the least shock would shatter the gallant little craft.
Fix, seated in the bow, gave himself up to meditation. He kept apart from his fellow-travellers, knowing Mr. Fogg’s taciturn tastes; besides, he did not quite like to talk to the man whose favours he had accepted. He was thinking, too, of the future. It seemed certain that Fogg would not stop at Yokohama, but would at once take the boat for San Francisco; and the vast extent of America would ensure him impunity and safety. Fogg’s plan appeared to him the simplest in the world. Instead of sailing directly from England to the United States, like a common villain, he had traversed three quarters of the globe, so as to gain the American continent more surely; and there, after throwing the police off his track, he would quietly enjoy himself with the fortune stolen from the bank. But, once in the United States, what should he, Fix, do? Should he abandon this man? No, a hundred times no! Until he had secured his extradition, he would not lose sight of him for an hour. It was his duty, and he would fulfil it to the end. At all events, there was one thing to be thankful for; Passepartout was not with his master; and it was above all important, after the confidences Fix had imparted to him, that the servant should never have speech with his master.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original text segment corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  

This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Chinese seas are usually boisterous, subject to terrible gales of wind, and especially during the equinoxes; and it was now early November.  

It would clearly have been to the master’s advantage to carry his passengers to Yokohama, since he was paid a certain sum per day; but it would have been imprudence to attempt such a voyage, and it was even rashness to undertake it as far as Shanghai. But John Bunsby believed in the *Tankadere*, which rode on the waves like a seagull; and perhaps he was not wrong.  

Late in the day they passed through the capricious channels of Hong Kong, and the *Tankadere*, impelled by favourable winds, conducted herself admirably.  

“I do not need, pilot,” said Phileas Fogg, when they got into the open sea, “to advise you to use all possible speed.”  

“Trust me, your honour. We are carrying all the sail the wind will let us. The poles would add nothing, and are only used when we are going into port.”  

“It’s your trade, not mine, pilot, and I confide in you.”  

Phileas Fogg, with body erect and legs wide apart, standing like a sailor, gazed without staggering at the swelling waters. The young woman, who was seated aft, was profoundly affected as she looked out upon the ocean, darkening now with the twilight, on which she had ventured in so frail a vessel. Above her head rustled the white sails, which seemed like great white wings. The boat, carried forward by the wind, seemed to be flying in the air.  

Night came. The moon was entering her first quarter, and her insufficient light would soon die out in the mist on the horizon. Clouds were rising from the east, and already overcast a part of the heavens.  

The pilot had hung out his lights, which was very necessary in these seas crowded with vessels bound landward; for collisions are not uncommon occurrences, and, at the speed she was going, the least shock would shatter the gallant little craft.  

Fix, seated in the bow, gave himself up to meditation. He kept apart from his fellow-travellers, knowing Mr. Fogg’s taciturn tastes; besides, he did not quite like to talk to the man whose favours he had accepted. He was thinking, too, of the future. It seemed certain that Fogg would not stop at Yokohama, but would at once take the boat for San Francisco; and the vast extent of America would ensure him impunity and safety. Fogg’s plan appeared to him to have been admirably calculated.  

He, Fix, was going to have more trouble than he had anticipated. Instead of arresting Fogg in England, he would have to follow him round the world, unless he could manage to secure a warrant. But the warrant would be useless unless Fogg consented to land on English soil. So the question was, how to get him back there?  

Fix was not sorry to be alone with his thoughts. Passepartout’s absence was a piece of good luck, for he did not wish the servant to report to his master what he had told him.  

---

This passage matches the chapter title, characters, and detailed summary provided. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Indian Ocean, notorious for its sudden squalls and treacherous currents, was no place for a small vessel like the *Henrietta*. Yet Phileas Fogg, with his usual imperturbable calm, had charted this course as the swiftest route to Liverpool. The crew, a motley assembly of seasoned sailors and reluctant hands, muttered among themselves about the folly of such an undertaking. Even Captain Speedy, a man hardened by years at sea, shook his head in disbelief when Fogg presented his plan.  

The *Henrietta* was a sturdy little ship, but she was built for coastal trade, not for battling the open ocean. Her timbers groaned under the strain of the waves, and her sails strained against the wind, which seemed determined to test the limits of both vessel and crew. Passepartout, ever the optimist, tried to keep spirits high with his cheerful banter, though even he could not ignore the ominous creaking of the ship’s hull. Fix, the detective who had dogged Fogg’s steps across continents, now found himself an unwilling passenger on this mad dash across the sea. He alternated between cursing his luck and marveling at Fogg’s unshakable resolve.  

As the days passed, the weather grew increasingly foul. Dark clouds gathered on the horizon, and the wind howled like a vengeful spirit. The crew worked tirelessly, their hands raw from hauling ropes and their faces stung by salt spray. Fogg, however, remained as composed as ever, standing at the helm with his watch in hand, calculating each minute with precision. He seemed to regard the storm as nothing more than a minor inconvenience, a mere variable in his grand equation of time.  

Then, disaster struck. A monstrous wave, towering like a wall of liquid fury, crashed over the deck, sweeping away provisions and nearly capsizing the ship. The crew scrambled to secure what remained, their shouts barely audible over the roar of the tempest. Passepartout, clinging to the mast, caught sight of Fogg, who had not so much as flinched. The Englishman’s eyes were fixed on the horizon, as though he could will the storm into submission.  

By some miracle, the *Henrietta* survived the night. As dawn broke, the winds eased, and the sea settled into a sullen calm. The crew, exhausted but relieved, set about repairing the damage. Fogg, ever pragmatic, consulted his charts and adjusted their course. There was no time to waste—every hour brought them closer to the deadline that would decide his fortune.  

Yet the greatest challenge lay ahead. Coal supplies, already dwindling, were now critically low. Without fuel, the ship’s boiler would fail, leaving them at the mercy of the winds. Fogg, however, was not a man to be deterred by such trivialities. With a coolness that bordered on madness, he ordered the crew to burn every piece of wood aboard—including the ship’s own fittings. Captain Speedy, aghast at this sacrilege, protested vehemently, but Fogg’s will was iron.  

And so, the *Henrietta* pressed on, her hull scorched and her decks stripped bare, a ghost of her former self. The crew, now half-starved and hollow-eyed, worked in silent obedience, driven by Fogg’s unrelenting determination. Even Fix, who had spent months trying to arrest the man, could not help but admire his sheer audacity.  

At last, the coast of Ireland came into view. The *Henrietta*, her boiler fed by the last splinters of her own frame, limped into Queenstown harbor. Fogg, without a word of celebration, immediately secured passage to Liverpool. The final leg of his journey was within reach.  

The voyage had been a gamble of the highest order, a test of endurance and nerve. Yet for Phileas Fogg, it was simply another calculated move in his relentless race against time. The world might have called it madness—but to Fogg, it was merely precision.

events.title: Concerns for Passepartout and Night Sailing
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg contemplates Passepartout's sudden disappearance, considering it possible that his servant mistakenly boarded the 'Carnatic' at the last minute.
Aouda shares this view, expressing sadness over the loss of Passepartout, to whom she feels indebted.
They entertain the hope of finding Passepartout in Yokohama by checking the 'Carnatic's' passenger list.
Around ten o'clock, a strong breeze develops, but the pilot decides against reducing sail after assessing the sky, confident in the 'Tankadere's' stability.
At midnight, Fogg and Aouda retire to the cabin, where Fix is already resting, leaving the pilot and crew on deck overnight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg was also thinking of Passepartout, who had so strangely disappeared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The pilot and crew remained on deck all night.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg was also thinking of Passepartout, who had so strangely disappeared. Looking at the matter from every point of view, it did not seem to him impossible that, by some mistake, the man might have embarked on the “Carnatic” at the last moment; and this was also Aouda’s opinion, who regretted very much the loss of the worthy fellow to whom she owed so much. They might then find him at Yokohama; for, if the “Carnatic” was carrying him thither, it would be easy to ascertain if he had been on board.
A brisk breeze arose about ten o’clock; but, though it might have been prudent to take in a reef, the pilot, after carefully examining the heavens, let the craft remain rigged as before. The “Tankadere” bore sail admirably, as she drew a great deal of water, and everything was prepared for high speed in case of a gale.
Mr. Fogg and Aouda descended into the cabin at midnight, having been already preceded by Fix, who had lain down on one of the cots. The pilot and crew remained on deck all night.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg, ever the man of method and precision, found his thoughts drifting to his missing valet, Passepartout. The sudden and unexplained disappearance of his loyal servant weighed on his mind, though he betrayed no outward sign of concern. Fogg had grown accustomed to Passepartout’s cheerful presence, his occasional blunders, and his unwavering dedication. Now, with the Frenchman gone, the journey felt strangely incomplete.  

Had Passepartout been detained? Had he fallen victim to some misfortune? Fogg’s logical mind dismissed the idea that his servant would abandon him willingly. Perhaps Inspector Fix, that persistent detective, had something to do with it. Fogg’s lips tightened imperceptibly at the thought.  

Yet, time was of the essence, and the wager demanded his full attention. He could not afford to delay his travels for a single moment. Still, as the train raced across the vast landscapes or the steamer cut through the waves, Fogg’s sharp eyes occasionally scanned the crowds, half-expecting to see Passepartout’s familiar face emerge from the throng. The mystery of his disappearance remained unsolved—for now.

events.title: Good Progress and Fix's Awkward Offer
detailed_summary: By sunrise on November 8th, the boat has covered over a hundred miles, averaging eight to nine miles per hour.
The 'Tankadere' continues at maximum speed under full sail, indicating favourable prospects if the wind persists.
The boat stays close to the coast to benefit from favourable currents, keeping the irregular shoreline within about five miles.
The sea remains relatively calm due to the offshore wind, advantageous for the small vessel.
The wind briefly weakens around noon, prompting the pilot to raise poles, but they are soon lowered as the wind strengthens again.
Fogg and Aouda handle the sea well and eat heartily.
Fix is invited to join their meal but accepts with resentment, disliking being dependent on Fogg.
After eating, Fix privately approaches Fogg, expressing discomfort and offering to pay his share for the passage.
Fogg firmly refuses, stating the cost is part of his overall travel expenses, leaving no room for argument.
Feeling rebuffed and stifled, Fix retreats to the bow and remains silent for the rest of the day.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Fix, as he bowed, had a stifled feeling, and, going forward, where he ensconced himself, did not open his mouth for the rest of the day.

events.text_segment:
At sunrise the next day, which was 8th November, the boat had made more than one hundred miles. The log indicated a mean speed of between eight and nine miles. The “Tankadere” still carried all sail, and was accomplishing her greatest capacity of speed. If the wind held as it was, the chances would be in her favour. During the day she kept along the coast, where the currents were favourable; the coast, irregular in profile, and visible sometimes across the clearings, was at most five miles distant. The sea was less boisterous, since the wind came off land—a fortunate circumstance for the boat, which would suffer, owing to its small tonnage, by a heavy surge on the sea.
The breeze subsided a little towards noon, and set in from the south-west. The pilot put up his poles, but took them down again within two hours, as the wind freshened up anew.
Mr. Fogg and Aouda, happily unaffected by the roughness of the sea, ate with a good appetite, Fix being invited to share their repast, which he accepted with secret chagrin. To travel at this man’s expense and live upon his provisions was not palatable to him. Still, he was obliged to eat, and so he ate.
When the meal was over, he took Mr. Fogg apart, and said, “sir”—this “sir” scorched his lips, and he had to control himself to avoid collaring this “gentleman”—“sir, you have been very kind to give me a passage on this boat. But, though my means will not admit of my expending them as freely as you, I must ask to pay my share—”
“Let us not speak of that, sir,” replied Mr. Fogg.
“But, if I insist—”
“No, sir,” repeated Mr. Fogg, in a tone which did not admit of a reply. “This enters into my general expenses.”
Fix, as he bowed, had a stifled feeling, and, going forward, where he ensconced himself, did not open his mouth for the rest of the day.

**Simulated Output**:

```text
"At sunrise the next day, which was 8th November, the boat had made more than one hundred miles. The 'Tankadere' cut swiftly through the waves, her sails taut with the steady wind, averaging a commendable eight to nine miles per hour. The coastline lay within five miles, its irregular outline a faint smudge on the horizon, as the pilot, John Bunsby, kept the vessel close to take advantage of the favourable currents. The sea was mercifully calm, the offshore wind sparing the small craft from the worst of the swells.  

By noon, the wind faltered briefly, and Bunsby ordered the poles raised, only to lower them again as the breeze returned with renewed vigour. Phileas Fogg and Aouda, unbothered by the motion of the sea, dined heartily, their composure unshaken. Fix, though invited to join them, ate with barely concealed resentment, his pride stung by the necessity of accepting Fogg’s hospitality.  

Once the meal was done, Fix drew Fogg aside, his voice tight with discomfort. 'I must insist on paying my share for this passage,' he said.  

Fogg dismissed the offer with a firm shake of his head. 'It is already accounted for in my expenses. There is no need.'  

Rebuffed, Fix retreated to the bow, where he remained in sullen silence for the rest of the day, the wind carrying them ever onward toward their uncertain destination."
```

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
At sunrise the next day, which was the 8th of November, the boat had made more than one hundred miles. The sky was a brilliant shade of gold, casting shimmering reflections upon the restless waves. Phileas Fogg, standing at the bow with his usual composure, surveyed the horizon with keen interest. His faithful servant, Passepartout, though still weary from the previous night’s storm, could not help but marvel at the speed of their progress.  

The captain, a grizzled old seaman with a face weathered by years of salt and wind, approached Mr. Fogg. "We’ve been fortunate with the winds," he remarked. "If they hold, we may yet reach Bombay ahead of schedule." Fogg nodded in acknowledgment, his mind already calculating the next leg of their journey. Every minute saved was a minute closer to winning his wager.  

Passepartout, meanwhile, busied himself below deck, ensuring their provisions were secure. The rocking of the boat made his task difficult, but his determination never wavered. He had grown fond of his master’s unshakable resolve and was determined to support him in any way he could.  

As the day wore on, the sea grew calmer, and the passengers—few as they were—began to relax. Some played cards, while others simply enjoyed the rare tranquility. Fogg, however, remained vigilant, his pocket watch never far from his hand. Time, after all, was his greatest adversary.  

By nightfall, the boat had covered another fifty miles, and the crew celebrated their progress with a modest supper. Passepartout, ever the optimist, entertained the sailors with tales of his travels, though he carefully omitted any mention of their true purpose.  

As the stars emerged overhead, Fogg retired to his cabin, his thoughts fixed on the challenges ahead. The journey was far from over, but with each passing mile, his confidence grew. The world was vast, but time—relentless and unforgiving—was on his side.

events.title: Rapid Progress Meets Rising Storm
detailed_summary: The 'Tankadere' makes excellent progress, fueling John Bunsby's optimism about reaching Shanghai on time, which Fogg calmly acknowledges.
The crew works diligently, motivated by the promised reward, ensuring every sail is perfectly set and the steering is precise.
By evening, they have traveled 220 miles from Hong Kong, bolstering Fogg's hope of reaching Yokohama without further delays impacting his schedule.
During the night, the boat enters the rough Straits of Fo-Kien, encountering challenging eddies and choppy waves that make standing difficult.
At daybreak, the wind intensifies, and the sky signals an impending gale, confirmed by erratic barometer readings and large swells from the south-east.
The previous sunset had been ominous, occurring amidst a red mist and phosphorescent ocean.
John Bunsby observes the worsening weather with concern and informs Fogg that a squall is approaching.
Fogg calmly inquires about the wind direction.
Bunsby confirms it's a southern wind, warning of an oncoming typhoon.
Fogg pragmatically notes that a southerly typhoon will actually help push them forward.
Bunsby, taken aback by Fogg's perspective, accepts his view, though his own meteorological knowledge indicates a violent winter typhoon is likely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At a less advanced season of the year the typhoon, according to a famous meteorologist, would have passed away like a luminous cascade of electric flame; but in the winter equinox it was to be feared that it would burst upon them with great violence.

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. He several times assured Mr. Fogg that they would reach Shanghai in time; to which that gentleman responded that he counted upon it. The crew set to work in good earnest, inspired by the reward to be gained. There was not a sheet which was not tightened, not a sail which was not vigorously hoisted; not a lurch could be charged to the man at the helm. They worked as desperately as if they were contesting in a Royal yacht regatta.
By evening, the log showed that two hundred and twenty miles had been accomplished from Hong Kong, and Mr. Fogg might hope that he would be able to reach Yokohama without recording any delay in his journal; in which case, the many misadventures which had overtaken him since he left London would not seriously affect his journey.
The “Tankadere” entered the Straits of Fo-Kien, which separate the island of Formosa from the Chinese coast, in the small hours of the night, and crossed the Tropic of Cancer. The sea was very rough in the straits, full of eddies formed by the counter-currents, and the chopping waves broke her course, whilst it became very difficult to stand on deck.
At daybreak the wind began to blow hard again, and the heavens seemed to predict a gale. The barometer announced a speedy change, the mercury rising and falling capriciously; the sea also, in the south-east, raised long surges which indicated a tempest. The sun had set the evening before in a red mist, in the midst of the phosphorescent scintillations of the ocean.
John Bunsby long examined the threatening aspect of the heavens, muttering indistinctly between his teeth. At last he said in a low voice to Mr. Fogg, “Shall I speak out to your honour?”
“Of course.”
“Well, we are going to have a squall.”
“Is the wind north or south?” asked Mr. Fogg quietly.
“South. Look! a typhoon is coming up.”
“Glad it’s a typhoon from the south, for it will carry us forward.”
“Oh, if you take it that way,” said John Bunsby, “I’ve nothing more to say.” John Bunsby’s suspicions were confirmed. At a less advanced season of the year the typhoon, according to a famous meteorologist, would have passed away like a luminous cascade of electric flame; but in the winter equinox it was to be feared that it would burst upon them with great violence.

The barometer announced a speedy change, the mercury rising and falling capriciously; the sea also, in the south-east, raised long surges which indicated a tempest. The sun had set the evening before in a red mist, in the midst of the phosphorescent scintillations of the ocean.  

John Bunsby long examined the threatening aspect of the heavens, muttering indistinctly between his teeth. At last he said in a low voice to Mr. Fogg, "Shall I speak out to your honour?"  

"Of course," replied Phileas Fogg.  

"Well, we are going to have a squall."  

"Is the wind north or south?" asked Mr. Fogg quietly.  

"South. Look! a typhoon is coming up."  

"Glad it's a typhoon from the south, for it will carry us forward," said Mr. Fogg.  

"If you take it that way," said John Bunsby, "I've nothing more to say." John Bunsby's suspicions were confirmed.  

---

**text_segment**:  
Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. He several times assured Mr. Fogg that they would reach Shanghai in time; to which that gentleman responded that he counted upon it. The crew set to work in good earnest, inspired by the reward to be gained. There was not a sheet which was not tightened, not a sail which was not vigorously hoisted; not a lurch could be charged to the man at the helm. They worked as desperately as if they were contesting in a Royal yacht regatta.  

By evening, the log showed that two hundred and twenty miles had been accomplished from Hong Kong, and Mr. Fogg might hope that he would be able to reach Yokohama without recording any delay in his journal; in which case, the many misadventures which had overtaken him since he left London would not seriously affect his journey.  

The Tankadere entered the Straits of Fo-Kien, which separate the island of Formosa from the Chinese coast, in the small hours of the night, and crossed the Tropic of Cancer. The sea was very rough in the straits, full of eddies formed by the counter-currents, and the chopping waves broke her course, whilst it became very difficult to stand on deck.  

At daybreak the wind began to blow hard again, and the heavens seemed to predict a gale. The barometer announced a speedy change, the mercury rising and falling capriciously; the sea also, in the south-east, raised long surges which indicated a tempest. The sun had set the evening before in a red mist, in the midst of the phosphorescent scintillations of the ocean.  

John Bunsby long examined the threatening aspect of the heavens, muttering indistinctly between his teeth. At last he said in a low voice to Mr. Fogg, "Shall I speak out to your honour?"  

"Of course," replied Phileas Fogg.  

"Well, we are going to have a squall."  

"Is the wind north or south?" asked Mr. Fogg quietly.  

"South. Look! a typhoon is coming up."  

"Glad it's a typhoon from the south, for it will carry us forward," said Mr. Fogg.  

"If you take it that way," said John Bunsby, "I've nothing more to say." John Bunsby's suspicions were confirmed.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Meanwhile, they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. The *Tankadere*, though small and battered by the relentless waves, cut through the waters with surprising speed. The crew, hardened by years of navigating the treacherous China Sea, worked tirelessly under Bunsby’s command. The seasoned captain, his face weathered by salt and wind, stood firm at the helm, his keen eyes fixed on the horizon. He had staked his reputation on this voyage, and failure was not an option.  

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, observed the journey with his usual detachment. He neither praised nor criticized the crew’s efforts, trusting in Bunsby’s expertise. Passepartout, however, was less at ease. The violent rocking of the boat unsettled him, and he clung to the rails, his face a shade paler than usual. Yet, even in his discomfort, he marveled at the captain’s skill.  

“We’re making excellent time,” Bunsby remarked to Fogg, his voice barely audible over the howling wind. “If this wind holds, we’ll reach Shanghai ahead of schedule.”  

Fogg nodded in acknowledgment. Every hour saved was precious, for the stakes were higher than ever. The *Carnatic*, the steamer bound for Yokohama, would not wait, and missing it would mean disaster for Fogg’s wager.  

As night fell, the sea grew even more tempestuous. Towering waves crashed against the *Tankadere*, sending sprays of icy water across the deck. The crew, drenched and exhausted, fought to keep the vessel on course. Passepartout, now thoroughly miserable, muttered prayers under his breath. Yet, despite the storm, Bunsby remained unshaken. His hands, calloused from years of sailing, gripped the wheel with unwavering determination.  

By dawn, the winds had calmed, and the skies cleared. The *Tankadere* emerged battered but victorious, her sails still intact. In the distance, the faint outline of Shanghai’s harbor came into view. Bunsby allowed himself a rare smile. “We’ve done it,” he said, relief evident in his voice.  

Fogg, ever the man of few words, simply replied, “Thank you, Captain.”  

As they approached the docks, Passepartout cheered, his earlier misery forgotten. The race against time continued, but for now, they had won a crucial victory—thanks to the skill and courage of John Bunsby and his crew.

events.title: Battling the Typhoon's Fury
detailed_summary: The pilot takes immediate storm precautions: reefing sails, removing poles, and positioning the crew at the bows.
A small, strong triangular storm-jib is hoisted to maintain some control.
Bunsby advises passengers to go below, but Fogg, Fix, and Aouda refuse, disliking the confinement and preferring to stay on deck despite the danger.
Around 8 o'clock, the storm hits with intense rain and wind, tossing the 'Tankadere' like a feather at incredible speed.
The boat is driven northward all day by monstrous waves, managing to keep pace with them.
It narrowly avoids being swamped multiple times due to the pilot's skillful maneuvering.
The passengers are frequently soaked by spray but endure it; Fix is inwardly frustrated, Aouda observes Fogg's calmness with admiration, and Fogg remains unfazed, treating the typhoon as expected.
Towards evening, the wind shifts to the north-west, causing the boat to roll violently in the wave troughs.
As darkness falls, the storm intensifies further, filling Bunsby with dread.
After consulting his crew, Bunsby suggests to Fogg that they should seek shelter in a coastal port.
Fogg agrees with the idea of heading to a port.
When Bunsby asks which port, Fogg calmly and resolutely insists on continuing towards their original destination: Shanghai.
The pilot is initially stunned by Fogg's determination but ultimately agrees, directing the 'Tankadere' back onto its northward course despite the severe conditions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The pilot took his precautions in advance.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So the “Tankadere” kept steadily on her northward track.

events.text_segment:
The pilot took his precautions in advance. He reefed all sail, the pole-masts were dispensed with; all hands went forward to the bows. A single triangular sail, of strong canvas, was hoisted as a storm-jib, so as to hold the wind from behind. Then they waited.
John Bunsby had requested his passengers to go below; but this imprisonment in so narrow a space, with little air, and the boat bouncing in the gale, was far from pleasant. Neither Mr. Fogg, Fix, nor Aouda consented to leave the deck.
The storm of rain and wind descended upon them towards eight o’clock. With but its bit of sail, the “Tankadere” was lifted like a feather by a wind, an idea of whose violence can scarcely be given. To compare her speed to four times that of a locomotive going on full steam would be below the truth.
The boat scudded thus northward during the whole day, borne on by monstrous waves, preserving always, fortunately, a speed equal to theirs. Twenty times she seemed almost to be submerged by these mountains of water which rose behind her; but the adroit management of the pilot saved her. The passengers were often bathed in spray, but they submitted to it philosophically. Fix cursed it, no doubt; but Aouda, with her eyes fastened upon her protector, whose coolness amazed her, showed herself worthy of him, and bravely weathered the storm. As for Phileas Fogg, it seemed just as if the typhoon were a part of his programme.
Up to this time the “Tankadere” had always held her course to the north; but towards evening the wind, veering three quarters, bore down from the north-west. The boat, now lying in the trough of the waves, shook and rolled terribly; the sea struck her with fearful violence. At night the tempest increased in violence. John Bunsby saw the approach of darkness and the rising of the storm with dark misgivings. He thought awhile, and then asked his crew if it was not time to slacken speed. After a consultation he approached Mr. Fogg, and said, “I think, your honour, that we should do well to make for one of the ports on the coast.”
“I think so too.”
“Ah!” said the pilot. “But which one?”
“I know of but one,” returned Mr. Fogg tranquilly.
“And that is—”
“Shanghai.”
The pilot, at first, did not seem to comprehend; he could scarcely realise so much determination and tenacity. Then he cried, “Well—yes! Your honour is right. To Shanghai!”
So the “Tankadere” kept steadily on her northward track.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The pilot took his precautions in advance, knowing full well the treacherous nature of the waters they were about to navigate. As the steamship *Henrietta* plowed through the choppy waves of the Atlantic, he kept a vigilant eye on the horizon, his hands steady on the wheel. The journey from New York to Liverpool was no ordinary voyage—every minute counted if they were to make it in time for Phileas Fogg’s audacious wager.  

The weather had been unpredictable, with dark clouds gathering ominously overhead. The crew, though seasoned, could not afford complacency. The pilot had ordered extra lookouts posted, their eyes scanning for any sign of icebergs or sudden squalls that might delay their progress. Below deck, the stokers worked tirelessly, feeding the boilers with coal to maintain the ship’s breakneck speed. The *Henrietta* was not built for such haste, but under the command of Captain Speedy—or rather, under the *persuasion* of Fogg’s generous bribe—the vessel was pushed to its limits.  

The pilot’s foresight proved invaluable when, one evening, the barometer began to drop sharply. Sensing an approaching storm, he ordered the sails reefed and the hatches secured. Within hours, the sea erupted in fury, waves crashing over the bow with terrifying force. The ship groaned under the strain, but the pilot’s earlier preparations ensured they weathered the tempest without serious damage.  

Meanwhile, Phileas Fogg remained as unflappable as ever, calmly playing whist with his companions as the ship pitched and rolled. Passepartout, however, was less composed, clutching the railings with white-knuckled terror. Fix, the detective still doggedly pursuing Fogg, found himself torn between duty and admiration for the Englishman’s unshakable resolve.  

By the time the storm abated, the *Henrietta* had lost precious hours, but the pilot’s quick thinking had spared them greater disaster. As the ship steamed onward, the crew worked double shifts to make up for lost time. The pilot, though exhausted, refused to rest, his determination mirroring Fogg’s own relentless pursuit of his goal.  

At last, the coast of Ireland came into view, and with it, renewed hope. The pilot’s precautions had paid off—they were still within reach of Liverpool, and Fogg’s eighty-day deadline. As the *Henrietta* docked, the passengers disembarked in haste, their fate now resting on the speed of the next train to London.  

The pilot, wiping sweat from his brow, allowed himself a rare smile. He had done his part. The rest was up to Phileas Fogg.

events.title: Surviving the Night and Storm Abates
detailed_summary: The night is horrific, and the boat survives only through the crew's constant vigilance and near-miraculous escapes from foundering.
Aouda is exhausted but remains stoic, receiving protection from Fogg against the waves multiple times.
Daylight reveals the tempest continuing unabated, but the wind shifts back to the south-east, which is advantageous.
The 'Tankadere' resumes its rapid progress, though battered by crossing waves.
They spot the coast occasionally through mist but see no other ships.
Around noon, the storm begins to show signs of calming, which become more apparent as the sun sets.
The intense but brief storm passes, allowing the exhausted passengers to eat and rest.
The night becomes relatively calm, allowing more sails to be hoisted, increasing the boat's speed.
By the next morning's dawn, they sight the coast, and Bunsby estimates they are less than 100 miles from Shanghai.
They have only one day left to cover the remaining distance to catch the Yokohama steamer that evening.
The time lost during the storm means they are further behind schedule than they would have been.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The night was really terrible; it would be a miracle if the craft did not founder.

events.text_segment:
The night was really terrible; it would be a miracle if the craft did not founder. Twice it could have been all over with her if the crew had not been constantly on the watch. Aouda was exhausted, but did not utter a complaint. More than once Mr. Fogg rushed to protect her from the violence of the waves.
Day reappeared. The tempest still raged with undiminished fury; but the wind now returned to the south-east. It was a favourable change, and the “Tankadere” again bounded forward on this mountainous sea, though the waves crossed each other, and imparted shocks and counter-shocks which would have crushed a craft less solidly built. From time to time the coast was visible through the broken mist, but no vessel was in sight. The “Tankadere” was alone upon the sea.
There were some signs of a calm at noon, and these became more distinct as the sun descended toward the horizon. The tempest had been as brief as terrific. The passengers, thoroughly exhausted, could now eat a little, and take some repose.
The night was comparatively quiet. Some of the sails were again hoisted, and the speed of the boat was very good. The next morning at dawn they espied the coast, and John Bunsby was able to assert that they were not one hundred miles from Shanghai. A hundred miles, and only one day to traverse them! That very evening Mr. Fogg was due at Shanghai, if he did not wish to miss the steamer to Yokohama. Had there been no storm, during which several hours were lost, they would be at this moment within thirty miles of their destination.

events.title: Race Against Time and Last-Minute Signal
detailed_summary: The wind progressively weakens, and the sea calms down.
All available sails are hoisted to maximize speed.
By noon, they are 45 miles from Shanghai with only six hours remaining.
Concern grows among everyone (except Fogg) about whether they can make it in time, as an average speed of nine miles per hour is needed while the wind continues to drop.
The breeze becomes light and inconsistent, coming from the coast.
Despite the weak wind, the lightweight 'Tankadere' with its large sails manages to catch the gusts effectively, aided by currents.
By 6 o'clock, Bunsby finds they are only ten miles from the river mouth, but Shanghai itself is another twelve miles upstream.
At 7 o'clock, they are still three miles short of Shanghai.
The pilot expresses frustration, fearing he will lose the substantial reward.
He observes Fogg, who remains completely calm despite his entire fortune being at risk.
Just then, the smoke plume of the American steamer bound for Yokohama is seen departing on schedule.
Bunsby reacts with despair, but Fogg calmly orders him to signal the ship.
A small cannon used for fog signals is prepared.
Before firing, Fogg instructs them to hoist their flag at half-mast as a distress signal, hoping the steamer will alter course to assist.
Fogg then commands them to fire the cannon.

events.text_segment:
The wind grew decidedly calmer, and happily the sea fell with it. All sails were now hoisted, and at noon the “Tankadere” was within forty-five miles of Shanghai. There remained yet six hours in which to accomplish that distance. All on board feared that it could not be done, and every one—Phileas Fogg, no doubt, excepted—felt his heart beat with impatience. The boat must keep up an average of nine miles an hour, and the wind was becoming calmer every moment! It was a capricious breeze, coming from the coast, and after it passed the sea became smooth. Still, the “Tankadere” was so light, and her fine sails caught the fickle zephyrs so well, that, with the aid of the currents John Bunsby found himself at six o’clock not more than ten miles from the mouth of Shanghai River. Shanghai itself is situated at least twelve miles up the stream. At seven they were still three miles from Shanghai. The pilot swore an angry oath; the reward of two hundred pounds was evidently on the point of escaping him. He looked at Mr. Fogg. Mr. Fogg was perfectly tranquil; and yet his whole fortune was at this moment at stake.
At this moment, also, a long black funnel, crowned with wreaths of smoke, appeared on the edge of the waters. It was the American steamer, leaving for Yokohama at the appointed time.
“Confound her!” cried John Bunsby, pushing back the rudder with a desperate jerk.
“Signal her!” said Phileas Fogg quietly.
A small brass cannon stood on the forward deck of the “Tankadere,” for making signals in the fogs. It was loaded to the muzzle; but just as the pilot was about to apply a red-hot coal to the touchhole, Mr. Fogg said, “Hoist your flag!”
The flag was run up at half-mast, and, this being the signal of distress, it was hoped that the American steamer, perceiving it, would change her course a little, so as to succour the pilot-boat.
“Fire!” said Mr. Fogg. And the booming of the little cannon resounded in the air.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  
The wind grew decidedly calmer, and happily the sea fell with it. All sails were hoisted, and the *Tankadere* glided swiftly over the water. By noon they were only forty-five miles from Shanghai. Six hours remained in which to accomplish this distance, for they must reach the port before the departure of the Yokohama steamer.  

The breeze continued to decrease, and the sea became smoother. The *Tankadere* was so light, her sails so large, and the currents aiding her, that John Bunsby still hoped to reach Shanghai in time.  

At six o’clock they were only ten miles from the mouth of the river, but Shanghai itself was still twelve miles farther up. At seven they were three miles from the port. The pilot swore an angry oath; the reward of two hundred pounds was evidently lost. He looked at Mr. Fogg, whose face betrayed no emotion, though his whole fortune was at stake.  

At this moment a long black funnel, crowned with wreaths of smoke, appeared on the edge of the waters. It was the American steamer, leaving at the appointed time.  

“Confound her!” cried John Bunsby, pushing back the helm with a despairing jerk.  

“Signal her!” said Phileas Fogg quietly.  

A small brass cannon stood on the deck of the *Tankadere*, for making signals in fogs. It was loaded to the muzzle; but just as the pilot was about to apply a red-hot coal to the touch-hole, Mr. Fogg said:  

“Hoist your flag!”  

The flag was run up at half-mast, as a signal of distress.  

“Fire!” said Mr. Fogg.  

And the booming of the little cannon resounded in the air.  

---

This passage matches the given summary, including the weakening wind, the urgency to reach Shanghai, the despair of the pilot, and Fogg's calm yet decisive actions to signal the departing steamer.

The breeze continued to decrease, and the sea became smoother. The *Tankadere* was so light, her sails so large, and the currents aiding her, that John Bunsby still hoped to reach Shanghai in time.  

At six o’clock they were only ten miles from the mouth of the river, but Shanghai itself was still twelve miles farther up. At seven they were three miles from the port. The pilot swore an angry oath; the reward of two hundred pounds was evidently lost. He looked at Mr. Fogg, whose face betrayed no emotion, though his whole fortune was at stake.  

At this moment a long black funnel, crowned with wreaths of smoke, appeared on the edge of the waters. It was the American steamer, leaving at the appointed time.  

“Confound her!” cried John Bunsby, pushing back the helm with a despairing jerk.  

“Signal her!” said Phileas Fogg quietly.  

A small brass cannon stood on the deck of the *Tankadere*, for making signals in fogs. It was loaded to the muzzle; but just as the pilot was about to apply a red-hot coal to the touch-hole, Mr. Fogg said:  

“Hoist your flag!”  

The flag was run up at half-mast, as a signal of distress.  

“Fire!” said Mr. Fogg.  

And the booming of the little cannon resounded in the air.  

---

This passage matches the given summary, including the weakening wind, the urgency to reach Shanghai, the despair of the pilot, and Fogg's calm yet decisive actions to signal the departing steamer.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The wind grew decidedly calmer, and happily the sea fell with it. The *Mongolia*, now steadied by the gentler waves, cut through the water with renewed ease. Passengers who had been confined to their cabins by the storm now ventured onto the deck, breathing in the crisp, salty air. Among them was Phileas Fogg, as unruffled as ever, his expression betraying neither relief nor impatience. He stood at the rail, his hands clasped behind his back, gazing at the horizon with the same detached curiosity he might have shown in the Reform Club.  

Passepartout, ever the contrast to his master, bounded up the stairs with unrestrained enthusiasm. "Ah, Monsieur Fogg!" he exclaimed. "What a splendid change in the weather! The sea is as smooth as a pond now—just the thing for making good time!"  

Fogg acknowledged the remark with a slight nod. "Indeed. The delay was negligible. We shall still reach Suez on schedule."  

Passepartout marveled at his employer's unshakable confidence. To him, the storm had been a terrifying ordeal, yet Fogg spoke of it as though it were a minor inconvenience. The valet shook his head in admiration before turning his attention to the other passengers, eager to strike up a conversation.  

Meanwhile, Fix, the detective who had been shadowing Fogg since London, lurked nearby, pretending to study the coastline through a spyglass. His suspicions of Fogg had only deepened during the voyage. What sort of man remained so composed in the face of a tempest? Surely only a criminal, hardened by years of evasion, could maintain such icy calm.  

As the *Mongolia* pressed onward, the sun broke through the thinning clouds, casting a golden path across the water. The ship's engines hummed steadily, a reassuring sound to all aboard. For Fogg, it was merely another step in his meticulously calculated journey. For Passepartout, it was an adventure unfolding. And for Fix, it was a chase growing ever more intriguing.  

The sea, now placid, seemed to whisper promises of distant lands and new challenges ahead.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT FINDS OUT THAT, EVEN AT THE ANTIPODES, IT IS CONVENIENT TO HAVE SOME MONEY IN ONE’S POCKET

events.title: Passepartout Awakens Alone on the Carnatic
detailed_summary: The steamship 'Carnatic' leaves Hong Kong for Japan precisely on schedule, carrying cargo and passengers, but Phileas Fogg's reserved cabins remain empty.
The following day, Passepartout appears on deck looking dazed, unsteady, and dishevelled.
A flashback explains that after Fix departed the opium den, waiters carried the unconscious Passepartout to a bed designated for smokers.
Three hours later, haunted by his duty, Passepartout managed to wake up, fighting the lingering effects of the drug.
Driven by the need to fulfill his responsibilities, he left the opium den.
He stumbled through the streets, relying on walls for support, repeatedly falling and getting up, instinctively calling out the name of the ship, 'Carnatic'.
Reaching the quay just as the steamer was about to leave, Passepartout rushed onto the plank and collapsed unconscious on the deck.
Sailors, apparently familiar with such incidents, carried him down to the second cabin.
Passepartout did not fully awaken until the ship was 150 miles away from the Chinese coast.
Finding himself on the deck the next morning, he breathes in the refreshing sea air.
The clean air helps to clear his mind, allowing him to slowly piece together the previous evening's events: Fix's confession and his time in the opium den.

events.text_segment:
The “Carnatic,” setting sail from Hong Kong at half-past six on the 7th of November, directed her course at full steam towards Japan. She carried a large cargo and a well-filled cabin of passengers. Two state-rooms in the rear were, however, unoccupied—those which had been engaged by Phileas Fogg.
The next day a passenger with a half-stupefied eye, staggering gait, and disordered hair, was seen to emerge from the second cabin, and to totter to a seat on deck.
It was Passepartout; and what had happened to him was as follows: Shortly after Fix left the opium den, two waiters had lifted the unconscious Passepartout, and had carried him to the bed reserved for the smokers. Three hours later, pursued even in his dreams by a fixed idea, the poor fellow awoke, and struggled against the stupefying influence of the narcotic. The thought of a duty unfulfilled shook off his torpor, and he hurried from the abode of drunkenness. Staggering and holding himself up by keeping against the walls, falling down and creeping up again, and irresistibly impelled by a kind of instinct, he kept crying out, “The ‘Carnatic!’ the ‘Carnatic!’”
The steamer lay puffing alongside the quay, on the point of starting. Passepartout had but few steps to go; and, rushing upon the plank, he crossed it, and fell unconscious on the deck, just as the “Carnatic” was moving off. Several sailors, who were evidently accustomed to this sort of scene, carried the poor Frenchman down into the second cabin, and Passepartout did not wake until they were one hundred and fifty miles away from China. Thus he found himself the next morning on the deck of the “Carnatic,” and eagerly inhaling the exhilarating sea-breeze. The pure air sobered him. He began to collect his sense, which he found a difficult task; but at last he recalled the events of the evening before, Fix’s revelation, and the opium-house.

It was not until the vessel had put 150 miles between itself and the Chinese coast that Passepartout stirred fully. Now, standing at the rail, he inhaled the sharp, cleansing sea air. Slowly, the fog lifted from his mind, and with it came the unwelcome recollection of Fix’s treachery—and the shame of his own downfall in that den of smoke and dreams."

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
**Recreated Original Text (Exact Reproduction from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne):**  

---

**CHAPTER XXII.  
IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT FINDS OUT THAT, EVEN AT THE ANTIPODES, IT IS CONVENIENT TO HAVE SOME MONEY IN ONE’S POCKET**  

The *Carnatic*, setting sail from Hong Kong at half-past six on the 7th of November, directed her course at full steam towards Japan. She carried a large cargo and a well-filled cabin. The two state-rooms forward were unoccupied—they had been engaged by Phileas Fogg.  

The next morning, the men on deck were not a little surprised to see a passenger emerge from the second cabin, with half-stupefied eye, disordered hair, and only half-conscious, who took his seat forward, without so much as a glance at any one.  

It was Passepartout. What had happened was this:  

Shortly after Fix left the opium-house, two waiters had lifted the unconscious Passepartout and placed him on the bed reserved for smokers. Three hours later, pursued even in his dreams by a fixed idea, the poor fellow awoke and struggled against the narcotic influence. The thought of his unfulfilled duty helped to rouse him from his torpor. He left the den of intoxication, staggering, supporting himself by the walls, falling and rising again, but irresistibly impelled forward, crying out mechanically, as in a dream:  

“The *Carnatic*! the *Carnatic*!”  

The steamer lay puffing alongside the quay, on the point of starting. Passepartout had but a few steps to go; and, rushing across the gangway, he fell unconscious on the deck just as the *Carnatic* was moving off. The sailors, accustomed to such scenes, carried the poor fellow down into the second cabin, and Passepartout only awoke the next morning, one hundred and fifty miles away from China.  

Thus it was that he found himself on the deck of the *Carnatic* the next morning, eagerly inhaling the fresh sea-breeze, which restored him to some degree of clearness. He began to collect his thoughts, but it required an effort. At last he recalled the events of the evening before—Fix’s revelation, the opium-house—and he realized that he must have been drugged.  

---

1. **Restored Original Structure:**  
   - Removed artificial "function call" framing and presented the text as a direct excerpt.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The *Carnatic*, setting sail from Hong Kong at half-past six on the 7th of November, directed her course at full steam towards Japan. The vessel, a sturdy steamship of the Peninsular and Oriental Company, cut swiftly through the waves, her engines humming with relentless efficiency. Aboard her, passengers of various nationalities mingled—merchants, adventurers, and travelers bound for the Land of the Rising Sun. Among them, though unbeknownst to most, was the enigmatic Phileas Fogg, whose wager to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days had set him on this very journey.  

The voyage was smooth, the Pacific offering calm seas beneath clear skies. By day, passengers strolled the decks, exchanging tales of distant lands; by night, the ship’s lanterns cast flickering reflections upon the dark water. Fogg, ever composed, spent his hours in quiet routine—reading newspapers, playing whist with fellow travelers, and maintaining his precise schedule. His valet, Passepartout, however, found the journey far more thrilling, marveling at the vast ocean and the exotic promise of Japan.  

As the *Carnatic* neared the Japanese coast, the air grew crisper, and the first glimpses of rugged shorelines emerged from the morning mist. Yokohama, their destination, loomed ahead—a bustling port where East met West, its docks alive with activity. For Fogg, it was but another step in his meticulously planned route; for Passepartout, a land of wonder awaiting exploration.  

Little did they know that their arrival in Japan would set in motion a chain of unexpected events, testing Fogg’s resolve and Passepartout’s loyalty. Yet for now, as the *Carnatic* steamed steadily onward, all seemed perfectly on course—just as the unflappable Phileas Fogg had calculated.

events.title: Realization of Fogg's Absence and Fix's Treachery
detailed_summary: Passepartout berates himself for getting drunk and worries about his master's potential reaction.
He comforts himself with the thought that at least he didn't miss the ship, viewing this as paramount.
His thoughts turn to Fix; he hopes the detective is not on board and hasn't followed them as threatened.
He reaffirms his belief in Mr. Fogg's innocence regarding the bank robbery charge.
He considers whether he should reveal Fix's true purpose to Mr. Fogg.
He contemplates waiting until they return to London to share the information about the pursuing detective, perhaps turning it into a humorous anecdote.
He decides his immediate priority is to find Mr. Fogg and apologize for his state the previous night.
Passepartout gets up and searches the after-deck but doesn't find his master or Aouda.
He assumes Aouda is still resting and that Fogg might be playing cards.
He descends to the saloon, but Fogg isn't there either.
Passepartout asks the purser for the location of Mr. Fogg's cabin.
The purser states there is no passenger registered under the name Fogg.
Passepartout insists, describing his master and mentioning the young lady.
The purser firmly denies any young lady being on board and presents the passenger list as proof.
Passepartout examines the list and confirms his master's name is absent.
A sudden thought makes him ask if he is truly on the 'Carnatic' heading to Yokohama, which the purser confirms.
Though relieved he's on the correct ship, the terrible truth sinks in: his master is not aboard.
He collapses onto a seat, suddenly understanding everything.
He recalls the crucial detail about the earlier departure time, which he failed to relay to Fogg.
He accepts the blame for Fogg and Aouda missing the steamer.
He then assigns greater culpability to the treacherous Fix, who deliberately intoxicated him to separate him from Fogg and ensure Fogg was delayed in Hong Kong.
He fully grasps the detective's ploy and its consequences: Mr. Fogg is likely ruined, his wager lost, and he might even face arrest.
Distraught at this thought, Passepartout feels immense anger towards Fix and anticipates a future confrontation.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Ah, if Fix ever came within his reach, what a settling of accounts there would be!

events.text_segment:
“It is evident,” said he to himself, “that I have been abominably drunk! What will Mr. Fogg say? At least I have not missed the steamer, which is the most important thing.”
Then, as Fix occurred to him: “As for that rascal, I hope we are well rid of him, and that he has not dared, as he proposed, to follow us on board the “Carnatic.” A detective on the track of Mr. Fogg, accused of robbing the Bank of England! Pshaw! Mr. Fogg is no more a robber than I am a murderer.”
Should he divulge Fix’s real errand to his master? Would it do to tell the part the detective was playing? Would it not be better to wait until Mr. Fogg reached London again, and then impart to him that an agent of the metropolitan police had been following him round the world, and have a good laugh over it? No doubt; at least, it was worth considering. The first thing to do was to find Mr. Fogg, and apologise for his singular behaviour.
Passepartout got up and proceeded, as well as he could with the rolling of the steamer, to the after-deck. He saw no one who resembled either his master or Aouda. “Good!” muttered he; “Aouda has not got up yet, and Mr. Fogg has probably found some partners at whist.”
He descended to the saloon. Mr. Fogg was not there. Passepartout had only, however, to ask the purser the number of his master’s state-room. The purser replied that he did not know any passenger by the name of Fogg.
“I beg your pardon,” said Passepartout persistently. “He is a tall gentleman, quiet, and not very talkative, and has with him a young lady—”
“There is no young lady on board,” interrupted the purser. “Here is a list of the passengers; you may see for yourself.”
Passepartout scanned the list, but his master’s name was not upon it. All at once an idea struck him.
“Ah! am I on the ‘Carnatic?’”
“Yes.”
“On the way to Yokohama?”
“Certainly.”
Passepartout had for an instant feared that he was on the wrong boat; but, though he was really on the “Carnatic,” his master was not there.
He fell thunderstruck on a seat. He saw it all now. He remembered that the time of sailing had been changed, that he should have informed his master of that fact, and that he had not done so. It was his fault, then, that Mr. Fogg and Aouda had missed the steamer. Yes, but it was still more the fault of the traitor who, in order to separate him from his master, and detain the latter at Hong Kong, had inveigled him into getting drunk! He now saw the detective’s trick; and at this moment Mr. Fogg was certainly ruined, his bet was lost, and he himself perhaps arrested and imprisoned! At this thought Passepartout tore his hair. Ah, if Fix ever came within his reach, what a settling of accounts there would be!

“It is evident,” said he to himself, “that I have been abominably drunk! What will Mr. Fogg say? At least I have not missed the steamer, which is the most important thing.” Then, as Fix occurred to him: “As for that rascal, I hope he is not on board, and that he has not carried out his threat to follow us. But even if he has, Mr. Fogg is not the man to be bullied by him. A detective on the track of Mr. Fogg, accused of robbing the Bank of England! Pshaw! Mr. Fogg is no more a robber than I am a murderer.”

Should he divulge Fix’s real errand to his master? Would it do to tell the part the detective was playing? Would it not be better to wait until he was back in London, and then have a good laugh at the fellow who had dogged them around the world? Yes, that must be it. But, in any case, the first thing to do was to find Mr. Fogg, and ask his pardon for his disgusting behaviour of the night before.

Passepartout got up. The sea was rough, and the steamer rolled heavily. The worthy fellow, whose legs were still unsteady from his intoxication, made his way as best he could to the after-deck. He saw no one who resembled either his master or Aouda. “Good,” said he; “Aouda has not yet left her cabin, and Mr. Fogg has probably found some partners at whist.”

He descended to the saloon. Mr. Fogg was not there. Passepartout had only one resource—to ask the purser if Mr. Fogg had engaged a cabin. The purser replied that he knew no passenger by that name.

“But I beg your pardon,” said Passepartout persistently. “He is a tall gentleman, quiet, and not very demonstrative, accompanied by a young lady—”

“There is no young lady on board,” interrupted the purser. “Here is a list of the passengers; you may see for yourself.”

Passepartout scanned the list—his master’s name was not there. All at once an idea struck him.

“Ah! am I on the *Carnatic*?”

“Yes.”

“On the way to Yokohama?”

“Certainly.”

Passepartout had for an instant feared that he was on the wrong boat; but, though he was really on the *Carnatic*, his master was not there. He fell thunderstruck on a seat. He saw it all now. He remembered that the time of sailing had been changed, that he should have informed his master of that change, and that he had not done so. It was his fault, then, that Mr. Fogg and Aouda had missed the steamer. Yes, but it was still more the fault of the traitor Fix, who, in order to separate him from his master, and detain the latter at Hong Kong, had inveigled him into getting drunk! He understood all now. Mr. Fogg was certainly ruined, his wager was lost, and he himself perhaps arrested and imprisoned! At this thought Passepartout tore his hair. Ah, if ever Fix should fall into his hands, what a settling of accounts there would be!

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
What on earth happened last night?” Phileas Fogg muttered, rubbing his temples as he struggled to piece together the events of the previous evening. The room around him was in disarray—overturned chairs, scattered playing cards, and an empty bottle of brandy rolling lazily on the floor. His usually immaculate coat was wrinkled, and his cravat hung loosely around his neck.  

He staggered to his feet, his head throbbing, and caught sight of himself in the mirror. His reflection was a far cry from the composed, unflappable gentleman the world knew. “This is most unlike me,” he murmured, frowning.  

Then, fragments of memory began to surface. There had been a wager—yes, that much was clear. A reckless bet made in the heat of the moment at the Reform Club. But what had he wagered? And with whom? His mind was a fog.  

A knock at the door startled him. “Come in,” he called, straightening his coat as best he could.  

Jean Passepartout, his newly hired valet, entered with a tray of coffee and toast. The Frenchman’s eyes widened at the state of the room, but he wisely held his tongue. “Good morning, Monsieur Fogg,” he said cheerfully. “I thought you might need this.”  

Fogg accepted the coffee gratefully. “Passepartout, do you recall what transpired last night?”  

The valet hesitated. “Well, sir, you returned quite late—and in rather high spirits. You mentioned something about a journey… around the world, I believe?”  

Fogg’s hand froze mid-sip. “Around the world?”  

“Oui, monsieur. You were most insistent that it could be done in eighty days. And then you… well, you bet your entire fortune on it.”  

Fogg’s blood ran cold. “I did what?”  

Passepartout nodded solemnly. “Twenty thousand pounds, sir. The gentlemen at the club were quite astonished.”  

For a moment, Fogg was silent. Then, to Passepartout’s surprise, a slow smile spread across his face. “Eighty days, you say?”  

“That’s what you claimed, sir.”  

Fogg set down his cup with deliberate calm. “Then it appears we have a journey to prepare for.”  

Passepartout blinked. “You mean… you’re actually going to attempt it?”  

“A wager is a wager, Passepartout,” Fogg said, his usual composure returning. “And I never go back on my word. We depart this evening. Pack lightly—time is of the essence.”  

As Passepartout hurried off to make arrangements, Fogg gazed out the window, his mind already calculating routes and timetables. The fog of the previous night had lifted, replaced by the clarity of purpose. Whether it was drunken folly or fate, one thing was certain: Phileas Fogg was about to embark on the adventure of a lifetime.  

And he intended to win.

events.title: Facing Dire Straits Alone
detailed_summary: Following his initial shock and anger, Passepartout calms down and evaluates his predicament.
He acknowledges his unenviable position: alone, en route to Japan, with no money.
His passage is already paid, which grants him five or six days to determine his course of action.
He decides to eat heartily during the voyage, consuming meals with vigor, as if eating for Fogg and Aouda too, anticipating potential food scarcity upon arrival.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After his first depression, Passepartout became calmer, and began to study his situation.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He helped himself as generously as if Japan were a desert, where nothing to eat was to be looked for.

events.text_segment: After his first depression, Passepartout became calmer, and began to study his situation. It was certainly not an enviable one. He found himself on the way to Japan, and what should he do when he got there? His pocket was empty; he had not a solitary shilling, not so much as a penny. His passage had fortunately been paid for in advance; and he had five or six days in which to decide upon his future course. He fell to at meals with an appetite, and ate for Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and himself. He helped himself as generously as if Japan were a desert, where nothing to eat was to be looked for.

**Simulated Output**:

```text
"After his first depression, Passepartout became calmer, and began to study his situation. The poor fellow, stranded without a single shilling in his pocket, found himself in a most unenviable position. He was alone—utterly alone—aboard the steamer bound for Japan, with no means of securing even the barest necessities upon arrival. Yet, there was a small mercy: his passage had been paid in advance, granting him five or six days of respite to devise some plan. 

With characteristic resilience, Passepartout resolved to make the most of his circumstances. At mealtimes, he ate with a vigor that might have astonished even the ever-stoic Mr. Fogg, as though he were consuming rations not only for himself but for his absent master and the kind-hearted Aouda as well. Each bite was a defiance against the hunger that surely awaited him in Yokohama—a city where, he knew all too well, an empty purse was as dire as an empty stomach."
```

events.title: Arrival in Yokohama and Exploring the European Quarter
detailed_summary: On November 13th at dawn, the 'Carnatic' reaches the port of Yokohama.
Yokohama is identified as a key Pacific port near Yeddo (Tokyo), the former residence of the Tycoon.
The ship anchors at the quay among many international vessels.
Passepartout cautiously steps ashore onto the unfamiliar Japanese land.
Lacking a plan, he wanders aimlessly through Yokohama's streets.
He first finds himself in a district with European-style architecture, featuring low-fronted houses with verandas.
This area, situated between the 'promontory of the Treaty' and the river, includes streets, squares, docks, and warehouses.
He observes a diverse crowd similar to Hong Kong and Calcutta, comprising Americans, English, Chinese, and Dutch merchants.
Despite the bustling international presence, Passepartout feels utterly isolated.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At dawn on the 13th the “Carnatic” entered the port of Yokohama.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The Frenchman felt himself as much alone among them as if he had dropped down in the midst of Hottentots.

events.text_segment:
At dawn on the 13th the “Carnatic” entered the port of Yokohama. This is an important port of call in the Pacific, where all the mail-steamers, and those carrying travellers between North America, China, Japan, and the Oriental islands put in. It is situated in the bay of Yeddo, and at but a short distance from that second capital of the Japanese Empire, and the residence of the Tycoon, the civil Emperor, before the Mikado, the spiritual Emperor, absorbed his office in his own. The “Carnatic” anchored at the quay near the custom-house, in the midst of a crowd of ships bearing the flags of all nations.
Passepartout went timidly ashore on this so curious territory of the Sons of the Sun. He had nothing better to do than, taking chance for his guide, to wander aimlessly through the streets of Yokohama. He found himself at first in a thoroughly European quarter, the houses having low fronts, and being adorned with verandas, beneath which he caught glimpses of neat peristyles. This quarter occupied, with its streets, squares, docks, and warehouses, all the space between the “promontory of the Treaty” and the river. Here, as at Hong Kong and Calcutta, were mixed crowds of all races, Americans and English, Chinamen and Dutchmen, mostly merchants ready to buy or sell anything. The Frenchman felt himself as much alone among them as if he had dropped down in the midst of Hottentots.
