LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
"Who knows?" replied Mr. Fogg, returning to the car as coolly as usual. His unshakable composure never failed to astonish those around him, even in the most unpredictable of circumstances. Passepartout, still catching his breath from the recent excitement, could only shake his head in admiration.  

The train had barely resumed its journey when the landscape outside began to shift once more—rolling plains giving way to dense forests, then to bustling towns where vendors hawked their wares at every stop. Yet Fogg remained indifferent to the changing scenery, his attention fixed instead on his pocket watch, as if time itself were the only thing of consequence.  

Passepartout, ever the optimist, leaned forward. "Monsieur, surely fortune favors the bold! We’ve overcome worse obstacles before."  

Fogg merely nodded, his expression inscrutable. "Fortune is irrelevant. Calculation is what matters."  

The other passengers exchanged glances, some amused, others bewildered by the Englishman’s unflappable demeanor. But Fogg paid them no mind. His mind was already several steps ahead, calculating distances, schedules, and contingencies.  

As the train rattled onward, the sun dipped below the horizon, casting long shadows across the compartment. Passepartout, unable to resist the lure of adventure, peered out the window, wondering what new challenges lay ahead. Meanwhile, Fogg closed his eyes briefly—not in weariness, but in quiet determination.  

For Phileas Fogg, the journey was not about the sights or the surprises. It was about proving that with precision and resolve, even the impossible could be conquered. And so, as the wheels of the train hummed against the tracks, the unspoken truth lingered in the air: the real test had only just begun.

events.title: Duel Arrangements Abruptly Halted by Sioux Attack
detailed_summary: Fogg, Proctor, their seconds, and the conductor moved through the train to the last car.
The conductor politely requested the dozen passengers in the rear car to vacate it for the duel, which they did promptly.
The car, about fifty feet long, was deemed suitable, allowing the adversaries space to advance and fire.
Fogg and Proctor, each holding two six-barrelled revolvers, entered the car.
The seconds remained outside and shut the doors.
The plan was for firing to begin at the first locomotive whistle, with the outcome assessed after two minutes.
The simplicity of the arrangement heightened the tension for Fix and Passepartout waiting outside.
As they listened for the whistle, sudden savage cries and gunfire erupted along the train, clearly not from the duellists' car.
Cries of terror arose from within the train cars.
Fogg and Proctor, revolvers ready, quickly left the designated duel car and rushed towards the commotion.
They realized the train was under attack by a band of Sioux Indians.
The narrative notes that such attacks were not uncommon, with the Sioux adept at boarding moving trains.

events.text_segment:
The two combatants, their seconds, and the conductor passed through the cars to the rear of the train. The last car was only occupied by a dozen passengers, whom the conductor politely asked if they would not be so kind as to leave it vacant for a few moments, as two gentlemen had an affair of honour to settle. The passengers granted the request with alacrity, and straightway disappeared on the platform.
The car, which was some fifty feet long, was very convenient for their purpose. The adversaries might march on each other in the aisle, and fire at their ease. Never was duel more easily arranged. Mr. Fogg and Colonel Proctor, each provided with two six-barrelled revolvers, entered the car. The seconds, remaining outside, shut them in. They were to begin firing at the first whistle of the locomotive. After an interval of two minutes, what remained of the two gentlemen would be taken from the car.
Nothing could be more simple. Indeed, it was all so simple that Fix and Passepartout felt their hearts beating as if they would crack. They were listening for the whistle agreed upon, when suddenly savage cries resounded in the air, accompanied by reports which certainly did not issue from the car where the duellists were. The reports continued in front and the whole length of the train. Cries of terror proceeded from the interior of the cars.
Colonel Proctor and Mr. Fogg, revolvers in hand, hastily quitted their prison, and rushed forward where the noise was most clamorous. They then perceived that the train was attacked by a band of Sioux.
This was not the first attempt of these daring Indians, for more than once they had waylaid trains on the road. A hundred of them had, according to their habit, jumped upon the steps without stopping the train, with the ease of a clown mounting a horse at full gallop.

The terms were simple: at the first whistle of the locomotive, the duel would commence, and after two minutes, the seconds would return to assess the grim results.  

```text
Fix wiped his brow; Passepartout clenched his fists. The unnatural quiet stretched between them, broken only by the rhythmic clatter of the train. Then—suddenly—savage war cries and gunfire erupted, not from the duel car, but from further ahead. Screams of terror rippled through the other passengers.  

Inside the rear car, Fogg and Proctor exchanged a glance. Revolvers still in hand, they abandoned their quarrel and rushed toward the commotion. The train was under attack—a band of Sioux warriors, swift as shadows, had overtaken the cars. Such assaults, the narrative noted, were not unheard of on these western rails, where the Sioux had mastered the perilous art of boarding moving trains."
```

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The two combatants, their seconds, and the conductor passed through the cars to the rear of the train. The early morning light cast long shadows across the tracks as the group stepped onto the open platform at the end of the last carriage. The wind whipped around them, carrying the rhythmic clatter of the wheels beneath their feet.  

Colonel Proctor, his face set in a cold, determined expression, removed his coat and rolled up his sleeves. His second, a burly man with a thick mustache, handed him a gleaming pistol. Phileas Fogg, ever composed, accepted his weapon with the same unflappable calm that had carried him across continents. Passepartout, his heart pounding, could barely contain his anxiety as he stood beside his master.  

The conductor, a nervous man unused to such affairs, cleared his throat. "Gentlemen," he began, "the rules are simple. You will stand back-to-back, take ten paces at my count, then turn and fire."  

Proctor gave a curt nod, while Fogg merely adjusted his cufflinks as if preparing for a routine business meeting. The two men took their positions, their backs pressed together. The conductor's voice trembled slightly as he began the count.  

"One... two... three..."  

With each step, the tension thickened. Passepartout clenched his fists, silently praying for a miracle. Just as the conductor reached "ten," a deafening war cry erupted from the nearby hills. A band of Sioux warriors, their faces painted for battle, charged toward the train on horseback, brandishing rifles and tomahawks.  

The duel was forgotten in an instant. Proctor and Fogg spun around, their pistols now aimed at the new threat. The conductor shouted for everyone to take cover as the first shots rang out. The train lurched forward, the engineer having realized the danger, but the warriors were already upon them.  

In the chaos, Fogg's coolheadedness prevailed. "To the front of the train!" he commanded. The group fought their way back through the cars, the duel postponed by fate itself. The adventure was far from over.

events.title: Desperate Defense and Passepartout's Gamble
detailed_summary: The armed Sioux exchanged fire with the passengers, most of whom were also armed.
Indians attacked the engine crew, stunning the engineer and stoker.
A Sioux chief tried to stop the train but, unfamiliar with the controls, accidentally opened the steam valve fully, causing the locomotive to accelerate violently.
Simultaneously, Sioux fighters swarmed the cars, climbing over roofs, forcing doors, and engaging in close combat with passengers.
They looted the baggage car, throwing luggage off the speeding train.
Amidst continuous cries and gunfire, the travelers fought back bravely.
Some cars were barricaded, becoming mobile forts enduring the siege at high speed.
Aouda displayed remarkable courage, using a revolver effectively against attackers appearing at broken windows.
The battle resulted in casualties on both sides: twenty Sioux fell dead, some crushed by the wheels, while several passengers lay wounded.
After ten minutes, it became clear the Sioux would win if the train wasn't stopped soon.
Fort Kearney station and its garrison were close, but if passed, the train would be entirely vulnerable.
The conductor, fighting near Fogg, was shot and fell, warning they had only five minutes to stop the train or be lost.
Fogg prepared to take action himself.
Passepartout intervened, declaring he would go.
Before Fogg could stop him, Passepartout slipped out a door unnoticed by the attackers and got under the train.
Leveraging his past acrobatic skills, he navigated the dangerous space beneath the cars amidst the ongoing firefight, moving towards the engine.
Reaching the front, hanging between the tender and the baggage car, he managed to loosen the safety chains.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There, suspended by one hand between the baggage-car and the tender, with the other he loosened the safety chains; but, owing to the traction, he would never have succeeded in unscrewing the yoking-bar, had not a violent concussion jolted this bar out.

events.text_segment:
The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots.
The Indians had first mounted the engine, and half stunned the engineer and stoker with blows from their muskets. A Sioux chief, wishing to stop the train, but not knowing how to work the regulator, had opened wide instead of closing the steam-valve, and the locomotive was plunging forward with terrific velocity.
The Sioux had at the same time invaded the cars, skipping like enraged monkeys over the roofs, thrusting open the doors, and fighting hand to hand with the passengers. Penetrating the baggage-car, they pillaged it, throwing the trunks out of the train. The cries and shots were constant. The travellers defended themselves bravely; some of the cars were barricaded, and sustained a siege, like moving forts, carried along at a speed of a hundred miles an hour.
Aouda behaved courageously from the first. She defended herself like a true heroine with a revolver, which she shot through the broken windows whenever a savage made his appearance. Twenty Sioux had fallen mortally wounded to the ground, and the wheels crushed those who fell upon the rails as if they had been worms. Several passengers, shot or stunned, lay on the seats.
It was necessary to put an end to the struggle, which had lasted for ten minutes, and which would result in the triumph of the Sioux if the train was not stopped. Fort Kearney station, where there was a garrison, was only two miles distant; but, that once passed, the Sioux would be masters of the train between Fort Kearney and the station beyond.
The conductor was fighting beside Mr. Fogg, when he was shot and fell. At the same moment he cried, “Unless the train is stopped in five minutes, we are lost!”
“It shall be stopped,” said Phileas Fogg, preparing to rush from the car.
“Stay, monsieur,” cried Passepartout; “I will go.”
Mr. Fogg had not time to stop the brave fellow, who, opening a door unperceived by the Indians, succeeded in slipping under the car; and while the struggle continued and the balls whizzed across each other over his head, he made use of his old acrobatic experience, and with amazing agility worked his way under the cars, holding on to the chains, aiding himself by the brakes and edges of the sashes, creeping from one car to another with marvellous skill, and thus gaining the forward end of the train.
There, suspended by one hand between the baggage-car and the tender, with the other he loosened the safety chains; but, owing to the traction, he would never have succeeded in unscrewing the yoking-bar, had not a violent concussion jolted this bar out.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne that corresponds to the provided metadata:

---

**text_segment**:  

*The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots. The Indians had first mounted the engine, and stunned the engineer and stoker with blows from their muskets. A Sioux chief, wishing to stop the train, but not knowing how to work the regulator, had opened wide instead of closing the steam-valve, and the locomotive was plunging forward with terrific velocity.  

Meanwhile the Sioux had invaded the cars, jumping like enraged monkeys upon the roofs, thrusting open the doors, and fighting hand to hand with the passengers. They pillaged the baggage-waggon, and were throwing the trunks and packages out upon the rails. The cries and shots were incessant.  

The travellers defended themselves bravely; some of the cars were barricaded, and sustained a siege, like moving forts, carried along at the rate of a hundred miles an hour.  

Aouda behaved courageously from the first. She defended herself like a true heroine with a revolver, which she fired through the broken windows whenever a savage made his appearance. Twenty Sioux, mortally wounded, fell upon the track, and the wheels crushed those who slipped upon the rails like so many worms. Several passengers, shot or stunned, lay on the seats.  

It was necessary to put an end to the struggle, which had lasted for ten minutes, and which would result in the triumph of the Sioux if the train was not stopped. Fort Kearney station, where there was a garrison, was only two miles distant; but, once past that station, the Sioux would be masters of the train between Fort Kearney and the next station.  

The conductor was fighting beside Mr. Fogg, when he was shot and fell. At the same moment he cried, "We are lost if the train is not stopped in five minutes!"  

"It shall be stopped," said Phileas Fogg, preparing to rush from the car.  

"Stay, monsieur," cried Passepartout. "I will go."  

Mr. Fogg had not time to stop the brave fellow, who, opening a door unperceived by the Indians, succeeded in slipping under the car; and while the struggle continued, and the balls whizzed across each other over his head, he made use of his old acrobatic experience, and with amazing agility worked his way under the cars, holding on to the chains, aiding himself by the brakes and edges of the sashes, creeping from one car to another with marvellous skill, and thus gaining the forward part of the train. There, suspended by one hand between the baggage-car and the tender, with the other he loosened the safety chains; but, owing to the traction, he would never have succeeded in unscrewing the coupling-bar, had not a violent concussion jolted this bar out. The train, now detached from the engine, remained a little behind, whilst the locomotive rushed forward with increased speed.*  

---  

This passage matches the chapter title, characters, and detailed summary provided. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots. The situation had escalated into a fierce battle atop the moving train, with bullets whizzing through the air and the deafening sound of gunfire drowning out all other noise. The Sioux warriors, mounted on their swift horses, rode alongside the train, attempting to board the cars and overpower the defenders. Their war cries echoed across the plains, striking fear into the hearts of those who had never faced such a relentless assault.  

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, took charge of the defense, directing the passengers to form a barricade with whatever they could find—luggage, crates, and even overturned seats. Passepartout, though unaccustomed to such violence, fought bravely, firing his revolver with surprising accuracy. His acrobatic skills proved useful as he dodged bullets and helped others take cover. Fix, the detective who had been trailing Fogg, found himself reluctantly fighting alongside the man he had been determined to arrest.  

The train’s engineer, realizing the danger, increased the locomotive’s speed in an attempt to outrun the attackers. But the Sioux were relentless, some even leaping onto the moving cars and engaging in hand-to-hand combat with the passengers. The struggle was desperate, and for a moment, it seemed the outnumbered travelers might be overwhelmed.  

Then, just as the battle reached its peak, a distant whistle pierced the chaos—another train was approaching from the opposite direction. The Sioux, caught between two speeding locomotives, hesitated. Sensing their advantage slipping away, they began to retreat, vanishing into the vast prairie as swiftly as they had appeared.  

The passengers, breathless and shaken, took stock of the damage. Though several had suffered minor injuries, none had been killed, thanks to their quick defense. The train, though riddled with bullet holes, continued its journey westward. Fogg, ever the man of few words, simply checked his watch and remarked that they had lost only twenty minutes.  

As the adrenaline faded, the travelers exchanged stories of their narrow escape. Passepartout, still clutching his revolver, marveled at how quickly their peaceful journey had turned into a life-or-death struggle. Fix, nursing a grazed arm, found himself grudgingly impressed by Fogg’s calm leadership.  

The incident served as a stark reminder of the dangers that lurked in the untamed American frontier. Yet for Phileas Fogg, it was merely another obstacle to be overcome in his relentless race against time. With the Sioux threat behind them, the train pressed on, carrying its passengers ever closer to their destinations—and Fogg one step nearer to winning his audacious wager.

events.title: Engine Detached, Train Saved, Hero Missing
detailed_summary: A sudden jolt dislodged the coupling bar, separating the engine from the train cars.
The locomotive sped off, while the detached cars continued moving forward due to momentum.
The brakes were applied, bringing the train cars to a halt less than a hundred feet from Kearney station.
Soldiers from the fort, alerted by the gunfire, approached rapidly.
Caught by surprise at the soldiers' arrival, the Sioux warriors fled before the train came to a complete stop.
As the passengers gathered on the station platform, a headcount revealed several missing individuals.
Among the missing was Passepartout, the courageous Frenchman whose actions had resulted in their rescue.

events.text_segment:
The train, now detached from the engine, remained a little behind, whilst the locomotive rushed forward with increased speed.
Carried on by the force already acquired, the train still moved for several minutes; but the brakes were worked and at last they stopped, less than a hundred feet from Kearney station.
The soldiers of the fort, attracted by the shots, hurried up; the Sioux had not expected them, and decamped in a body before the train entirely stopped.
But when the passengers counted each other on the station platform several were found missing; among others the courageous Frenchman, whose devotion had just saved them.

events.title: Aftermath of the Sioux Attack and Fogg's Resolve
detailed_summary: Three individuals, including Passepartout, were unaccounted for following the Sioux attack, their fate unknown.
Numerous passengers were wounded, with Colonel Proctor suffering a serious injury after fighting valiantly.
The injured were transported to the station for medical care.
Aouda remained unharmed, and Phileas Fogg, despite being in the center of the conflict, was unscathed. Fix had a minor arm wound.
Passepartout's absence deeply distressed Aouda.
Passengers exited the blood-stained train, witnessing gruesome remnants of the battle and observing the retreating Sioux in the distance.
Phileas Fogg stood silently, contemplating a significant choice.
Aouda observed him wordlessly, conveying her unspoken plea for Passepartout's rescue.
Fogg understood her concern regarding his imprisoned servant and the necessity of risking everything for him.
He firmly declared to Aouda his intention to find Passepartout, whether alive or deceased.
Aouda emotionally expressed her gratitude, clutching his hands.
Fogg emphasized the urgency, stating they must act immediately to find Passepartout alive.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Three passengers including Passepartout had disappeared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Living,” added Mr. Fogg, “if we do not lose a moment.”

events.text_segment:
Three passengers including Passepartout had disappeared. Had they been killed in the struggle? Were they taken prisoners by the Sioux? It was impossible to tell.
There were many wounded, but none mortally. Colonel Proctor was one of the most seriously hurt; he had fought bravely, and a ball had entered his groin. He was carried into the station with the other wounded passengers, to receive such attention as could be of avail.
Aouda was safe; and Phileas Fogg, who had been in the thickest of the fight, had not received a scratch. Fix was slightly wounded in the arm. But Passepartout was not to be found, and tears coursed down Aouda’s cheeks.
All the passengers had got out of the train, the wheels of which were stained with blood. From the tyres and spokes hung ragged pieces of flesh. As far as the eye could reach on the white plain behind, red trails were visible. The last Sioux were disappearing in the south, along the banks of Republican River.
Mr. Fogg, with folded arms, remained motionless. He had a serious decision to make. Aouda, standing near him, looked at him without speaking, and he understood her look. If his servant was a prisoner, ought he not to risk everything to rescue him from the Indians? “I will find him, living or dead,” said he quietly to Aouda.
“Ah, Mr.—Mr. Fogg!” cried she, clasping his hands and covering them with tears.
“Living,” added Mr. Fogg, “if we do not lose a moment.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Three passengers, including Passepartout, had mysteriously disappeared from the steamship *Mongolia* during its voyage from Suez to Bombay. The sudden absence of the trio sent shockwaves through the ship, leaving the crew and remaining passengers baffled.  

Captain Speedy, a gruff and no-nonsense seaman, was furious at the unexplained vanishing act. He suspected foul play, perhaps even mutiny, and ordered a thorough search of the vessel. However, no trace of the missing men could be found—no signs of struggle, no belongings left behind, nothing.  

Meanwhile, Phileas Fogg, ever the picture of calm indifference, seemed entirely unperturbed by his valet’s disappearance. When questioned, he merely remarked that Passepartout had likely wandered off on some impulsive adventure and would reappear in due time. His unshakable composure only deepened the mystery.  

Unbeknownst to the others, Passepartout had not vanished by accident. He had, in fact, been lured away by Fix, the cunning detective who was determined to arrest Fogg on suspicion of bank robbery. Fix had spun a convincing tale, tricking Passepartout into following him under false pretenses. The third missing passenger, an unfortunate bystander, had stumbled upon their scheme and was swiftly silenced.  

As the *Mongolia* steamed toward Bombay, the enigma of the missing men weighed heavily on the crew. Little did they know that Passepartout’s disappearance was merely the first twist in a far greater adventure—one that would test Fogg’s resolve and challenge the very limits of time itself.

events.title: Organizing the Rescue Mission
detailed_summary: Fogg's decision to rescue Passepartout meant sacrificing his journey and likely losing his wager due to the unavoidable delay.
Despite the personal cost, Fogg felt it was his duty and did not waver.
The commander of Fort Kearney was present with a hundred soldiers prepared to defend the station.
Fogg informed the captain about the three missing passengers, unsure if they were dead or captured.
He asked if the captain planned to pursue the Sioux.
The captain hesitated, citing the risk of the Sioux retreating far beyond reach and the need to protect the fort.
Fogg pressed the issue, emphasizing the importance of the three missing lives.
The captain questioned the wisdom of risking fifty soldiers to save three.
Fogg countered that while he couldn't dictate the captain's decision, he believed it was the right thing to do.
The captain asserted his authority, stating no one could tell him his duty.
Fogg coolly declared he would pursue the Sioux alone.
Fix, surprised, questioned Fogg's intention to go alone.
Fogg argued he couldn't abandon Passepartout, to whom everyone owed their lives.
Moved by Fogg's bravery, the captain changed his mind and called for thirty volunteers.
The entire company stepped forward, and the captain selected thirty men led by an old sergeant.
Fogg thanked the captain.
Fix asked to join the rescue party.
Fogg permitted him but requested, as a favor, that Fix stay with Aouda in case anything happened to him.
The detective turned pale at the thought of being separated from Fogg and leaving him to venture into the wilderness.
Fix observed Fogg closely and, despite his internal conflict and suspicions, felt compelled by Fogg's calm demeanor to agree.
He promised to stay.
Fogg briefly took Aouda's hand, entrusted his valuable carpet-bag to her, and departed with the sergeant and soldiers.
Before leaving, he offered the soldiers a $5,000 reward if the prisoners were saved.
The rescue party departed shortly after midday.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg, by this resolution, inevitably sacrificed himself; he pronounced his own doom.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was then a little past noon.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg, by this resolution, inevitably sacrificed himself; he pronounced his own doom. The delay of a single day would make him lose the steamer at New York, and his bet would be certainly lost. But as he thought, “It is my duty,” he did not hesitate.
The commanding officer of Fort Kearney was there. A hundred of his soldiers had placed themselves in a position to defend the station, should the Sioux attack it.
“Sir,” said Mr. Fogg to the captain, “three passengers have disappeared.”
“Dead?” asked the captain.
“Dead or prisoners; that is the uncertainty which must be solved. Do you propose to pursue the Sioux?”
“That’s a serious thing to do, sir,” returned the captain. “These Indians may retreat beyond the Arkansas, and I cannot leave the fort unprotected.”
“The lives of three men are in question, sir,” said Phileas Fogg.
“Doubtless; but can I risk the lives of fifty men to save three?”
“I don’t know whether you can, sir; but you ought to do so.”
“Nobody here,” returned the other, “has a right to teach me my duty.”
“Very well,” said Mr. Fogg, coldly. “I will go alone.”
“You, sir!” cried Fix, coming up; “you go alone in pursuit of the Indians?”
“Would you have me leave this poor fellow to perish—him to whom every one present owes his life? I shall go.”
“No, sir, you shall not go alone,” cried the captain, touched in spite of himself. “No! you are a brave man. Thirty volunteers!” he added, turning to the soldiers.
The whole company started forward at once. The captain had only to pick his men. Thirty were chosen, and an old sergeant placed at their head.
“Thanks, captain,” said Mr. Fogg.
“Will you let me go with you?” asked Fix.
“Do as you please, sir. But if you wish to do me a favour, you will remain with Aouda. In case anything should happen to me—”
A sudden pallor overspread the detective’s face. Separate himself from the man whom he had so persistently followed step by step! Leave him to wander about in this desert! Fix gazed attentively at Mr. Fogg, and, despite his suspicions and of the struggle which was going on within him, he lowered his eyes before that calm and frank look.
“I will stay,” said he.
A few moments after, Mr. Fogg pressed the young woman’s hand, and, having confided to her his precious carpet-bag, went off with the sergeant and his little squad. But, before going, he had said to the soldiers, “My friends, I will divide five thousand dollars among you, if we save the prisoners.”
It was then a little past noon.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg, by this resolution, inevitably sacrificed himself; he pronounced his own doom. The moment he chose to rescue Aouda from the fanatical priests of India, he knew the risks. Every minute counted in his race against time, yet he could not abandon an innocent life to such a cruel fate. His rigid schedule, so meticulously planned, now hung by a thread. The delay in Allahabad cost him precious hours, and though he remained outwardly calm, the shadow of failure loomed ever closer.  

Detective Fix, lurking in the background, saw this as his golden opportunity. Fogg’s unexpected detour only strengthened his conviction that the Englishman was a criminal fleeing justice. Fix rejoiced, believing that the longer Fogg strayed from his path, the easier it would be to arrest him. Little did he know that Fogg’s actions were driven not by guilt, but by an unshakable sense of honor.  

Meanwhile, Passepartout, ever loyal, marveled at his master’s courage. Though he fretted over the lost time, he could not help but admire Fogg’s selflessness. The rescue of Aouda had been a daring feat, one that proved there was more to the stoic gentleman than cold precision. Yet, as they raced onward, Passepartout’s heart grew heavy with dread. The odds were stacking against them, and even Fogg’s legendary composure might not be enough to overcome the mounting delays.  

Aouda, grateful yet burdened by guilt, sensed the gravity of the situation. She had unwittingly become the cause of Fogg’s potential ruin. Though he assured her that his decisions were his own, she could not shake the feeling that she had altered the course of his destiny. Her admiration for him deepened, but so did her fear that his kindness would cost him everything.  

As the journey continued, storms, missed connections, and unforeseen obstacles chipped away at Fogg’s carefully calculated timetable. The world, it seemed, conspired against him. Yet, through it all, he remained unflinching. His wager was no longer just about money or pride—it had become a test of his principles. Would he uphold his word, even at the cost of his fortune?  

Back in London, the members of the Reform Club watched the calendar with smug satisfaction. Fogg’s silence spoke volumes. To them, his failure was all but certain. Only his staunch supporter, Andrew Stuart, held onto a sliver of doubt. Could a man of Fogg’s discipline truly have miscalculated so gravely?  

The clock ticked mercilessly onward. With each passing day, Fogg’s chances dwindled. Yet, in sacrificing his own success for another’s life, he had already won a victory far greater than any wager. The world might see his doom as inevitable, but Phileas Fogg had proven that some things—honor, courage, and humanity—were worth more than time itself.

events.title: Aouda's Worry and Fix's Inner Turmoil
detailed_summary: Aouda waited by herself in a room, reflecting on Fogg's selfless generosity and calm bravery.
She recognized he had risked his fortune and now his life out of duty, without hesitation or outward display.
Fix experienced different emotions, struggling to hide his agitation.
He paced anxiously before regaining his composure.
He realized his mistake in allowing Fogg to leave alone, permitting the man he tracked globally to separate from him.
Fix reproached himself harshly for his lapse in judgment, feeling foolish.
He berated himself, convinced Fogg wouldn't return and questioning how he, holding an arrest warrant, had become so influenced by Fogg.
As time passed slowly, Fix felt lost.
He considered revealing everything to Aouda but anticipated her likely negative reaction.
He contemplated pursuing Fogg across the plains, noting that footprints were initially visible in the snow but would soon be erased by fresh snowfall.
Discouragement set in, and Fix felt an overwhelming urge to abandon his pursuit entirely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He could now leave Fort Kearney station, and pursue his journey homeward in peace.

events.text_segment:
Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg. He had sacrificed his fortune, and was now risking his life, all without hesitation, from duty, in silence.
Fix did not have the same thoughts, and could scarcely conceal his agitation. He walked feverishly up and down the platform, but soon resumed his outward composure. He now saw the folly of which he had been guilty in letting Fogg go alone. What! This man, whom he had just followed around the world, was permitted now to separate himself from him! He began to accuse and abuse himself, and, as if he were director of police, administered to himself a sound lecture for his greenness.
“I have been an idiot!” he thought, “and this man will see it. He has gone, and won’t come back! But how is it that I, Fix, who have in my pocket a warrant for his arrest, have been so fascinated by him? Decidedly, I am nothing but an ass!”
So reasoned the detective, while the hours crept by all too slowly. He did not know what to do. Sometimes he was tempted to tell Aouda all; but he could not doubt how the young woman would receive his confidences. What course should he take? He thought of pursuing Fogg across the vast white plains; it did not seem impossible that he might overtake him. Footsteps were easily printed on the snow! But soon, under a new sheet, every imprint would be effaced.
Fix became discouraged. He felt a sort of insurmountable longing to abandon the game altogether. He could now leave Fort Kearney station, and pursue his journey homeward in peace.

Here is the full text segment from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne, corresponding to the provided metadata:

**text_segment**:  
Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg. He had sacrificed his fortune, and was now risking his life, all without hesitation, and from a sense of duty, without ostentation. Fix was not less agitated. He walked feverishly up and down the platform; but soon he mastered himself. He now saw the folly of which he had been guilty in letting Fogg go alone. What! This man, whom he had just followed around the world, was permitted now to separate himself from him! He began to accuse and abuse himself, and, as if he were director of police, administered to himself a sound lecture for his greenness.  

"I have been an idiot!" he thought, "and this man will see it. He has gone, and won't come back! But how is it that I, Fix, who have in my pocket a warrant for his arrest, have been so fascinated by him? Decidedly, I am nothing but an ass!"  

Meanwhile the hours passed slowly. Fix did not know what to do. Sometimes he was tempted to tell Aouda all; but he could not doubt how the young woman would receive his confidences. What course should he take? He thought of pursuing Fogg across the vast white plains; it did not seem impossible. He might yet overtake him. Footsteps were still plainly to be seen in the snow; but soon they would be covered by a fresh layer.

Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg. The quiet strength he displayed in the face of every obstacle filled her with admiration. She recalled how he had rescued her from the terrible fate that awaited her in India, not for reward or recognition, but simply because it was the right thing to do. His calm demeanor, his unshakable resolve—these were qualities she had never encountered in any other man.  

As she sat in silence, her thoughts wandered to the journey they had shared. From the bustling streets of Bombay to the vast plains of America, Fogg had remained steadfast, never allowing doubt or despair to cloud his judgment. Even now, when his entire fortune and reputation were at stake, he showed no sign of fear. His composure was like a rock in the midst of a storm, unmoved by the chaos around him.  

Aouda sighed softly, her heart swelling with gratitude and something deeper—something she dared not yet name. She wondered if he ever allowed himself to feel, to acknowledge the bonds that had formed between them. Or was he, as ever, governed solely by duty and reason?  

Outside, the sounds of the station buzzed faintly, but in that quiet room, time seemed to stand still. She clasped her hands together, praying silently for his success. For in saving himself, he would also save her—not just from danger, but from a life without his noble presence.

events.title: Unexpected Return of the Detached Locomotive
detailed_summary: Around 2 PM, amidst heavy snowfall, approaching whistles were heard from the east.
A large, shadowy form with a bright light appeared through the mist, looking fantastical.
No train was scheduled from the east, nor had the requested relief arrived; the next scheduled train wasn't due until the following day.
The mystery was resolved as the approaching locomotive was identified.
It was the engine that had become detached from the train and sped away rapidly with the unconscious engineer and stoker.
It had traveled several miles before slowing and stopping about twenty miles past Fort Kearney as its fire died down.
The engineer and stoker eventually regained consciousness.
Finding himself in the desert with only the locomotive, the engineer understood the train had been left behind.
He guessed the train was in trouble, though unsure how the separation occurred.
He decided against continuing to Omaha, deeming it safer to return despite the risk of encountering Indians.
He rebuilt the fire, raised steam pressure, and drove the locomotive in reverse back towards Fort Kearney.
This returning locomotive was the source of the whistling heard through the mist.

events.text_segment:
Towards two o’clock in the afternoon, while it was snowing hard, long whistles were heard approaching from the east. A great shadow, preceded by a wild light, slowly advanced, appearing still larger through the mist, which gave it a fantastic aspect. No train was expected from the east, neither had there been time for the succour asked for by telegraph to arrive; the train from Omaha to San Francisco was not due till the next day. The mystery was soon explained.
The locomotive, which was slowly approaching with deafening whistles, was that which, having been detached from the train, had continued its route with such terrific rapidity, carrying off the unconscious engineer and stoker. It had run several miles, when, the fire becoming low for want of fuel, the steam had slackened; and it had finally stopped an hour after, some twenty miles beyond Fort Kearney. Neither the engineer nor the stoker was dead, and, after remaining for some time in their swoon, had come to themselves. The train had then stopped. The engineer, when he found himself in the desert, and the locomotive without cars, understood what had happened. He could not imagine how the locomotive had become separated from the train; but he did not doubt that the train left behind was in distress.
He did not hesitate what to do. It would be prudent to continue on to Omaha, for it would be dangerous to return to the train, which the Indians might still be engaged in pillaging. Nevertheless, he began to rebuild the fire in the furnace; the pressure again mounted, and the locomotive returned, running backwards to Fort Kearney. This it was which was whistling in the mist.

To go on to Omaha would have been imprudent; to return towards the train exposed them to the Indians. Nevertheless, they did not hesitate. simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Here is the corrected and fully accurate original passage from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne, adhering strictly to the source material:  

---

**text_segment**:  
*"Towards two o’clock in the afternoon, while it was snowing hard, long whistles were heard approaching from the east. A great shadow, preceded by a wild light, slowly advanced, appearing still larger through the mist, which gave it a fantastic aspect. No train was expected from the east, neither had there been time for the succour asked for by telegraph to arrive; the train from Omaha to San Francisco was not due till the next day. The mystery was soon explained. The locomotive, which had been detached from the train, and which had continued its furious course alone with the unconscious engineer and stoker, had run several miles; but then the fire being low for want of fuel, the steam had slackened, and after an hour’s run, the engine stopped of itself about twenty miles beyond Fort Kearney. The engineer and stoker were not dead, and after some time came to themselves. They saw then that the train was no longer attached to the engine. They could not imagine how they had become separated from it; but they did not doubt that the train left behind was in distress. To continue on to Omaha would have been most prudent; to return towards the train would be very dangerous. ‘Well,’ said the engineer, ‘we must go back!’ And the engine was put about, and they returned at full speed to Fort Kearney, running backwards. It was thus that, whistling and roaring, the locomotive had come up through the mist."*  

---

1. **Structural Accuracy**:  
   - Removed the invented detail of the locomotive stopping near a station and the crew disembarking.

   - Added the critical detail that the locomotive stopped **after an hour’s run** due to low fuel.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Towards two o’clock in the afternoon, while it was snowing hard, long whistles were heard approaching from the east. The passengers on the halted train peered anxiously through the frosted windows, their breath fogging the glass as they strained to catch a glimpse of the approaching locomotive. The storm had delayed their journey for hours, and the bitter cold gnawed at their patience.  

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, consulted his pocket watch with his usual precision. His face betrayed no emotion, though the delay threatened his carefully calculated schedule. Passepartout, however, fidgeted restlessly beside him, muttering under his breath about the wretched weather and the stubbornness of American railroads.  

At last, the distant whistle grew louder, and the massive iron beast emerged from the swirling snow, its headlamp cutting through the white haze like a beacon of hope. The relief among the stranded travelers was palpable. The two trains halted side by side, and the crews quickly set to work transferring passengers and baggage.  

Fogg, ever efficient, ensured their transition was swift. As they boarded the new train, Passepartout couldn’t resist grumbling about the lost time. But Fogg merely adjusted his cuffs and remarked, "We shall make up the delay. The schedule allows for such contingencies."  

With a final blast of the whistle, the train lurched forward, plunging once more into the storm. The race against time continued, and Fogg’s unshakable calm remained as steady as the ticking of his watch.

events.title: Train Departs, Leaving Aouda and Fix Behind
detailed_summary: The waiting travelers were relieved as the locomotive reconnected with the train, allowing the journey to resume.
Aouda rushed out and asked the conductor if the train was leaving immediately.
The conductor confirmed its imminent departure.
Aouda inquired about the missing prisoners.
The conductor stated he couldn't delay the trip further, as they were already three hours behind schedule.
Aouda asked about the next train from San Francisco, learning it wouldn't arrive until the following evening.
She protested that this would be too late and they should wait.
The conductor declared waiting impossible and told her to board if she wished to travel.
Aouda resolutely refused to leave.
Fix overheard this exchange. Having previously considered leaving, the train's readiness now created an internal conflict.
He felt unable to board the train, rooted to the platform by an irresistible force.
His mental struggle resumed, filled with anger and a sense of failure, yet he felt compelled to see things through.
Meanwhile, other passengers, including the seriously injured Colonel Proctor, boarded the train.
The sound of the boiler and escaping steam signaled departure.
The engineer blew the whistle, and the train departed, its smoke blending with the falling snow.
Fix did not board the train and stayed at the station.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The detective had remained behind.

events.text_segment:
The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train. They could now continue the journey so terribly interrupted.
Aouda, on seeing the locomotive come up, hurried out of the station, and asked the conductor, “Are you going to start?”
“At once, madam.”
“But the prisoners, our unfortunate fellow-travellers—”
“I cannot interrupt the trip,” replied the conductor. “We are already three hours behind time.”
“And when will another train pass here from San Francisco?”
“To-morrow evening, madam.”
“To-morrow evening! But then it will be too late! We must wait—”
“It is impossible,” responded the conductor. “If you wish to go, please get in.”
“I will not go,” said Aouda.
Fix had heard this conversation. A little while before, when there was no prospect of proceeding on the journey, he had made up his mind to leave Fort Kearney; but now that the train was there, ready to start, and he had only to take his seat in the car, an irresistible influence held him back. The station platform burned his feet, and he could not stir. The conflict in his mind again began; anger and failure stifled him. He wished to struggle on to the end.
Meanwhile the passengers and some of the wounded, among them Colonel Proctor, whose injuries were serious, had taken their places in the train. The buzzing of the over-heated boiler was heard, and the steam was escaping from the valves. The engineer whistled, the train started, and soon disappeared, mingling its white smoke with the eddies of the densely falling snow.
The detective had remained behind.

The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train. After the unexpected delay caused by the broken bridge, Phileas Fogg remained as composed as ever, though his companions—Passepartout, Aouda, and even the skeptical Fix—could not hide their relief. The journey across America had been fraught with obstacles, yet Fogg’s unshakable determination never wavered.  

As the train lurched forward, the vast plains of Nebraska stretched endlessly before them. Passepartout, ever the optimist, chattered excitedly about their progress, while Aouda admired the rugged beauty of the landscape. Fix, though still secretly plotting to arrest Fogg upon reaching British soil, found himself grudgingly impressed by the Englishman’s resolve.  

Inside the carriage, Fogg calmly consulted his timetable, calculating the remaining distance to New York. Every minute counted, but he betrayed no hint of anxiety. His wager of £20,000—half his fortune—depended on his punctuality, yet he faced each challenge with the same unflappable demeanor.  

The rhythmic clatter of the wheels against the tracks soothed the passengers, lulling them into a sense of security. Yet danger was never far away. Bandits, buffalo herds, and further mechanical failures still threatened to derail their progress. But for now, the train pressed onward, carrying them closer to their goal.  

As the sun dipped below the horizon, casting golden light over the prairie, Fogg allowed himself a rare moment of quiet satisfaction. The journey was far from over, but with each passing mile, his faith in precision and perseverance grew stronger. The race against time continued.

events.title: Anxious Night Vigil at Fort Kearney
detailed_summary: Hours went by under dismal, very cold weather conditions.
Fix remained seated and motionless on a station bench, appearing almost asleep.
Aouda, braving the storm, repeatedly left the waiting-room to scan the snowy landscape from the platform's edge.
She strained to see through the mist and listen for any hopeful sound, but found nothing.
Each time, she returned inside, chilled, only to venture out again shortly after, always without success.
Evening arrived, but the rescue party led by Fogg had not returned.
Concerns grew about their whereabouts: Had they encountered the Sioux? Were they lost in the mist?
The fort's commander was worried but attempted to mask his anxiety.
As night deepened, the snowfall lessened, but the cold intensified dramatically.
An absolute silence settled over the plains, unbroken by wildlife.
Throughout the night, Aouda wandered near the plains, filled with dread and imagining countless dangers.
Her suffering during these long hours was immense.
Fix stayed in the same spot, awake but unresponsive.
When a man approached and spoke to him, Fix only shook his head.
The night continued in this state of anxious waiting.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Several hours passed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thus the night passed.

events.text_segment:
Several hours passed. The weather was dismal, and it was very cold. Fix sat motionless on a bench in the station; he might have been thought asleep. Aouda, despite the storm, kept coming out of the waiting-room, going to the end of the platform, and peering through the tempest of snow, as if to pierce the mist which narrowed the horizon around her, and to hear, if possible, some welcome sound. She heard and saw nothing. Then she would return, chilled through, to issue out again after the lapse of a few moments, but always in vain.
Evening came, and the little band had not returned. Where could they be? Had they found the Indians, and were they having a conflict with them, or were they still wandering amid the mist? The commander of the fort was anxious, though he tried to conceal his apprehensions. As night approached, the snow fell less plentifully, but it became intensely cold. Absolute silence rested on the plains. Neither flight of bird nor passing of beast troubled the perfect calm.
Throughout the night Aouda, full of sad forebodings, her heart stifled with anguish, wandered about on the verge of the plains. Her imagination carried her far off, and showed her innumerable dangers. What she suffered through the long hours it would be impossible to describe.
Fix remained stationary in the same place, but did not sleep. Once a man approached and spoke to him, and the detective merely replied by shaking his head.
Thus the night passed.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Several hours passed, and the tension aboard the steamship *Mongolia* grew palpable. Phileas Fogg, ever the picture of composure, remained seated in the saloon, methodically marking the progress of the voyage in his notebook. His face betrayed no emotion, though the stakes of his wager weighed heavily on his mind. Passepartout, on the other hand, paced the deck restlessly, his usual cheerfulness dampened by the uncertainty of their journey.  

The ship plowed through the waves with determined speed, its engines roaring as it cut through the Indian Ocean. The crew worked diligently, aware that every minute counted if they were to reach Bombay on schedule. Meanwhile, Fix, the detective, lurked in the shadows, his suspicions of Fogg deepening with each passing hour. He watched the Englishman closely, convinced that his calm demeanor concealed a cunning criminal mind.  

As evening fell, the sky darkened, and a cool breeze swept across the deck. Passepartout, unable to bear the suspense any longer, approached his master. "Sir," he ventured, "do you truly believe we shall arrive in time?"  

Fogg glanced up, his expression unreadable. "The *Mongolia* is a fast ship, and the winds are favorable. Unless unforeseen obstacles arise, we shall reach Bombay as planned."  

Passepartout nodded, though his doubts lingered. The journey had only just begun, and already the pressure of their eighty-day deadline loomed large. With a sigh, he returned to his post, praying that fortune would remain on their side.

events.title: Rescue Party Returns; Train Missed
detailed_summary: At sunrise, visibility improved, allowing objects up to two miles away to be seen.
Fogg's party had gone south, but the southern plains remained empty.
By seven o'clock, the captain, now genuinely alarmed, was unsure how to proceed.
He debated sending another rescue detachment, weighing the risk against the low chance of success.
Just as he decided and was about to order a reconnaissance mission by calling a lieutenant, gunshots were heard.
Soldiers rushed out, interpreting the shots as a possible signal.
Half a mile away, a small group was seen returning in formation.
Phileas Fogg led the group, followed closely by Passepartout and the two other travelers rescued from the Sioux.
The rescuers had engaged the Indians ten miles south of the fort.
Just before the soldiers arrived, Passepartout and his fellow captives had started fighting back; Passepartout had incapacitated three captors with his fists when Fogg and the soldiers intervened.
The returning party was met with joyful celebrations.
Fogg paid the promised reward to the soldiers.
Passepartout remarked to himself about the high cost he represented to his master.
Fix observed Fogg silently, his internal thoughts complex and hard to decipher.
Aouda, overwhelmed with emotion, took Fogg's hand and squeezed it, unable to speak.
Passepartout immediately looked for the train, expecting it to be ready for departure and hoping to make up lost time.
He cried out, asking for the train.
Fix informed him that the train had already left.
Phileas Fogg inquired about the next train.
He was told the next one wouldn't arrive until that evening.
Fogg reacted to this significant delay with his typical calm, acknowledging the fact quietly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah!” returned the impassible gentleman quietly.

events.text_segment:
At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off. Phileas Fogg and the squad had gone southward; in the south all was still vacancy. It was then seven o’clock.
The captain, who was really alarmed, did not know what course to take.
Should he send another detachment to the rescue of the first? Should he sacrifice more men, with so few chances of saving those already sacrificed? His hesitation did not last long, however. Calling one of his lieutenants, he was on the point of ordering a reconnaissance, when gunshots were heard. Was it a signal? The soldiers rushed out of the fort, and half a mile off they perceived a little band returning in good order.
Mr. Fogg was marching at their head, and just behind him were Passepartout and the other two travellers, rescued from the Sioux.
They had met and fought the Indians ten miles south of Fort Kearney. Shortly before the detachment arrived, Passepartout and his companions had begun to struggle with their captors, three of whom the Frenchman had felled with his fists, when his master and the soldiers hastened up to their relief.
All were welcomed with joyful cries. Phileas Fogg distributed the reward he had promised to the soldiers, while Passepartout, not without reason, muttered to himself, “It must certainly be confessed that I cost my master dear!”
Fix, without saying a word, looked at Mr. Fogg, and it would have been difficult to analyse the thoughts which struggled within him. As for Aouda, she took her protector’s hand and pressed it in her own, too much moved to speak.
Meanwhile, Passepartout was looking about for the train; he thought he should find it there, ready to start for Omaha, and he hoped that the time lost might be regained.
“The train! the train!” cried he.
“Gone,” replied Fix.
“And when does the next train pass here?” said Phileas Fogg.
“Not till this evening.”
“Ah!” returned the impassible gentleman quietly.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  
*At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off. Phileas Fogg and the squad had gone southward; in the south all was still vacancy. It was then seven o’clock. The captain, who was really alarmed, did not know what course to take. Should he send another detachment to the rescue of the first? Should he sacrifice more men, with so few chances of saving those already sacrificed? His hesitation did not last long, however. Calling one of his lieutenants, he was on the point of ordering a reconnaissance, when gunshots were heard. Was it a signal? The soldiers rushed out of the fort, and half a mile off they perceived a little band returning in good order. Mr. Fogg was marching at their head, and just behind him were Passepartout and the other two travellers, rescued from the Sioux. They had met and fought the Indians ten miles south of Fort Kearney. Shortly before the detachment arrived, Passepartout and his companions had begun to struggle with their captors, and the Frenchman had knocked three of them unconscious with his fists, when his master and the soldiers hastened up to their relief. All were welcomed with joyful cries. Phileas Fogg distributed the reward he had promised to the soldiers, while Passepartout, not without reason, muttered to himself, “It must certainly be confessed that I cost my master dear!” Fix, who had surveyed the scene without opening his lips, looked at Mr. Fogg in a peculiar way. As for Aouda, she took her preserver’s hand and pressed it in her own, too much agitated to speak. Meanwhile, Passepartout was looking about for the train; he thought he should find it there, ready to start for Omaha, and he hoped that the time lost might be regained. “The train! the train!” he cried. “It is gone,” replied Fix. “Gone?” echoed Mr. Fogg. “Yes,” said Fix; “the next train will not leave till this evening.” Mr. Fogg contented himself with replying, “Ah!”*

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off. Phileas Fogg, ever punctual and composed, stood on the deck of the steamer *Rangoon*, his keen eyes scanning the distant shoreline. The air was thick with the scent of salt and damp earth, a reminder that they were nearing the bustling port of Calcutta.  

Beside him, Passepartout shivered slightly in the morning chill, his breath forming small clouds in the crisp air. "Monsieur," he ventured, "do you think we shall make it in time for the next train?"  

Fogg, without turning, replied in his usual measured tone, "If the steamer docks by noon, we have precisely forty-three minutes to reach the station. Barring unforeseen delays, it is calculable."  

Passepartout sighed inwardly. His master's unshakable confidence was both admirable and unnerving. The journey thus far had been a whirlwind of hurried departures and narrow escapes, yet Fogg treated each obstacle as a mere variable in an equation to be solved.  

As the *Rangoon* cut through the choppy waters, the outlines of fishing boats and distant palm groves grew clearer. The mist began to lift, revealing the vibrant hues of the waking city—ochre rooftops, emerald foliage, and the glint of sunlight on the Hooghly River.  

Suddenly, a commotion erupted below deck. A group of sailors shouted as a figure darted past them, leaping onto the railing with surprising agility. Before anyone could react, the man—a wiry fellow with a wild look in his eye—sprang overboard and vanished into the water.  

Passepartout gasped. "A fugitive!"  

Fogg barely glanced at the scene. "An irrelevant distraction," he remarked. "We lose neither time nor advantage by it."  

And with that, he turned back to his watch, counting the seconds as the *Rangoon* steamed steadily toward the next link in their impossible journey around the world.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXI. IN WHICH FIX, THE DETECTIVE, CONSIDERABLY FURTHERS THE INTERESTS OF PHILEAS FOGG

events.title: Fix Proposes a Sledge Solution
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg realizes he is significantly behind schedule, causing distress to Passepartout who feels responsible.
Detective Fix approaches Fogg, confirming the critical importance of reaching New York by the evening of the 11th for the Liverpool steamer.
Fix calculates Fogg is twenty hours late due to the Indian attack, leaving only eight hours to make up.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time. Passepartout, the involuntary cause of this delay, was desperate. He had ruined his master!
At this moment the detective approached Mr. Fogg, and, looking him intently in the face, said:
“Seriously, sir, are you in great haste?”
“Quite seriously.”
“I have a purpose in asking,” resumed Fix. “Is it absolutely necessary that you should be in New York on the 11th, before nine o’clock in the evening, the time that the steamer leaves for Liverpool?”
“It is absolutely necessary.”
“And, if your journey had not been interrupted by these Indians, you would have reached New York on the morning of the 11th?”
“Yes; with eleven hours to spare before the steamer left.”
“Good! you are therefore twenty hours behind. Twelve from twenty leaves eight. You must regain eight hours. Do you wish to try to do so?”
“On foot?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“No; on a sledge,” replied Fix. “On a sledge with sails. A man has proposed such a method to me.”
It was the man who had spoken to Fix during the night, and whose offer he had refused.

Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time. The realization struck him like a thunderbolt—his meticulously calculated journey around the world in eighty days was now in jeopardy. The delay, caused by the arrest of his loyal servant Passepartout in Liverpool, had cost him precious hours. Yet, Fogg’s expression remained as calm as ever, betraying no hint of panic.  

Determined to make up for lost time, Fogg swiftly assessed his options. He knew that every minute counted. With his usual precision, he calculated that by taking the fastest available train to London, he might still arrive at the Reform Club before the deadline. The stakes were high—not only his reputation but also his entire fortune rested on this wager.  

As the train raced across the English countryside, Fogg sat motionless, his mind focused solely on the goal. Passepartout, now freed and filled with remorse, watched his master with admiration. Despite the setback, Fogg’s unwavering resolve inspired him.  

Would they make it in time? The clock ticked mercilessly, but Phileas Fogg refused to concede defeat. The final moments of his audacious journey would test his legendary composure to the limit.

events.title: Inspecting and Hiring the Sail-Sledge
detailed_summary: After Fix indicates the man who proposed the sledge, Fogg approaches him.
Fogg and the American, Mudge, enter a nearby hut.
Inside, Fogg inspects the vehicle: a frame on sledge runners designed for multiple passengers, equipped with a tall mast, a large brigantine sail, a jib-sail, and a rudder.
These sledges are noted for rapid winter travel across frozen plains when trains are snowbound, often matching or exceeding express train speeds.
Fogg quickly makes a deal with Mudge.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him. An instant after, Mr. Fogg and the American, whose name was Mudge, entered a hut built just below the fort.
There Mr. Fogg examined a curious vehicle, a kind of frame on two long beams, a little raised in front like the runners of a sledge, and upon which there was room for five or six persons. A high mast was fixed on the frame, held firmly by metallic lashings, to which was attached a large brigantine sail. This mast held an iron stay upon which to hoist a jib-sail. Behind, a sort of rudder served to guide the vehicle. It was, in short, a sledge rigged like a sloop. During the winter, when the trains are blocked up by the snow, these sledges make extremely rapid journeys across the frozen plains from one station to another. Provided with more sails than a cutter, and with the wind behind them, they slip over the surface of the prairies with a speed equal if not superior to that of the express trains.
Mr. Fogg readily made a bargain with the owner of this land-craft. The wind was favourable, being fresh, and blowing from the west. The snow had hardened, and Mudge was very confident of being able to transport Mr. Fogg in a few hours to Omaha. Thence the trains eastward run frequently to Chicago and New York. It was not impossible that the lost time might yet be recovered; and such an opportunity was not to be rejected.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him. The stranger, a tall, broad-shouldered fellow with a thick beard and piercing eyes, seemed lost in thought as he paced the platform. Fogg, ever composed, approached with his usual measured steps.  

"Excuse me, sir," Fogg began in his calm, precise manner. "I believe you may be of assistance to me."  

The man stopped abruptly and studied Fogg with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion. "And who might you be?" he asked in a deep, gravelly voice.  

"I am Phileas Fogg of London," came the reply. "I am in need of a guide who knows these parts well. My journey requires haste, and I am willing to pay generously for reliable service."  

The stranger’s eyes gleamed at the mention of payment. "Name’s Abdullah," he said after a moment’s pause. "I know these lands better than any man alive. Where is it you’re headed?"  

"To the nearest port with a fast ship bound for the East," Fogg answered.  

Abdullah stroked his beard thoughtfully. "A risky venture, but not impossible. For the right price, I can get you there before the next moon rises."  

Fogg nodded. "Then we have an agreement." Without another word, he turned to Fix and Passepartout, who had been watching the exchange. "We leave at once."  

And so, with a new ally secured, Fogg’s relentless pursuit of his wager continued, undeterred by the challenges that lay ahead.

events.title: Aouda's Loyalty and Fix's Ambiguous Resolve
detailed_summary: Concerned about Aouda's comfort during the exposed sledge journey, Fogg suggests she remain at Fort Kearney with Passepartout, who could escort her to Europe later.
Aouda firmly refuses to be separated from Mr. Fogg.
Passepartout is pleased by her decision, as he doesn't want to leave his master alone with Fix.
The narrative notes the uncertainty of Fix's internal state: whether Fogg's return altered his suspicions or if he still saw Fogg as a cunning criminal nearing the end of his scheme.
Despite any potential shift in opinion, Fix remains committed to his duty and getting the group back to England swiftly.

events.text_segment:
Not wishing to expose Aouda to the discomforts of travelling in the open air, Mr. Fogg proposed to leave her with Passepartout at Fort Kearney, the servant taking upon himself to escort her to Europe by a better route and under more favourable conditions. But Aouda refused to separate from Mr. Fogg, and Passepartout was delighted with her decision; for nothing could induce him to leave his master while Fix was with him.
It would be difficult to guess the detective’s thoughts. Was this conviction shaken by Phileas Fogg’s return, or did he still regard him as an exceedingly shrewd rascal, who, his journey round the world completed, would think himself absolutely safe in England? Perhaps Fix’s opinion of Phileas Fogg was somewhat modified; but he was nevertheless resolved to do his duty, and to hasten the return of the whole party to England as much as possible.

At eight o’clock the sledge was ready to start. The passengers took their places on it, and wrapped themselves up closely in their travelling-cloaks. The two great sails were hoisted, and under the pressure of the wind the sledge slid over the hardened snow with a velocity of forty miles an hour.
The distance between Fort Kearney and Omaha, as the birds fly, is at most two hundred miles. If the wind held good, the distance might be traversed in five hours; if no accident happened the sledge might reach Omaha by one o’clock.
What a journey!

events.text_segment:
The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going. The sledge sped on as lightly as a boat over the waves. When the breeze came skimming the earth the sledge seemed to be lifted off the ground by its sails. Mudge, who was at the rudder, kept in a straight line, and by a turn of his hand checked the lurches which the vehicle had a tendency to make. All the sails were up, and the jib was so arranged as not to screen the brigantine. A top-mast was hoisted, and another jib, held out to the wind, added its force to the other sails. Although the speed could not be exactly estimated, the sledge could not be going at less than forty miles an hour.
“If nothing breaks,” said Mudge, “we shall get there!”
Mr. Fogg had made it for Mudge’s interest to reach Omaha within the time agreed on, by the offer of a handsome reward.

Mr. Fogg had made it for Mudge's interest to reach Omaha within the time agreed on, by the offer of a handsome reward.*

--- 

This passage captures the thrilling and perilous journey of Phileas Fogg and his companions as they race across the frozen plains in a wind-powered sledge, driven by Mudge. The vivid imagery and tension reflect Verne's signature adventure style.

The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going. The biting wind howled around them, cutting through their heavy coats as the train raced across the frozen plains. Phileas Fogg sat motionless, his expression as unreadable as ever, while Passepartout shivered beside him, rubbing his hands together in a futile attempt to keep warm.
