events.text_segment:
And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt? It was difficult to imagine. Nevertheless he seemed to have decided upon one, for that evening he sent for the engineer, and said to him, “Feed all the fires until the coal is exhausted.”
A few moments after, the funnel of the “Henrietta” vomited forth torrents of smoke. The vessel continued to proceed with all steam on; but on the 18th, the engineer, as he had predicted, announced that the coal would give out in the course of the day.
“Do not let the fires go down,” replied Mr. Fogg. “Keep them up to the last. Let the valves be filled.”
Towards noon Phileas Fogg, having ascertained their position, called Passepartout, and ordered him to go for Captain Speedy. It was as if the honest fellow had been commanded to unchain a tiger. He went to the poop, saying to himself, “He will be like a madman!”
In a few moments, with cries and oaths, a bomb appeared on the poop-deck. The bomb was Captain Speedy. It was clear that he was on the point of bursting. “Where are we?” were the first words his anger permitted him to utter. Had the poor man been an apoplectic, he could never have recovered from his paroxysm of wrath.
“Where are we?” he repeated, with purple face.
“Seven hundred and seven miles from Liverpool,” replied Mr. Fogg, with imperturbable calmness.
“Pirate!” cried Captain Speedy.
“I have sent for you, sir—”
“Pickaroon!”
“—sir,” continued Mr. Fogg, “to ask you to sell me your vessel.”
“No! By all the devils, no!”
“But I shall be obliged to burn her.”
“Burn the ‘Henrietta’!”
“Yes; at least the upper part of her. The coal has given out.”
“Burn my vessel!” cried Captain Speedy, who could scarcely pronounce the words. “A vessel worth fifty thousand dollars!”
“Here are sixty thousand,” replied Phileas Fogg, handing the captain a roll of bank-bills. This had a prodigious effect on Andrew Speedy. An American can scarcely remain unmoved at the sight of sixty thousand dollars. The captain forgot in an instant his anger, his imprisonment, and all his grudges against his passenger. The “Henrietta” was twenty years old; it was a great bargain. The bomb would not go off after all. Mr. Fogg had taken away the match.
“And I shall still have the iron hull,” said the captain in a softer tone.
“The iron hull and the engine. Is it agreed?”
“Agreed.”
And Andrew Speedy, seizing the banknotes, counted them and consigned them to his pocket.
During this colloquy, Passepartout was as white as a sheet, and Fix seemed on the point of having an apoplectic fit. Nearly twenty thousand pounds had been expended, and Fogg left the hull and engine to the captain, that is, near the whole value of the craft! It was true, however, that fifty-five thousand pounds had been stolen from the Bank.
When Andrew Speedy had pocketed the money, Mr. Fogg said to him, “Don’t let this astonish you, sir.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt? The situation was dire. The *Mongolia*, the steamer he had counted on to carry him from Suez to Bombay, had departed earlier than expected, leaving him stranded in Egypt. For a man whose every action was calculated down to the minute, this was a severe blow. Yet, as always, his face betrayed no emotion. He stood on the docks, his hands clasped behind his back, his gaze fixed on the horizon where the ship had vanished.  

Passepartout, ever the anxious companion, wrung his hands. "What shall we do, sir? We are ruined!"  

Fogg, however, remained unshaken. "There is always an alternative," he replied coolly. "We must find another vessel."  

But no other steamer was scheduled to depart for Bombay for several days—far too late to keep to his meticulously planned schedule. Time was slipping away, and with it, the wager of twenty thousand pounds. Yet Fogg did not despair. Instead, he turned to the bustling port, where merchants, sailors, and travelers hurried about their business.  

It was then that he spotted a small, swift-looking steamer, the *Henrietta*, preparing to set sail for Hong Kong. Though it was not his intended destination, Fogg saw an opportunity. Hong Kong was a major port, and from there, he could secure passage to Yokohama and then across the Pacific. Adjusting his plan with the precision of a chess master, he approached the captain.  

The negotiation was brief. Fogg offered an exorbitant sum to charter the ship immediately. The captain, a shrewd man, hesitated—until Fogg doubled the offer. Money, it seemed, could buy even time itself. Within the hour, the *Henrietta* was under steam, cutting through the waves with Fogg and Passepartout aboard.  

Passepartout, though relieved, could not help but marvel at his master's unflappable nature. "You amaze me, sir! To change course so swiftly—it is as if nothing troubles you!"  

Fogg merely adjusted his cuffs. "The unforeseen is to be expected. One must adapt."  

And so they raced eastward, the *Henrietta* slicing through the water at full speed. Fogg spent his days in quiet calculation, studying his itinerary, while Passepartout fretted over coal supplies and storm clouds on the horizon. Yet Fogg’s resolve never wavered. Every delay, every obstacle, was but a variable in his grand equation.  

As the days passed, it became clear that the *Henrietta* would not reach Hong Kong in time for Fogg’s connecting ship. Once again, he was forced to improvise. When the steamer neared Shanghai, he ordered the crew to alter course, making for the Chinese port instead. From there, he secured passage on a faster vessel, the *Carnatic*, which would carry him to Yokohama with minutes to spare.  

Passepartout, dizzy from the whirlwind of changes, could only shake his head in admiration. "You are a magician of travel, sir!"  

Fogg permitted himself the faintest of smiles. "There is no magic, Passepartout—only determination and logic."  

And so, against all odds, Phileas Fogg pressed onward, his icy composure unbroken, his eyes fixed on the prize. The world might throw storms, delays, and misfortunes in his path, but he would not be deterred. For in the game of circumnavigation, every second counted—and Fogg intended to win.

events.title: Burning the Ship for Fuel
detailed_summary: Fogg explains his wager to Speedy: he must reach London by 8:45 PM on December 21st or lose £20,000.
He reminds Speedy that his refusal to go to Liverpool necessitated these actions.
Speedy retorts gleefully that Fogg's predicament earned him $40,000.
Speedy compliments Fogg, saying he has 'something of the Yankee' about him.
Fogg confirms his ownership of the vessel's wooden parts.
Fogg orders the crew to dismantle the interior fittings—seats, bunks, frames—to be used as fuel.
Dry wood is needed to maintain high steam pressure.
The poop deck, cabins, bunks, and spare deck structures are sacrificed on the first day.
On December 19th, the masts, rafts, and spars are burned.
The crew works energetically, feeding the fires.
Passepartout joins in the demolition efforts with great vigor.
A frenzied atmosphere of destruction takes hold as they dismantle the ship.

events.text_segment:
You must know that I shall lose twenty thousand pounds, unless I arrive in London by a quarter before nine on the evening of the 21st of December. I missed the steamer at New York, and as you refused to take me to Liverpool—”
“And I did well!” cried Andrew Speedy; “for I have gained at least forty thousand dollars by it!” He added, more sedately, “Do you know one thing, Captain—”
“Fogg.”
“Captain Fogg, you’ve got something of the Yankee about you.”
And, having paid his passenger what he considered a high compliment, he was going away, when Mr. Fogg said, “The vessel now belongs to me?”
“Certainly, from the keel to the truck of the masts—all the wood, that is.”
“Very well. Have the interior seats, bunks, and frames pulled down, and burn them.”
It was necessary to have dry wood to keep the steam up to the adequate pressure, and on that day the poop, cabins, bunks, and the spare deck were sacrificed. On the next day, the 19th of December, the masts, rafts, and spars were burned; the crew worked lustily, keeping up the fires. Passepartout hewed, cut, and sawed away with all his might. There was a perfect rage for demolition.

**Simulated Output**:

```text
"You must know that I shall lose twenty thousand pounds, unless I arrive in London by a quarter before nine on the evening of the 21st of December," said Phileas Fogg, his voice steady despite the urgency of his words.  

Andrew Speedy, arms crossed, regarded him with a mixture of amusement and grudging admiration. "And yet here you are, burning my ship to cinders!"  

Fogg remained unperturbed. "Your refusal to sail to Liverpool left me no choice. The wager stands."  

Speedy chuckled. "A fine predicament you’ve gotten yourself into—though I can’t complain. Forty thousand dollars richer, thanks to you!" He shook his head. "I’ll say this, Fogg—you’ve got something of the Yankee about you."  

Fogg gave a curt nod. "The vessel’s wooden parts are mine by contract. Crew!" he commanded. "Dismantle everything—seats, bunks, frames. We need dry wood to feed the boilers."  

The men set to work with a will. Passepartout, sleeves rolled up, tore into the cabin fittings with almost manic enthusiasm. By the first day, the poop deck, cabins, and spare structures had been reduced to kindling.  

On the 19th of December, the masts and spars followed, crackling in the furnace. The ship groaned under the assault, but the fires roared higher, driving them ever closer to England. A feverish energy gripped them all—every splintered plank, every shattered beam was another mile gained in their desperate race against time.
```

"You must know that I shall lose twenty thousand pounds, unless I arrive in London by a quarter before nine on the evening of the 21st of December," said Phileas Fogg.  

Andrew Speedy replied, "But the Henrietta is not going to Liverpool."  

Fogg answered, "It is not. I wished to go to Bordeaux, and you refused to take me to Liverpool. So now I must burn her."  

Speedy laughed. "Forty thousand dollars for a broken-down craft!"  

"You are right," said Fogg. "Forty thousand dollars." Then, after a pause, he added, "I do not regret it. From the keel to the truck of the masts—all the wood, that is—the vessel is mine."  

"Of course," said Speedy. "You’ve something of the Yankee about you."  

Fogg turned to the crew. "Dismantle the fittings—seats, bunks, frames. We must have dry wood to keep up the steam."  

That day, the poop, cabins, bunks, and spare deck structures were burned. On the 19th of December, they fed the masts, rafts, and spars to the furnace. The crew worked without rest; Passepartout tore at the wood with his own hands. The ship was stripped bare, plank by plank, to feed the insatiable fires.

events.title: Reaching Queenstown and Devising a New Strategy
detailed_summary: By December 20th, the ship is reduced to little more than a flat hull as railings and most of the deck are burned.
They sight the Irish coast and Fastnet Light.
By 10 PM, they are passing Queenstown.
Fogg has only 24 hours left to reach London, the time needed just to get to Liverpool at full steam.
The fuel source (the ship itself) is nearly exhausted.
Captain Speedy expresses sympathy, noting their position opposite Queenstown suggests failure.
Fogg confirms the lights indicate Queenstown.
He inquires about entering the harbour.
Speedy states it will take three hours, possible only at high tide.
Fogg calmly pauses, formulating a final, inspired plan to overcome this setback.
Queenstown is identified as the port where transatlantic mails are offloaded.
These mails travel by express train to Dublin and then by fast boat to Liverpool, saving 12 hours compared to the ships.
Fogg intends to use this same mail route.
By taking this route, he aims to reach Liverpool by noon the next day, allowing enough time to travel to London before his deadline.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The railings, fittings, the greater part of the deck, and top sides disappeared on the 20th, and the “Henrietta” was now only a flat hulk.

events.text_segment:
The railings, fittings, the greater part of the deck, and top sides disappeared on the 20th, and the “Henrietta” was now only a flat hulk. But on this day they sighted the Irish coast and Fastnet Light. By ten in the evening they were passing Queenstown. Phileas Fogg had only twenty-four hours more in which to get to London; that length of time was necessary to reach Liverpool, with all steam on. And the steam was about to give out altogether!
“Sir,” said Captain Speedy, who was now deeply interested in Mr. Fogg’s project, “I really commiserate you. Everything is against you. We are only opposite Queenstown.”
“Ah,” said Mr. Fogg, “is that place where we see the lights Queenstown?”
“Yes.”
“Can we enter the harbour?”
“Not under three hours. Only at high tide.”
“Stay,” replied Mr. Fogg calmly, without betraying in his features that by a supreme inspiration he was about to attempt once more to conquer ill-fortune.
Queenstown is the Irish port at which the transatlantic steamers stop to put off the mails. These mails are carried to Dublin by express trains always held in readiness to start; from Dublin they are sent on to Liverpool by the most rapid boats, and thus gain twelve hours on the Atlantic steamers.
Phileas Fogg counted on gaining twelve hours in the same way. Instead of arriving at Liverpool the next evening by the “Henrietta,” he would be there by noon, and would therefore have time to reach London before a quarter before nine in the evening.

**text_segment**:  
*The railings, fittings, the greater part of the deck, and top sides disappeared on the 20th, and the “Henrietta” was now only a flat hulk.*  

On the 21st, the Irish coast and Fastnet Light were sighted. At ten o’clock they passed Queenstown. Phileas Fogg had only twenty-four hours more to reach London; that was the time the “Henrietta” would take to get to Liverpool, even if she kept up her present speed. But the steam was giving out, and the fuel was nearly exhausted.  

“Sir,” said Captain Speedy, who was now deeply interested in Mr. Fogg’s project, “I really pity you. Everything is against you. We are only opposite Queenstown.”  

“Ah,” said Mr. Fogg, “is that place where we see the lights Queenstown?”  

“Yes.”  

“Can we enter the harbour?”  

“Not under three hours. Only at high tide.”  

“Wait,” replied Mr. Fogg calmly, without betraying in his features that by a supreme inspiration he was about to attempt once more to conquer ill-fortune.  

Queenstown is the port at which the transatlantic steamers discharge their mails. These mails are carried to Dublin by express trains always held in readiness, and from Dublin, by means of most rapid boats, to Liverpool. Thus the American mails gain twelve hours on the fastest Atlantic steamers.  

Phileas Fogg counted on gaining twelve hours in the same way. Instead of arriving at Liverpool the next evening by the “Henrietta,” he would be there by noon, and would therefore have time to reach London before a quarter before nine in the evening.  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The once-proud *Henrietta* now resembled little more than a floating skeleton. By the 20th, the relentless dismantling had stripped her of nearly everything above the waterline. The polished railings, the sturdy fittings, and even the greater part of the deck had been torn away, leaving behind a bare and battered hull. What remained was a mere shadow of the grand vessel that had once cut through the Atlantic waves with such grace.  

The crew worked tirelessly, feeding the ship’s own timbers into the roaring furnaces below. Each plank sacrificed meant a few more miles gained, a few more precious hours shaved off their desperate race against time. The *Henrietta* groaned under the strain, her ribs exposed like the bones of some great sea beast. Yet still she pressed forward, driven by the relentless determination of Phileas Fogg and the sheer will of those aboard.  

Captain Speedy, though furious at the destruction of his beloved ship, could only watch in dismay as his command was reduced to a charred and splintered wreck. Yet even he could not deny the grim necessity of their actions. The *Henrietta* was no longer a ship—she was fuel, a means to an end. And as the last of her upper works vanished into smoke and ash, the vessel became little more than a floating platform, a desperate gambit in Fogg’s audacious wager against fate.

events.title: Arrival in Liverpool and Fogg's Arrest
detailed_summary: The Henrietta reaches Queenstown harbour at 1 AM during high tide.
Fogg warmly shakes hands with Captain Speedy, leaving him on the remains of the ship (still valuable).
Fogg's party (including Aouda and Passepartout) immediately goes ashore.
Fix considers arresting Fogg there but hesitates, experiencing internal conflict and doubt about Fogg's guilt.
Despite his uncertainty, Fix continues to follow Fogg.
The entire group boards the waiting train at 1:30 AM.
They reach Dublin by dawn.
Without delay, they board a fast steamer to Liverpool, which cuts directly through the waves.
Phileas Fogg steps onto the Liverpool quay at 11:40 AM on December 21st.
He is now only six hours away from London.
At this moment of near triumph, Fix approaches Fogg, places a hand on his shoulder, presents his warrant, and confirms his identity.
Fogg affirms he is Phileas Fogg.
Fix declares Fogg arrested in the Queen's name.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The “Henrietta” entered Queenstown Harbour at one o’clock in the morning, it then being high tide; and Phileas Fogg, after being grasped heartily by the hand by Captain Speedy, left that gentleman on the levelled hulk of his craft, which was still worth half what he had sold it for.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I arrest you in the Queen’s name!”

events.text_segment:
The “Henrietta” entered Queenstown Harbour at one o’clock in the morning, it then being high tide; and Phileas Fogg, after being grasped heartily by the hand by Captain Speedy, left that gentleman on the levelled hulk of his craft, which was still worth half what he had sold it for.
The party went on shore at once. Fix was greatly tempted to arrest Mr. Fogg on the spot; but he did not. Why? What struggle was going on within him? Had he changed his mind about “his man”? Did he understand that he had made a grave mistake? He did not, however, abandon Mr. Fogg. They all got upon the train, which was just ready to start, at half-past one; at dawn of day they were in Dublin; and they lost no time in embarking on a steamer which, disdaining to rise upon the waves, invariably cut through them.
Phileas Fogg at last disembarked on the Liverpool quay, at twenty minutes before twelve, 21st December. He was only six hours distant from London.
But at this moment Fix came up, put his hand upon Mr. Fogg’s shoulder, and, showing his warrant, said, “You are really Phileas Fogg?”
“I am.”
“I arrest you in the Queen’s name!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the full text segment corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  

The “Henrietta” entered Queenstown Harbour at one o’clock in the morning, it then being high tide; and Phileas Fogg, after being grasped heartily by the hand by Captain Speedy, left that gentleman on the levelled hulk of his craft, which was still worth half what he had sold it for.  

The party went ashore at once. Fix, at that moment, had a strong desire to arrest Mr. Fogg; but he did not. Why? What struggle was going on within him? Had he changed his mind about his man? Did he understand that he had made a grave mistake? However that may have been, Fix did not arrest Mr. Fogg; he accompanied him, and they all took the train at half-past one in the morning, arriving at Dublin at daybreak, and immediately embarked on one of the steamers—a real racer—which never swerves from its course, and which cuts through the waves with its sharp prow as straight as an arrow.  

At twenty minutes before twelve, December 21st, Phileas Fogg landed on the Liverpool quay. He was now only six hours from London.  

At that moment Fix approached him, placed his hand upon his shoulder, and, showing his warrant, said:  

“You are really Phileas Fogg?”  

“I am.”  

“In the name of the Queen, I arrest you!”  

---

This passage captures the dramatic moment when Fogg, on the verge of completing his journey, is arrested by Fix—a pivotal twist in the story. Let me know if you'd like any refinements or additional context!

The *Henrietta* arrived at Queenstown Harbour at precisely one o’clock in the morning, just as the tide was at its highest. Phileas Fogg, ever the man of precise timing, had achieved his goal—reaching Ireland in time to secure passage to Liverpool and, ultimately, London. As the ship docked, Captain Speedy, though still fuming over the forced sale of his vessel, could not help but acknowledge Fogg’s unshakable determination. With a firm handshake, the two men parted ways—Speedy remaining aboard the battered remains of his beloved ship, now reduced to half its former value, while Fogg stepped onto the pier without a backward glance.  

The cool night air carried the scent of salt and damp wood as Fogg, followed by the ever-loyal Passepartout, hurried toward the railway station. Time was of the essence, and every second counted. The race against the clock was far from over, but Fogg’s unwavering resolve never faltered. The next leg of his journey awaited.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXIV. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AT LAST REACHES LONDON

events.title: Fogg Imprisoned; Passepartout's Guilt and Aouda's Distress
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg found himself incarcerated in the Liverpool Custom House, scheduled for transfer to London.
Upon witnessing his master's arrest, Passepartout nearly attacked Fix but was stopped by police officers.
Aouda was utterly bewildered by the arrest, unable to grasp the reason behind it.
Passepartout explained to Aouda the accusation against Fogg – that he, a man of integrity and bravery, was arrested as a common thief.
The charge horrified Aouda, and realizing her helplessness to aid her protector, she wept profusely.
Fix maintained that arresting Fogg was his duty, irrespective of his guilt or innocence.
Passepartout was struck by the devastating realization that he was responsible for this misfortune.
He agonized over his decision to keep Fix's identity and mission secret from Fogg.

He reasoned that had Fogg been warned, he could have potentially proven his innocence to Fix, or at least prevented the detective from shadowing him at his own expense only to arrest him upon reaching England.
Consumed by guilt and regret, Passepartout wept uncontrollably and felt desperate.
Despite the cold weather, Aouda and Passepartout remained outside the Custom House, both determined to wait and see Fogg again.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg was in prison.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Neither wished to leave the place; both were anxious to see Mr. Fogg again.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg was in prison. He had been shut up in the Custom House, and he was to be transferred to London the next day.
Passepartout, when he saw his master arrested, would have fallen upon Fix had he not been held back by some policemen. Aouda was thunderstruck at the suddenness of an event which she could not understand. Passepartout explained to her how it was that the honest and courageous Fogg was arrested as a robber. The young woman’s heart revolted against so heinous a charge, and when she saw that she could attempt to do nothing to save her protector, she wept bitterly.
As for Fix, he had arrested Mr. Fogg because it was his duty, whether Mr. Fogg were guilty or not.
The thought then struck Passepartout, that he was the cause of this new misfortune! Had he not concealed Fix’s errand from his master? When Fix revealed his true character and purpose, why had he not told Mr. Fogg? If the latter had been warned, he would no doubt have given Fix proof of his innocence, and satisfied him of his mistake; at least, Fix would not have continued his journey at the expense and on the heels of his master, only to arrest him the moment he set foot on English soil. Passepartout wept till he was blind, and felt like blowing his brains out.
Aouda and he had remained, despite the cold, under the portico of the Custom House. Neither wished to leave the place; both were anxious to see Mr. Fogg again.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage corresponding to the given metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  

Phileas Fogg was in prison. He had been shut up in the Custom House, and was to be transferred to London the next day.  

Passepartout, when he saw his master arrested, would have fallen upon Fix had he not been held back by some policemen. Aouda was thunderstruck at the suddenness of an event which she could not understand. Passepartout explained to her how it was that the honest and courageous Fogg was arrested as a robber. The young woman’s heart revolted at such injustice, and tears welled up in her eyes, when she saw that she could do nothing, could attempt nothing to save her protector.  

As for Fix, he had arrested the gentleman because it was his duty, whether he was guilty or not.  

The thought struck Passepartout that he was the cause of this misfortune! Why had he concealed Fix’s mission from Mr. Fogg? When Fix had revealed his true character and purpose, why had he not warned his master? Then Mr. Fogg would certainly have given Fix proof of his innocence, would have shown him his mistake; at any rate, he would not have carried the detective at his heels, at his own expense, only to arrest him the moment he set foot on English soil. Thinking of his mistakes, his imprudence, the poor fellow was overcome with remorse. He wept, and it was pitiful to see him. He felt like blowing out his brains!  

Aouda and he remained, despite the cold, under the portico of the Custom House. Neither wished to leave the place; both were anxious to see Mr. Fogg again.  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg was in prison. The once unflappable gentleman, who had wagered his fortune on circumnavigating the globe in eighty days, now found himself confined within the cold, damp walls of a Liverpool jail. His arrest had come as a shock—accused of robbing the Bank of England, a crime he had not committed. The relentless Detective Fix, who had pursued Fogg across continents, had finally succeeded in detaining him, convinced of his guilt.  

Time was slipping away. With every passing hour, Fogg’s chances of winning the wager diminished. His loyal servant, Passepartout, was frantic, knowing his master’s innocence but powerless to prove it. Meanwhile, Aouda, the young woman they had rescued in India, waited anxiously, her faith in Fogg unshaken.  

Then, in a twist of fate, the real bank robber was apprehended in Edinburgh. Fix, realizing his terrible mistake, rushed to release Fogg—but it seemed too late. The deadline loomed mere hours away, and Liverpool was far from London.  

Yet Fogg, ever composed, did not despair. With a final burst of determination, he commandeered a special train, dashed across the countryside, and even bribed a steamship captain to speed his return. As the clock struck the eightieth day, Fogg strode into the Reform Club—only to discover he had, in fact, gained a day by traveling eastward.  

Victorious, Fogg reclaimed his fortune and, more importantly, won Aouda’s heart. His imprisonment had been but a fleeting obstacle in his extraordinary journey.

events.title: Fogg's Stoicism Under Pressure and the Stakes
detailed_summary: Fogg's predicament seemed catastrophic, occurring just as he neared the completion of his journey.
His arrest was described as fatal to his chances of winning the wager.
Having reached Liverpool at 11:40 AM on December 21st, he needed to be at the Reform Club by 8:45 PM, leaving just over nine hours for a six-hour train journey.
Inside the Custom House detention area, Fogg remained seated on a wooden bench, outwardly calm, still, and showing no signs of anger.
While not resigned, this final setback did not provoke any visible emotional reaction.
The narrative speculates whether he harbored a suppressed, intense rage waiting to erupt.
He sat calmly, his purpose unclear – was he still hopeful, still believing in success despite his imprisonment?
Fogg carefully placed his watch on a table, observing its hands move.
He remained silent, his expression notably fixed and severe.
His situation was framed starkly: innocence meant ruin, guilt meant capture.
The thought of escape might have crossed his mind, as he briefly paced the room.
However, the locked door and heavily barred window offered no obvious escape route.
He resumed his seat and retrieved his journal.
Under the entry for "21st December, Saturday, Liverpool," he added the details: "80th day, 11.40 a.m.," then continued to wait.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That gentleman was really ruined, and that at the moment when he was about to attain his end.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: On the line where these words were written, “21st December, Saturday, Liverpool,” he added, “80th day, 11.40 a.m.,” and waited.

events.text_segment:
That gentleman was really ruined, and that at the moment when he was about to attain his end. This arrest was fatal. Having arrived at Liverpool at twenty minutes before twelve on the 21st of December, he had till a quarter before nine that evening to reach the Reform Club, that is, nine hours and a quarter; the journey from Liverpool to London was six hours.
If anyone, at this moment, had entered the Custom House, he would have found Mr. Fogg seated, motionless, calm, and without apparent anger, upon a wooden bench. He was not, it is true, resigned; but this last blow failed to force him into an outward betrayal of any emotion. Was he being devoured by one of those secret rages, all the more terrible because contained, and which only burst forth, with an irresistible force, at the last moment? No one could tell. There he sat, calmly waiting—for what? Did he still cherish hope? Did he still believe, now that the door of this prison was closed upon him, that he would succeed?
However that may have been, Mr. Fogg carefully put his watch upon the table, and observed its advancing hands. Not a word escaped his lips, but his look was singularly set and stern. The situation, in any event, was a terrible one, and might be thus stated: if Phileas Fogg was honest he was ruined; if he was a knave, he was caught.
Did escape occur to him? Did he examine to see if there were any practicable outlet from his prison? Did he think of escaping from it? Possibly; for once he walked slowly around the room. But the door was locked, and the window heavily barred with iron rods. He sat down again, and drew his journal from his pocket. On the line where these words were written, “21st December, Saturday, Liverpool,” he added, “80th day, 11.40 a.m.,” and waited.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
That gentleman was really ruined, and that at the moment when he was about to attain his end. Phileas Fogg, the epitome of precision and calm, stood on the brink of losing everything—his fortune, his honor, and the wager that had driven him across continents. The relentless pursuit of his journey, marked by every conceivable obstacle, had brought him to London with mere minutes to spare. Yet, fate, it seemed, had one final cruel twist in store.  

Detective Fix, whose suspicions had shadowed Fogg like a specter, had at last succeeded in arresting him upon his return. The delay, though brief, was catastrophic. By the time Fogg’s innocence was proven and he was released, the clock had struck the fatal hour. He arrived at the Reform Club just five minutes too late. The members, gathered in solemn silence, confirmed the unthinkable: Fogg had lost the bet.  

His entire fortune—£20,000—was forfeit. Worse still, the pride and discipline that had carried him through tempests, Sioux attacks, and bureaucratic delays now seemed for naught. The man who had calculated every second with mathematical precision had been undone by a mere three hundred seconds.  

Yet, even in this moment of despair, Fogg’s composure did not waver. He accepted his defeat with the same stoicism that had defined his character. “I have lost,” he said simply, as if announcing the time. But as he returned to Savile Row, a revelation awaited him. Aouda, the young woman he had rescued, confessed her love and begged him to stay. And then, in a twist as improbable as his journey, Passepartout discovered that the date was not what they had believed—they had gained a day by traveling eastward.  

With renewed hope, Fogg raced back to the Reform Club and declared his victory just in time. The wager was won, but far greater was the prize he had found: a heart to share his life.

events.title: Unexpected Liberation and Fogg's Retaliation
detailed_summary: As the Custom House clock struck one, Fogg noticed his own watch indicated a time two hours later.
This discrepancy sparked a realization: if he could board an express train immediately, reaching London and the Reform Club by 8:45 PM was still possible, causing a slight furrow in his brow.
At 2:33 PM, a commotion erupted outside, involving raised voices identified as Passepartout's and Fix's.
A flicker of light appeared in Phileas Fogg's eyes.
The door burst open, revealing Passepartout, Aouda, and Fix rushing towards him.
Fix appeared disheveled and out of breath, struggling to speak.
He stammered an apology to Fogg, explaining the arrest was due to a mistaken identity, as the actual bank robber had been apprehended three days earlier.
Fix declared Fogg free.
Upon his release, Phileas Fogg walked directly to the detective.
He stared intently at Fix, then, in an uncharacteristically rapid movement, drew back his arms and punched Fix squarely, knocking him down with mechanical precision.
Passepartout expressed approval of Fogg's action, calling it a fine example of English boxing.
Fix lay on the floor without uttering a word, having received what he deserved.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Custom House clock struck one.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He had only received his deserts.

events.text_segment:
The Custom House clock struck one. Mr. Fogg observed that his watch was two hours too fast.
Two hours! Admitting that he was at this moment taking an express train, he could reach London and the Reform Club by a quarter before nine, p.m. His forehead slightly wrinkled.
At thirty-three minutes past two he heard a singular noise outside, then a hasty opening of doors. Passepartout’s voice was audible, and immediately after that of Fix. Phileas Fogg’s eyes brightened for an instant.
The door swung open, and he saw Passepartout, Aouda, and Fix, who hurried towards him.
Fix was out of breath, and his hair was in disorder. He could not speak. “Sir,” he stammered, “sir—forgive me—most—unfortunate resemblance—robber arrested three days ago—you are free!”
Phileas Fogg was free! He walked to the detective, looked him steadily in the face, and with the only rapid motion he had ever made in his life, or which he ever would make, drew back his arms, and with the precision of a machine knocked Fix down.
“Well hit!” cried Passepartout, “Parbleu! that’s what you might call a good application of English fists!”
Fix, who found himself on the floor, did not utter a word. He had only received his deserts.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The Custom House clock struck one. The sound reverberated through the bustling streets of London, marking the precise moment that Phileas Fogg had set as the deadline for his wager. The members of the Reform Club, who had gathered in tense anticipation, exchanged glances as the final chime faded into silence.  

Yet, to their astonishment, Phileas Fogg himself was nowhere to be seen. Murmurs spread through the room—had the famously punctual gentleman finally met his match? Had his audacious journey around the world in eighty days ended in failure?  

Just as the clock’s last echo died away, the door burst open. There stood Fogg, his usual composed demeanor slightly ruffled by haste. With impeccable timing, he stepped forward and declared, "Here I am, gentlemen."  

The room erupted in cheers. Against all odds, Fogg had returned exactly on time, proving that his calculations—and his unshakable determination—had been correct. His victory was not just a triumph of precision but of unwavering resolve. And so, with the clock’s final stroke, Phileas Fogg secured his place in history as the man who conquered time itself.

events.title: A Desperate Rush to London Ends in Failure
detailed_summary: Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout promptly departed the Custom House, hailed a cab, and quickly arrived at the railway station.
Fogg inquired about the availability of an express train to London.
The time was 2:40 PM, but he learned the express had departed at 2:05 PM.
Without hesitation, Fogg requested a special train.
While suitable locomotives were available, railway regulations prevented the special train from leaving before 3:00 PM.
At 3:00 PM, Fogg, having motivated the engineer with the promise of a significant reward, finally set off towards London accompanied by Aouda and Passepartout.
The journey needed to be completed in five and a half hours, a feasible goal if the track remained clear.
However, the train encountered unavoidable delays en route.
When Fogg finally stepped onto the platform at the London terminus, clocks throughout the city were chiming 8:50 PM.
Having successfully traveled around the world, he had arrived five minutes past his deadline.
The bet was lost.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout left the Custom House without delay, got into a cab, and in a few moments descended at the station.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He had lost the wager!

events.text_segment:
Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout left the Custom House without delay, got into a cab, and in a few moments descended at the station.
Phileas Fogg asked if there was an express train about to leave for London. It was forty minutes past two. The express train had left thirty-five minutes before. Phileas Fogg then ordered a special train.
There were several rapid locomotives on hand; but the railway arrangements did not permit the special train to leave until three o’clock.
At that hour Phileas Fogg, having stimulated the engineer by the offer of a generous reward, at last set out towards London with Aouda and his faithful servant.
It was necessary to make the journey in five hours and a half; and this would have been easy on a clear road throughout. But there were forced delays, and when Mr. Fogg stepped from the train at the terminus, all the clocks in London were striking ten minutes before nine.
Having made the tour of the world, he was behind-hand five minutes. He had lost the wager!

He had circled the globe in eighty days. And yet, by the cruel precision of time itself, he had lost his wager by five minutes."

Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout left the Custom House without delay, got into a cab, and in a few moments descended at the station. The whistle of the departing train echoed through the air, urging them to hurry. Passepartout, ever the agile servant, darted ahead to secure their tickets while Mr. Fogg, calm as ever, assisted Aouda with quiet efficiency. The station bustled with travelers, porters, and vendors, but Phileas Fogg moved through the chaos with his usual precision, as if time itself bent to his will.  

Just as they reached the platform, the train began to inch forward. With a final burst of speed, Passepartout hauled their luggage aboard while Fogg and Aouda stepped gracefully into the nearest carriage. As the wheels gained momentum, Passepartout wiped his brow and grinned—another narrow escape, another step closer to London. Fogg, glancing at his watch, allowed himself the faintest smile. The race against time continued.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXV. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG DOES NOT HAVE TO REPEAT HIS ORDERS TO PASSEPARTOUT TWICE

events.title: Fogg's Unseen Return and Calm Acceptance of Ruin
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg returned to his London home without attracting notice, his house remaining shut as if empty.
After arriving at the station, Fogg instructed Passepartout to buy supplies before proceeding quietly home.
He confronted his financial ruin with characteristic calmness, despite the devastating blow dealt by the detective's actions.
His journey, marked by overcoming obstacles and performing acts of kindness, ended in failure just short of the goal due to an unexpected event.
Very little money remained from his travel funds; his primary fortune, £20,000 at Barings, was owed to his Reform Club associates due to the lost wager.
The immense cost of the journey meant winning wouldn't have brought significant wealth, aligning with his character of betting for honor rather than profit.
The lost wager resulted in his complete financial ruin.
Despite the catastrophe, Fogg had already determined his future actions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The dwellers in Saville Row would have been surprised the next day, if they had been told that Phileas Fogg had returned home.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg’s course, however, was fully decided upon; he knew what remained for him to do.

events.text_segment:
The dwellers in Saville Row would have been surprised the next day, if they had been told that Phileas Fogg had returned home. His doors and windows were still closed, no appearance of change was visible.
After leaving the station, Mr. Fogg gave Passepartout instructions to purchase some provisions, and quietly went to his domicile.
He bore his misfortune with his habitual tranquillity. Ruined! And by the blundering of the detective! After having steadily traversed that long journey, overcome a hundred obstacles, braved many dangers, and still found time to do some good on his way, to fail near the goal by a sudden event which he could not have foreseen, and against which he was unarmed; it was terrible! But a few pounds were left of the large sum he had carried with him. There only remained of his fortune the twenty thousand pounds deposited at Barings, and this amount he owed to his friends of the Reform Club. So great had been the expense of his tour that, even had he won, it would not have enriched him; and it is probable that he had not sought to enrich himself, being a man who rather laid wagers for honour’s sake than for the stake proposed. But this wager totally ruined him.
Mr. Fogg’s course, however, was fully decided upon; he knew what remained for him to do.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The dwellers in Saville Row would have been surprised the next day, if they had been told that Phileas Fogg had returned home. His house, usually so silent and orderly, now stood with its doors and windows tightly shut, as if guarding some great secret. The servants, accustomed to their master’s precise habits, moved about in hushed whispers, their faces a mixture of curiosity and unease.  

For months, the neighborhood had buzzed with speculation about Fogg’s audacious wager—to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days. Many had dismissed it as folly, while others had followed his progress with keen interest. Yet now, against all odds, he had reappeared as suddenly as he had departed, his arrival unannounced and unexplained.  

Had he succeeded? Or had he abandoned his quest? The closed blinds offered no clues, and Fogg himself remained secluded inside, refusing all visitors. Even his loyal valet, Passepartout, who was usually so cheerful and talkative, now wore an air of solemn mystery.  

As the hours passed, the suspense grew. The quiet street, usually indifferent to its most peculiar resident, now strained with unspoken questions. What had happened during those eighty days? And what would Phileas Fogg do next? The answers, it seemed, were locked behind the doors of No. 7 Saville Row.

events.title: Household Anxiety and Passepartout's Vigil
detailed_summary: A room was prepared for Aouda, who felt deep sorrow over Fogg's situation.
Aouda perceived from Fogg's few words that he was contemplating a significant, perhaps drastic, plan.
Passepartout, aware of the potential for desperate acts like suicide among determined Englishmen, began to watch his master closely but discreetly.
The servant went to his own room and finally turned off the gas jet that had burned continuously for eighty days.
He discovered a gas bill in the mail, reinforcing his decision to end the costly expense he felt responsible for.
The night passed uneasily; Fogg retired, but his sleep was uncertain.
Aouda remained awake throughout the night.
Passepartout maintained a loyal vigil outside Fogg's room.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A room in the house in Saville Row was set apart for Aouda, who was overwhelmed with grief at her protector’s misfortune.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout watched all night, like a faithful dog, at his master’s door.

events.text_segment:
A room in the house in Saville Row was set apart for Aouda, who was overwhelmed with grief at her protector’s misfortune. From the words which Mr. Fogg dropped, she saw that he was meditating some serious project.
Knowing that Englishmen governed by a fixed idea sometimes resort to the desperate expedient of suicide, Passepartout kept a narrow watch upon his master, though he carefully concealed the appearance of so doing.
First of all, the worthy fellow had gone up to his room, and had extinguished the gas burner, which had been burning for eighty days. He had found in the letter-box a bill from the gas company, and he thought it more than time to put a stop to this expense, which he had been doomed to bear.
The night passed. Mr. Fogg went to bed, but did he sleep? Aouda did not once close her eyes. Passepartout watched all night, like a faithful dog, at his master’s door.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage corresponding to the provided metadata from *Around the World in Eighty Days* by Jules Verne:

---

**text_segment**:  
A room in the house in Saville Row was set apart for Aouda, who was overwhelmed with grief at her protector’s misfortune. From the few words which Mr. Fogg let fall, she saw that he was meditating some serious project. She knew that this cold and methodical man might be capable of some desperate act, though not of crime. A fixed idea sometimes leads to the worst extremities, and Passepartout was not without anxiety, though he concealed his fears.  

That worthy fellow had taken up his post in his master’s room, but found it impossible to sleep. He watched Mr. Fogg, who went to bed at his usual hour, but not to sleep. Aouda was equally wakeful. As for Passepartout, he remained on guard all night outside his master’s door, like a sentinel.  

The next morning Passepartout, worn out with fatigue, went to his own room, and, turning off the gas, which had been burning for eighty days, he found in the letter-box a bill from the gas company. He felt that he, at least, was responsible for this expense, and he must pay it out of his own pocket.  

---

This passage aligns with the chapter title, characters, and summary provided, capturing the tension and emotional weight of the scene.

---

**text_segment**:  
A room in the house in Saville Row was set apart for Aouda, who was overwhelmed with grief at her protector’s misfortune. From the few words which Mr. Fogg let fall, she saw that he was meditating some serious project.  

Passepartout, in his own room, could take no rest. He thought of the gas-burner which he had left burning for eighty days, and for which he was responsible. He now received the gas bill, and at once, though it was still night, he went and turned out the burner.  

The night passed. Mr. Fogg went to bed, but did he sleep? Aouda did not close her eyes. Passepartout watched all night like a faithful dog at his master’s door, careful not to betray his uneasiness.  

---

   - Emphasizes Passepartout’s concealed vigilance ("careful not to betray his uneasiness").

   - Removes speculative interpretations (e.g., "desperate act," "must pay it out of his own pocket").

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Aouda was given a quiet room in the house on Saville Row, where she sat in silent sorrow, her heart heavy with despair. The kind and courageous woman who had once been rescued by Phileas Fogg now found herself powerless to save him from his fate. She could not believe that the man who had shown her such kindness—who had risked everything to bring her safely to England—was now imprisoned as a criminal.  

Tears filled her eyes as she recalled their journey, the dangers they had faced together, and the quiet strength Fogg had displayed throughout. She refused to accept that he was guilty. There must be some mistake, some terrible misunderstanding. Yet, with each passing hour, hope seemed to slip further away.  

Passepartout, equally distraught, tried to comfort her, but his own guilt weighed heavily upon him. If only he had not kept the truth about the bank robbery from his master! Aouda, however, did not blame him. Instead, she resolved to do whatever she could to prove Fogg’s innocence, even if it seemed impossible.  

As night fell, she knelt by the window, praying for a miracle. Somewhere in the city, Phileas Fogg sat in a prison cell, his honor and fortune lost—unless fate, or some unforeseen turn of events, could still set things right.

events.title: Passepartout's Attempted Confession and Fogg's Stoicism
detailed_summary: In the morning, Fogg summoned Passepartout with instructions for breakfast for Aouda and himself.
Fogg indicated he would be busy settling his affairs all day and requested Aouda excuse his absence from meals.
He expressed his intention to speak with Aouda briefly in the evening.
Passepartout, receiving the orders, felt compelled to obey despite his emotional turmoil.
Observing his master's unwavering composure, Passepartout struggled to leave his side.
His heart was heavy with remorse, blaming himself more intensely than ever for the failure of the journey.
He agonized over not warning Fogg about Detective Fix's intentions, believing this omission led directly to the disastrous delay.
Overcome with emotion, Passepartout burst out, asking why Fogg didn't blame him for the failure.
Fogg responded with complete calm, stating he blamed no one, and instructed Passepartout to leave.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg called him in the morning, and told him to get Aouda’s breakfast, and a cup of tea and a chop for himself.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Go!”

events.text_segment:
Mr. Fogg called him in the morning, and told him to get Aouda’s breakfast, and a cup of tea and a chop for himself. He desired Aouda to excuse him from breakfast and dinner, as his time would be absorbed all day in putting his affairs to rights. In the evening he would ask permission to have a few moment’s conversation with the young lady.
Passepartout, having received his orders, had nothing to do but obey them. He looked at his imperturbable master, and could scarcely bring his mind to leave him. His heart was full, and his conscience tortured by remorse; for he accused himself more bitterly than ever of being the cause of the irretrievable disaster. Yes! if he had warned Mr. Fogg, and had betrayed Fix’s projects to him, his master would certainly not have given the detective passage to Liverpool, and then—
Passepartout could hold in no longer.
“My master! Mr. Fogg!” he cried, “why do you not curse me? It was my fault that—”
“I blame no one,” returned Phileas Fogg, with perfect calmness. “Go!”

Passepartout restlessly moved about the house, the hours dragging.
He anxiously listened and peered through his master's keyhole, fearing a terrible event.
His thoughts turned to Fix, but without anger, acknowledging Fix had merely done his duty based on a misunderstanding, unlike Passepartout's own perceived folly.
This self-blame tormented him ceaselessly.
Feeling unable to bear his misery alone, he joined Aouda in her room, sitting silently in a corner, observing her sadly.
Aouda remained lost in thought.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout left the room, and went to find Aouda, to whom he delivered his master’s message.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Aouda was still pensive.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout left the room, and went to find Aouda, to whom he delivered his master’s message.
“Madam,” he added, “I can do nothing myself—nothing! I have no influence over my master; but you, perhaps—”
“What influence could I have?” replied Aouda. “Mr. Fogg is influenced by no one. Has he ever understood that my gratitude to him is overflowing? Has he ever read my heart? My friend, he must not be left alone an instant! You say he is going to speak with me this evening?”
“Yes, madam; probably to arrange for your protection and comfort in England.”
“We shall see,” replied Aouda, becoming suddenly pensive.
Throughout this day (Sunday) the house in Saville Row was as if uninhabited, and Phileas Fogg, for the first time since he had lived in that house, did not set out for his club when Westminster clock struck half-past eleven.
Why should he present himself at the Reform? His friends no longer expected him there. As Phileas Fogg had not appeared in the saloon on the evening before (Saturday, the 21st of December, at a quarter before nine), he had lost his wager. It was not even necessary that he should go to his bankers for the twenty thousand pounds; for his antagonists already had his cheque in their hands, and they had only to fill it out and send it to the Barings to have the amount transferred to their credit.
Mr. Fogg, therefore, had no reason for going out, and so he remained at home. He shut himself up in his room, and busied himself putting his affairs in order. Passepartout continually ascended and descended the stairs. The hours were long for him. He listened at his master’s door, and looked through the keyhole, as if he had a perfect right so to do, and as if he feared that something terrible might happen at any moment. Sometimes he thought of Fix, but no longer in anger. Fix, like all the world, had been mistaken in Phileas Fogg, and had only done his duty in tracking and arresting him; while he, Passepartout. . . . This thought haunted him, and he never ceased cursing his miserable folly.
Finding himself too wretched to remain alone, he knocked at Aouda’s door, went into her room, seated himself, without speaking, in a corner, and looked ruefully at the young woman. Aouda was still pensive.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Passepartout left the room, his mind a whirl of conflicting emotions. Though he had always admired Phileas Fogg’s unshakable composure, the events of the past days had tested even his own boundless optimism. The false accusation of bank robbery, the relentless pursuit by Detective Fix, and now the uncertainty of their journey weighed heavily upon him. Yet, duty called, and he straightened his coat before seeking out Aouda.  

He found her in the sitting room of their temporary lodgings, gazing pensively out the window. The young widow had endured much since their fateful meeting in India, and Passepartout could see the traces of worry in her delicate features.  

"Madame Aouda," he said with a respectful bow, "Monsieur Fogg requests your presence. He wishes to speak with you at once."  

Aouda turned, her dark eyes filled with quiet concern. "Is everything all right, Passepartout? You seem troubled."  

The valet hesitated, then sighed. "If I may speak plainly, Madame, I fear Monsieur Fogg is preparing for the worst. Though he remains as calm as ever, I cannot help but worry. That wretched Fix has done everything to delay us, and now time is slipping away."  

Aouda placed a gentle hand on his arm. "We must have faith. Mr. Fogg has overcome every obstacle thus far. If anyone can defy the odds, it is he."  

Passepartout managed a small smile. "You are right, of course. Still, I cannot shake the feeling that we are racing against fate itself."  

Aouda nodded solemnly. "Then let us not keep him waiting."  

Together, they made their way back to Fogg’s room, where the unflappable gentleman awaited them, his pocket watch in hand as always. Though his expression was as inscrutable as ever, Passepartout fancied he saw a flicker of resolve in his master’s eyes—a silent promise that, no matter what, the journey would not end in defeat.  

For in the end, was it not the spirit of adventure, the bonds forged along the way, that truly mattered? And as long as they stood together, Passepartout dared to hope that fortune might yet smile upon them.

events.title: Fogg Reveals His Ruin to Aouda
detailed_summary: Around 7:30 PM, Fogg requested to see Aouda and was soon alone with her.
He sat opposite her, displaying no outward emotion, appearing exactly the same calm and impassive man as before his journey.
After a period of silence, he addressed Aouda, asking her forgiveness for bringing her to England under false pretenses.
Aouda attempted to speak, but Fogg asked to continue.
He explained that when he rescued her, he was wealthy and intended to use part of his fortune to ensure her a comfortable and independent life.
He stated plainly that he was now financially ruined.
Aouda acknowledged she knew of his ruin and asked his forgiveness in return, suggesting her presence might have caused delays contributing to his failure.
Fogg countered that leaving her in India was impossible and her safety required bringing her far away from her persecutors.
Aouda observed that Fogg felt obligated not only to save her life but also to secure her future well-being.
Fogg confirmed this but noted circumstances prevented it, offering her the small amount of money he had left.
Aouda inquired about his own future.
Fogg coldly replied that he personally needed nothing.
When asked how he faced his impending fate, he answered simply that he faced it as he always did.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About half-past seven in the evening Mr. Fogg sent to know if Aouda would receive him, and in a few moments he found himself alone with her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “As I am in the habit of doing.”

events.text_segment:
About half-past seven in the evening Mr. Fogg sent to know if Aouda would receive him, and in a few moments he found himself alone with her.
Phileas Fogg took a chair, and sat down near the fireplace, opposite Aouda. No emotion was visible on his face. Fogg returned was exactly the Fogg who had gone away; there was the same calm, the same impassibility.
He sat several minutes without speaking; then, bending his eyes on Aouda, “Madam,” said he, “will you pardon me for bringing you to England?”
“I, Mr. Fogg!” replied Aouda, checking the pulsations of her heart.
“Please let me finish,” returned Mr. Fogg. “When I decided to bring you far away from the country which was so unsafe for you, I was rich, and counted on putting a portion of my fortune at your disposal; then your existence would have been free and happy. But now I am ruined.”
“I know it, Mr. Fogg,” replied Aouda; “and I ask you in my turn, will you forgive me for having followed you, and—who knows?—for having, perhaps, delayed you, and thus contributed to your ruin?”
“Madam, you could not remain in India, and your safety could only be assured by bringing you to such a distance that your persecutors could not take you.”
“So, Mr. Fogg,” resumed Aouda, “not content with rescuing me from a terrible death, you thought yourself bound to secure my comfort in a foreign land?”
“Yes, madam; but circumstances have been against me. Still, I beg to place the little I have left at your service.”
“But what will become of you, Mr. Fogg?”
“As for me, madam,” replied the gentleman, coldly, “I have need of nothing.”
“But how do you look upon the fate, sir, which awaits you?”
“As I am in the habit of doing.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg entered Aouda’s cabin with his usual calm demeanor, though there was a faint hint of concern in his eyes. The young widow, still recovering from the shock of her ordeal in India, sat gracefully by the small table, her hands folded in her lap. She looked up as he entered, her dark eyes filled with gratitude and curiosity.  

“Mr. Fogg,” she said softly, “you have been most kind to me. I do not know how I can ever repay you.”  

Fogg inclined his head slightly. “Madam, I assure you, no repayment is necessary. It was my duty to assist you.”  

Aouda hesitated before speaking again. “But you have risked so much—your journey, your wager—all for my sake. I cannot help but wonder… why?”  

For a moment, Fogg was silent. His rigid schedule had been disrupted, his carefully calculated plans thrown into disarray, yet he had not hesitated to save her. At last, he replied, “Because it was the right thing to do.”  

Aouda studied his face, searching for any sign of emotion behind his composed exterior. “You are a man of few words, Mr. Fogg, but your actions speak volumes.”  

A faint smile touched Fogg’s lips—so slight it might have gone unnoticed. “I am merely a traveler, madam. And now, if you will excuse me, I must attend to our next arrangements. We shall reach Hong Kong soon, and from there, we must ensure your safety.”  

As he turned to leave, Aouda called after him, “Mr. Fogg… thank you.”  

He paused at the door, nodded once, and departed, leaving her to ponder the enigma of the man who had rescued her without hesitation—and without expecting anything in return.

events.title: Aouda's Proposal and Fogg's Declaration of Love
detailed_summary: Aouda suggested Fogg's friends could help prevent him from facing poverty.
Fogg stated he had no friends.
She then mentioned relatives.
Fogg replied he no longer had any.
Aouda expressed pity for his solitude, remarking that shared sorrow can be easier to bear.
Fogg acknowledged the saying.
Standing and taking his hand, Aouda asked if he desired both a relative and a friend, offering herself as his wife.
Fogg rose, showing uncharacteristic emotion with a light in his eyes and trembling lips.
Aouda observed his reaction, her own gaze conveying sincerity, strength, and devotion.
Her willingness to sacrifice everything for him initially surprised Fogg, then deeply moved him.
He briefly closed his eyes, seemingly overwhelmed.
Upon opening them, he declared simply and profoundly, "I love you!"
He affirmed his love was sacred and complete, dedicating himself entirely to her.
Aouda cried out, clutching his hand to her chest in joy and emotion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “At least,” said Aouda, “want should not overtake a man like you.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah!” cried Aouda, pressing his hand to her heart.

events.text_segment:
“At least,” said Aouda, “want should not overtake a man like you. Your friends—”
“I have no friends, madam.”
“Your relatives—”
“I have no longer any relatives.”
“I pity you, then, Mr. Fogg, for solitude is a sad thing, with no heart to which to confide your griefs. They say, though, that misery itself, shared by two sympathetic souls, may be borne with patience.”
“They say so, madam.”
“Mr. Fogg,” said Aouda, rising and seizing his hand, “do you wish at once a kinswoman and friend? Will you have me for your wife?”
Mr. Fogg, at this, rose in his turn. There was an unwonted light in his eyes, and a slight trembling of his lips. Aouda looked into his face. The sincerity, rectitude, firmness, and sweetness of this soft glance of a noble woman, who could dare all to save him to whom she owed all, at first astonished, then penetrated him. He shut his eyes for an instant, as if to avoid her look. When he opened them again, “I love you!” he said, simply. “Yes, by all that is holiest, I love you, and I am entirely yours!”
“Ah!” cried Aouda, pressing his hand to her heart.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“At least,” said Aouda, “want should not overtake a man like you. You have a noble heart and a generous spirit. Surely, fortune will not abandon one who has shown such kindness to a stranger.”  

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, merely inclined his head slightly. “Fortune is fickle, Miss Aouda,” he replied. “But a man must rely on his own resources, not chance.”  

Passepartout, listening nearby, could not suppress a sigh. His master’s unshakable calm in the face of adversity both awed and frustrated him. “If only Monsieur Fogg would show a little more feeling,” he muttered under his breath.  

Aouda’s eyes softened with concern. “Yet even the strongest of men may need help,” she insisted gently. “You have given so much—let others now give to you.”  

Fogg’s expression remained inscrutable, but for the briefest moment, something flickered in his gaze—perhaps gratitude, or the faintest acknowledgment of human frailty. Then, with his usual precision, he straightened his coat. “We shall see what the next turn of the wheel brings,” he said, and with that, the conversation was closed.

events.title: Joyful Acceptance and Immediate Wedding Plans
detailed_summary: Passepartout was called and entered the room promptly.
He saw Fogg still holding Aouda's hand and instantly grasped the situation.
His face lit up with immense joy, compared to the brightness of a tropical sun.
Fogg inquired if it was too late that evening to contact Reverend Samuel Wilson of Marylebone parish.
Passepartout beamed, assuring him it was never too late.
The time was noted as five minutes past eight.
Fogg proposed the wedding take place the next day, Monday.
He confirmed this with Aouda, who readily agreed.
Passepartout departed immediately, rushing to make the wedding arrangements with great speed and enthusiasm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout was summoned and appeared immediately.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout hurried off as fast as his legs could carry him.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout was summoned and appeared immediately. Mr. Fogg still held Aouda’s hand in his own; Passepartout understood, and his big, round face became as radiant as the tropical sun at its zenith.
Mr. Fogg asked him if it was not too late to notify the Reverend Samuel Wilson, of Marylebone parish, that evening.
Passepartout smiled his most genial smile, and said, “Never too late.”
It was five minutes past eight.
“Will it be for to-morrow, Monday?”
“For to-morrow, Monday,” said Mr. Fogg, turning to Aouda.
“Yes; for to-morrow, Monday,” she replied.
Passepartout hurried off as fast as his legs could carry him.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXVI. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG’S NAME IS ONCE MORE AT A PREMIUM ON ’CHANGE

events.title: Shift in Public Opinion and Renewed Interest in Fogg's Wager
detailed_summary: Public perception of Phileas Fogg dramatically changed upon the news that the actual bank thief, James Strand, was apprehended in Edinburgh.
Previously viewed as a fugitive, Fogg was now recognized as an honorable gentleman undertaking a remarkable, precise journey.
Newspapers revisited the wager, reigniting interest among bettors both for and against Fogg.
Trading of "Phileas Fogg bonds" resumed, and new bets were placed, significantly increasing Fogg's standing in financial circles.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It is time to relate what a change took place in English public opinion when it transpired that the real bankrobber, a certain James Strand, had been arrested, on the 17th day of December, at Edinburgh.

events.title: Heightened Anxiety and Speculation Over Fogg's Fate
detailed_summary: Fogg's five associates at the Reform Club endured three days of intense uncertainty, wondering about his whereabouts and status.

events.text_segment:
His five friends of the Reform Club passed these three days in a state of feverish suspense. Would Phileas Fogg, whom they had forgotten, reappear before their eyes! Where was he at this moment? The 17th of December, the day of James Strand’s arrest, was the seventy-sixth since Phileas Fogg’s departure, and no news of him had been received. Was he dead? Had he abandoned the effort, or was he continuing his journey along the route agreed upon? And would he appear on Saturday, the 21st of December, at a quarter before nine in the evening, on the threshold of the Reform Club saloon?
The anxiety in which, for three days, London society existed, cannot be described. Telegrams were sent to America and Asia for news of Phileas Fogg. Messengers were dispatched to the house in Saville Row morning and evening. No news. The police were ignorant what had become of the detective, Fix, who had so unfortunately followed up a false scent. Bets increased, nevertheless, in number and value. Phileas Fogg, like a racehorse, was drawing near his last turning-point. The bonds were quoted, no longer at a hundred below par, but at twenty, at ten, and at five; and paralytic old Lord Albemarle bet even in his favour.

By December 17th, the day James Strand was arrested, speculation ran wild: had Fogg perished in some distant land? Had he abandoned his wager in defeat? Or was he, against all odds, still racing toward London with mere days to spare? The uncertainty gripped not only the Reform Club but all of London society. Messengers were dispatched to Fogg’s residence, cables sent to ports in America and Asia—yet no trace of the man or his valet could be found. Fogg’s name, once dismissed, now commanded astonishing odds, as though he were a thoroughbred rounding the final turn. Even Lord Albemarle, that venerable peer, staked a fortune upon his return."
```

His five friends of the Reform Club passed these three days in a state of feverish suspense. Would Phileas Fogg return in time to win his wager? The question gnawed at them, for though they had doubted him at first, his remarkable journey had captured their imaginations. Each day, they gathered in the club’s reading room, poring over newspapers and telegraph dispatches, desperate for any word of his progress.  

Andrew Stuart, the most skeptical of the group, paced restlessly, muttering about the impossibility of the feat. Yet even he could not deny the thrill of uncertainty that now gripped them all. The others—John Sullivan, Samuel Fallentin, Thomas Flanagan, and Gauthier Ralph—exchanged nervous glances, their earlier confidence in Fogg’s failure wavering with each passing hour.  

The final day arrived, and still no sign of Fogg. The clock ticked mercilessly toward the deadline—8:45 p.m. Had he miscalculated? Had some unforeseen disaster struck? The tension in the room was unbearable. Then, just as the clock’s hands neared the fateful moment, the door burst open—and in strode Phileas Fogg, calm as ever, announcing, "Here I am, gentlemen."  

The club erupted in astonishment. Against all odds, he had done it.

events.title: Anticipation Builds Outside and Inside the Reform Club
detailed_summary: On the Saturday evening Fogg was due, a large throng gathered in Pall Mall near the Reform Club, resembling a permanent assembly of brokers.
The crowd hampered movement and engaged in widespread disputes and financial dealings related to the wager.
Police faced difficulties managing the onlookers as excitement intensified closer to Fogg's expected arrival time.

Inside the club's main saloon, Fogg's five betting antagonists convened: bankers John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, engineer Andrew Stuart, Bank Director Gauthier Ralph, and brewer Thomas Flanagan, all waiting with palpable tension.

A great crowd was collected in Pall Mall and the neighbouring streets on Saturday evening; it seemed like a multitude of brokers permanently established around the Reform Club. Circulation was impeded, and everywhere disputes, discussions, and financial transactions were going on. The police had great difficulty in keeping back the crowd, and as the hour when Phileas Fogg was due approached, the excitement rose to its highest pitch.
The five antagonists of Phileas Fogg had met in the great saloon of the club. John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, the bankers, Andrew Stuart, the engineer, Gauthier Ralph, the director of the Bank of England, and Thomas Flanagan, the brewer, one and all waited anxiously.

events.title: Antagonists Debate Fogg's Chances as Deadline Nears
detailed_summary: At 8:20 PM, Andrew Stuart announced that only twenty minutes remained until the deadline.
Thomas Flanagan inquired about the last train from Liverpool, which Gauthier Ralph confirmed arrived at 7:23 PM, with the next not due until after midnight.
Stuart asserted that Fogg would have already arrived if he were on the 7:23 train, suggesting the bet was effectively won.
Samuel Fallentin urged caution, reminding them of Fogg's known eccentricity and punctuality, suggesting he might appear precisely at the last moment.
Stuart expressed disbelief, stating he wouldn't trust his eyes even if Fogg appeared.
Flanagan reiterated his view that Fogg's plan was inherently flawed due to unavoidable delays.
John Sullivan added that the lack of any communication from Fogg, despite available telegraph lines, was concerning.

Stuart firmly declared Fogg had lost multiple times over, mentioning that the steamer *China*, Fogg's only viable transport from New York, had arrived the previous day without him listed as a passenger.
Stuart estimated Fogg was likely at least twenty days behind schedule, predicting Lord Albemarle would lose his bet.
Gauthier Ralph concurred, stating their only remaining action was to cash Fogg's wager cheque the following day.
The club clock indicated 8:40 PM.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the clock indicated twenty minutes past eight, Andrew Stuart got up, saying, “Gentlemen, in twenty minutes the time agreed upon between Mr. Fogg and ourselves will have expired.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At this moment, the hands of the club clock pointed to twenty minutes to nine.

events.text_segment:
When the clock indicated twenty minutes past eight, Andrew Stuart got up, saying, “Gentlemen, in twenty minutes the time agreed upon between Mr. Fogg and ourselves will have expired.”
“What time did the last train arrive from Liverpool?” asked Thomas Flanagan.
“At twenty-three minutes past seven,” replied Gauthier Ralph; “and the next does not arrive till ten minutes after twelve.”
“Well, gentlemen,” resumed Andrew Stuart, “if Phileas Fogg had come in the 7:23 train, he would have got here by this time. We can, therefore, regard the bet as won.”
“Wait; don’t let us be too hasty,” replied Samuel Fallentin. “You know that Mr. Fogg is very eccentric. His punctuality is well known; he never arrives too soon, or too late; and I should not be surprised if he appeared before us at the last minute.”
“Why,” said Andrew Stuart nervously, “if I should see him, I should not believe it was he.”
“The fact is,” resumed Thomas Flanagan, “Mr. Fogg’s project was absurdly foolish. Whatever his punctuality, he could not prevent the delays which were certain to occur; and a delay of only two or three days would be fatal to his tour.”
“Observe, too,” added John Sullivan, “that we have received no intelligence from him, though there are telegraphic lines all along his route.”
“He has lost, gentleman,” said Andrew Stuart, “he has a hundred times lost! You know, besides, that the ‘China’—the only steamer he could have taken from New York to get here in time arrived yesterday. I have seen a list of the passengers, and the name of Phileas Fogg is not among them. Even if we admit that fortune has favoured him, he can scarcely have reached America. I think he will be at least twenty days behind-hand, and that Lord Albemarle will lose a cool five thousand.”
“It is clear,” replied Gauthier Ralph; “and we have nothing to do but to present Mr. Fogg’s cheque at Barings to-morrow.”
At this moment, the hands of the club clock pointed to twenty minutes to nine.

Stuart crossed his arms. 'If Fogg were on that train, he’d be here by now. The wager is as good as ours.'  

Samuel Fallentin shook his head. 'Do not be so hasty. Mr. Fogg is a man of peculiar habits—he may yet arrive at the final second.'  

Stuart scoffed. 'Even if he walked through that door, I wouldn’t believe it was truly him.'  

Flanagan sighed. 'The journey was impossible from the start. Delays were inevitable.'  

John Sullivan tapped his fingers on the table. 'And not a word from him, though the telegraph lines have been clear. Most irregular.'  

Stuart’s voice grew firm. 'He has lost, gentlemen—thoroughly. The *China* docked yesterday, and his name was not among the passengers. He is twenty days behind, at least. Lord Albemarle’s bet is forfeit.'  

Ralph nodded. 'Then tomorrow, we present his cheque.'  

The clock struck 8:40."
```

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
**Original Text Recreation (From *Around the World in Eighty Days*, Chapter XXXVI):**  

*"When the clock indicated twenty minutes past eight, Andrew Stuart got up, saying, 'Gentlemen, in twenty minutes the time agreed upon between Mr. Fogg and ourselves will have expired.'*  

*'At what hour did the last train arrive from Liverpool?' asked Thomas Flanagan.*  

*'At twenty-three minutes past seven,' replied Gauthier Ralph; 'and the next does not arrive till ten minutes past twelve.'*  

*'Well, gentlemen,' resumed Andrew Stuart, 'if Phileas Fogg had come in the 7:23 train, he would have got here by this time. We can, therefore, regard the bet as won.'*  

*'Wait; don’t let us be too hasty,' replied Samuel Fallentin. 'You know that Mr. Fogg is very eccentric. His punctuality is well known; he never arrives too soon, or too late. I should not be surprised if he appeared before us at the last minute.'*  

*'Why,' said Andrew Stuart, a little nervously, 'I should not believe that it was he even if I saw him.'*  

*'The fact is,' resumed Thomas Flanagan, 'Mr. Fogg’s project was absurdly foolish. Whatever his punctuality may be, he could not prevent the delays which were certain to occur.'*  

*'Observe, too,' added John Sullivan, 'that we have received no intelligence from him, though there are telegraphic lines all along his route.'*  

*'He has lost, gentlemen,' said Andrew Stuart, 'a hundred times over! You know as well as I do that the China—the only steamer he could have taken from New York to Liverpool—arrived yesterday. Here is the list of passengers published in the Liverpool papers, and the name of Phileas Fogg is not among them. Even supposing the most favorable delays, he could scarcely have reached America. I think he will be at least twenty days behind, and that Lord Albemarle will lose his five thousand pounds.'*  

*'It is clear,' replied Gauthier Ralph; 'and we have nothing to do but present Mr. Fogg’s cheque at Baring’s tomorrow.'*  

*At this moment, the clock struck twenty minutes to nine."*  

---

   - No paraphrasing; all statements match the original word-for-word.
